Cartographers can compare multiple editions, states, and impressions of several of the most important maps of the period, follow the development of a particular map from the manuscript sketch to the finished printed version and its foreign derivatives, and examine the cartographic styles and techniques of surveyors and mapmakers from seven countries: Great Britain, France, Germany, Spain, Holland, Italy, and the U.S.

image.caption: North America -- 1763
image.alttext: An accurate map of North America. Describing and distinguishing the British, Spanish and French dominions on this great continent; according to the definitive treaty concluded at Paris 10th Feby. 1763

resource.title: Map Collections: 1544-1996
resource.description: offers thousands of digitized online maps. The collections are broken into seven categories, cities and towns, conservation and environment, discovery and exploration, immigration and settlement, military battles and campaigns, transportation and communication, and general maps.

image.caption: Washington, DC -- 1835
image.alttext: District of Columbia. Bradford, T. G. 1802-1887. (Thomas Gamaliel),Published [Boston : T.G. Bradford, 1835]. Shows major streets and buildings.

resource.title: Places in the News
resource.description: presents maps of a geographic location currently in the news.

image.caption: Iraq and Iran
image.alttext: Contemporary Iraq occupies territory traditionally considered the site of the earliest civilizations of the ancient Near East.

resource.title: Railroad Maps of North America
resource.description: offers progress report surveys for individual railroad lines, official government surveys, promotional maps, maps showing land grants and rights-of-way, and route guides published by commercial firms illustrate the growth of travel and settlement as well as the development of industry and agriculture in the United States.

image.caption: Peru and Indianapolis Rail Road
image.alttext: Outline map with colored state boundaries of the northeastern and north-central United States indicating larger cities. Shows

resource.title: Architecture and Interior Design for 20th Century America: Samuel Gottscho and William Schleisner
resource.description: offer over 29,000 images primarily of architectural subjects, including interiors and exteriors of homes, stores, offices, factories, historic buildings, and other structures. Subjects are concentrated chiefly in the northeastern United States, especially the New York City area, and Florida. Included are the homes of notable Americans, such as Raymond Loewy, and of several U.S. presidents, as well as color images of the 1939-40 New York World's Fair.

image.caption: Music room to balcony
image.alttext: Charles E.F. McCann, residence in Oyster Bay, Long Island, New York. General view, music room to balcony. Gottscho, Samuel H. (Samuel Herman), 1875-1971, photographer.

resource.title: George Washington Papers
resource.description: includes letters, diaries, financial accounts, military records, and other writings from Washington's youth and service as a surveyor and colonel, as delegate to the Continental Congress, as commander during the Revolutionary War, and as president (1789-97). His many interests and correspondents make these papers are a rich source for almost every aspect of early American history.

image.caption: The diaries...
image.alttext: Color halftone print of the George Washington portrait by Gilbert Stuart, from Prints and Photographs Division, Library of Congress. c1929.

interestingfact.text: Between 1747 and 1799, Washington surveyed over 200 tracts of land and held title to more than 65,000 acres in 37 locations.

resource.title: The Diaries of George Washington
resource.description: features the colorful diaries of the first U.S. President, written between 1748 and 1799. They chronicle his life from his time as a self-made farmer to his tenure as a soldier-statesman.

image.caption: Portrait of George Washington,
image.alttext: Portrait of George Washington, posing, turned slightly left, armed with gun and sword.

resource.title: Built in America: Historic American Buildings Survey/Historic American Engineering Record, 1933-Present
resource.description: documents the achievements in architecture, engineering, and design in the U.S., including examples as diverse as windmills, one-room schoolhouses, the Golden Gate Bridge, and buildings designed by Frank Lloyd Wright. The site offers searches to thousands of drawings, large-format photographs, and written histories for more than 35,000 historic structures and sites dating from the 17th to the 20th century.

image.caption: Freestanding spiral staircase
image.alttext: This beautiful freestanding spiral staircase climbs from the first floor to the attic of the Captain Charles L. Shrewsbury House. General view of circular stair, first floor, from the north. Photogra

resource.title: Fiddle Tunes of the Old Frontier
resource.description: is a collection of 184 original sound recordings of traditional fiddle tunes performed by Henry Reed of Glen Lyn, Virginia, and recorded by folklorist Alan Jabbour. The tunes represent the music, history, and spirit of Virginia's Appalachian frontier. The site also offers musical transcriptions with descriptive notes on tune histories and musical features and an illustrated essay about Reed's life, art, and influence.

image.caption: Josh and Henry Reed
image.alttext: Josh and Henry Reed, ca. 1903. Henry Reed, age 19, plays banjo and his older brother Josh plays fiddle.

resource.title: Baseball and Jackie Robinson
resource.description: includes a narrative presentation of early baseball photos (1860s-1920) and a timeline titled "Baseball, the Color Line, and Jackie Robinson" (1860 - 1972).

resource.title: The Capital and the Bay
resource.description: consists of 139 books -- first-person narratives, early histories, historical biographies, promotional brochures, and photograph collections that capture this distinctive region as it developed between the onset of European settlement and the first quarter of the 20th Century.

image.caption: Inside the Dome of the Capitol
image.alttext: Inside section of the Dome of the Capitol,' Washington, Outside and Inside. A Picture and a Narrative of the Origin, Growth, Excellencies, Abuses, Beauties, and Personages of Our Governing City. By G

resource.title: Southern Mosaic: The John and Ruby Lomax 1939 Southern States Recording Trip
resource.description: is a field collection of 700 sound recordings, field notes, dust jackets, and other manuscripts documenting a three-month, 6,502-mile trip through the southern U.S. The recordings include ballads, blues, children's songs, cowboy songs, fiddle tunes, field hollers, lullabies, play-party songs, religious dramas, spirituals, and work songs.

image.caption: Wayne Perry playing fiddle
image.alttext: [Wayne Perry playing fiddle, Crowley, Louisiana]. Lomax, Alan, 1915- photographer. [between 1934 and 1950]

resource.title: Words and Deeds in American History
resource.description: presents historical documents spanning from the 15th to the mid-20th century. Included are the papers of presidents, cabinet ministers, members of Congress, Supreme Court justices, military officers and diplomats, reformers and political activists, artists and writers, scientists and inventors, and other Americans whose lives reflect our country's evolution. A detailed description accompanies each document.

image.caption: James McNeill Whistler's Peacock Room
image.alttext: Illustrated letter, Aubrey Beardsley to G. F. Scotson-Clark concerning James McNeill Whistler's Peacock Room, [1891].

resource.title: The Thomas Jefferson Papers
resource.description: contains more than 20,000 digitized images of various letters, memoranda, notes, and drafts of documents, books, papers, letters, and manuscripts of the third President, as well as correspondence, commonplace books, and financial account books. The online collection is being produced in installments. The first release deals with Mr. Jefferson's general correspondence, dating from 1621 through 1789, and documents relating to Virginia history, from 1606-1737.

image.caption: Thomas Jefferson
image.alttext: Th. Jefferson, photomechanical print, created/published [between 1890 and 1940(?)]. Library of Congress. This print is a reproduction of the 1805 Rembrandt Peale painting of Thomas Jefferson held by

interestingfact.text: "Bigotry is the disease of ignorance, of morbid minds; enthusiasm of the free and buoyant. Education and free discussion are the antidotes of both."

resource.title: Votes for Women: Selections from NAWSA Collection, 1848-1921
resource.description: consists of 167 books, pamphlets, and other artifacts documenting the suffrage campaign. They are a subset of the Library's collection donated by Carrie Chapman Catt, longtime president of the National American Woman Suffrage Association. The collection includes works from the libraries of other members and officers of the organization, including, Elizabeth Cady Stanton, Susan B. Anthony, Lucy Stone, Alice Stone Blackwell, Julia Ward Howe, Elizabeth Smith Miller, and Mary A. Livermore.

image.caption: The terrible triplets
image.alttext: A book equates feminism and woman suffrage with both socialism and atheism. According to the author, feminism and the enfranchisement of women will destroy the family. The book also suggests that preg

resource.title: Buckaroos in Paradise: Ranching Culture in Northern Nevada, 1945-1982
resource.description: presents documentation of a northern Nevada cattle-ranching community, with a focus on the family-run Ninety-Six Ranch and its cowboys, known as buckaroos. This collection presents 41 motion pictures and 28 sound recordings of the ranch. In addition there are 2,400 still photographs portraying the people, sites, and traditions on other ranches and in the larger community.

image.caption: Roping, ninety-six ranch
image.alttext: Roping, Ninety-Six Ranch [35mm slide] Fleischhauer, Carl, photographer.

resource.title: Turn of the Century First Ladies... Who's That Lady?
resource.description: is an online "bowl event" where teams of students compete by naming First Ladies who appear in a slideshow.

resource.title: Port of Entry: Immigration
resource.description: is a game in which the viewer assumes the role of historical detective, searching for clues in photographs and eyewitness accounts about immigrant life in America.

image.caption: Italian bread peddlers
image.alttext: Italian bread peddlers, Mulberry St., New York. Byron (Firm : New York, N.Y.), photographer. Created/Published [ca. 1900]

resource.title: Big Picture: Jigsaw Puzzles
resource.description: provides online jigsaw puzzles from the Library of Congress's photo collection. Once the photo is assembled, the reader can search the Library's web site to identify it.

resource.title: Elections... the American Way
resource.description: looks at political campaigns by exploring the history and roles of candidates and voters, the structure of the party system and election process, and tough issues that politicians have faced over the years.

resource.title: Inaugurations
resource.description: profiles Presidential inaugurations of the past using primary sources from the American Memory historicalcollections of the Library of Congress. Through images, film, and personal recollections users can view the pomp and circumstance of Inaugurations.

image.caption: First Capitol Inauguration, 1829
image.alttext: First Capitol Inauguration 1829. Chief Justice John Marshall administering the oath of office to Andrew Jackson

interestingfact.text: George Washington set a precedent for future Presidents when he delivered the first inaugural address on April 30, 1789. Washington used the opportunity to discuss some of his positions, including his refusal to take a salary while in office.

resource.title: Thanksgiving in American Memory
resource.description: features photographs and discussions, poems, proclamations, and other material related to the holiday.

image.caption: First Thanksgiving
image.alttext: A Detail of a Photographic Reproduction of J.L.G. Ferris's Early-20th Century Painting, 'First Thanksgiving.'

interestingfact.text: On September 28, 1863, magazine editor Sarah Hale wrote a letter to President Abraham Lincoln encouraging him to proclaim a national Thanksgiving Day. This was part of Hale's 17-year campaign to establish Thanksgiving Day as a national holiday.

resource.title: American Memory Timeline
resource.description: helps teachers and students navigate the vast online collections of primary source materials at the Library of Congress. The links, arranged by chronological period, lead to sets of selected primary sources on a variety of topics in U.S. history.

image.caption: Jacqueline Kennedy
image.alttext: First official White House photograph of Mrs. John F. Kennedy, half-length portrait, seated on couch, facing front.

subject.subcategory: Other History & Social Studies: U.S. History Time Periods

resource.title: Women Pioneers in American Memory
resource.description: features photographs of women throughout American history who have forged ahead to make a better life for themselves, their families, and their society. These women include pioneers who journeyed across the country to settle unknown western territories, as well as women who struggled for recognition as equals in politics, in the workforce, and in their communities.

image.caption: Bombardier nose section
image.alttext: This girl in a glass house is putting finishing touches on the bombardier nose section of a B-17F navy bomber, Long Beach, Calif. Palmer, Alfred T., photographer. 1942 Oct.

resource.title: The Learning Page
resource.description: helps teachers use the Library of Congress's "American Memory" website to teach U.S. history and culture. It includes suggestions for using photos, objects, life histories and other primary sources; tools for analyzing primary sources; and a "lesson framework" for incorporating primary sources into all phases of instruction. It features 40 teacher-developed lessons on 17 topics, including the Revolutionary Era, Civil War, Emergence of Modern America and Great Depression.

image.caption: Around the World?
image.alttext: Saddled camel (1894). Jackson, William Henry, 1843-1942, photographer.

resource.title: From Jim Crow to Linda Brown: A Retrospective of the African-American Experience, 1897-1953
resource.description: helps students understand themes of African American life in the first half of the 20th century and explore to what extent the African American experience was "separate but equal." Among the activities, students examine Plessy v. Ferguson (1897) and simulate the 1898 meeting of the Afro-American Council.

image.caption: Progress of a people
image.alttext: American Sketches: A Negro Congregation in Washington. Artist unknown. Wood Engraving, Illustrated London News, November 18, 1876. LC-USZ62-50584.

resource.title: America Dreams
resource.description: investigates what the American Dream has meant over the years to poets, politicians, comedians, musicians, photographers, lawyers, reporters, and others. Students may contribute to the Student Gallery and post their dreams on a Wall of Dreams.

image.caption: Above and beyond
image.alttext: Above and Beyond the Call of Duty. Dorie Miller with his Navy Cross at Pearl Harbor, May 27, 1942. Color-offset poster. Prints and Photographs Division. Reproduction Number: LC-USZC4-2328 (8-10)

resource.title: History Firsthand: Primary Source Research in Elementary School
resource.description: is designed to help elementary students understand primary sources. Students learn how archival collections are organized, how to interpret artifacts and documents, how to use primary sources to tell a story, and how to do online research.

image.caption: Edna Wallace Hopper
image.alttext: [Edna Wallace Hopper, seated, full-length portrait with foot on stool]. c1905. Clark, Frank S., photographer, copyright claimant.

resource.title: Photojournalism: A Record of War
resource.description: explores how and why war has been photographed and affords students an opportunity to see bias within war reporting. In addition to analyzing war photographs, students learn about Mathew Brady's process for photographing the Civil War and how photographic equipment has improved over time.

resource.title: Reservation Controversies: Then and Now
resource.description: is built around two scenarios that help students understand issues related to American Indian reservations. Under one scenario, set in 1973, the student plays the role of agent for a Comanche Indian reservation. Under a contemporary scenario, the student is cast as a new congressional intern who has received a letter from the his congresswoman asking for help on issues related to casinos on reservations.

resource.title: Doing the Decades, 1890-1941: Group Investigations in Twentieth Century U.S. History
resource.description: is a two-month team research project for 9-10th graders that uses Library of Congress resources to focus on long-term change in U.S. history. Students gather, analyze, and evaluate primary and secondary sources; develop their own conclusions; and refine their writing.

resource.title: When Work is Done
resource.description: is a lesson plan that uses photographs as primary sources and that can help students develop historical analysis skills. After completing the introductory lesson using photographs as primary sources, students compile their own albums based on a thesis statement about life in the 20th century.

resource.title: Brother, Can You Spare a Dime: The Effects of the New Deal and the Great Depression
resource.description: examines primary sources -- from photographs to oral histories recorded by the famous Federal Writer's Project -- to develop a sense of the profound impact the Great Depression had on people's lives.

resource.title: Child Labor in America
resource.description: is a teaching unit that leads middle and high school students through the process of critically examining photographs (by Lewis Hine) as historical evidence.

resource.title: Immigration/Migration: Today and During the Great Depression
resource.description: is a 4-week American history unit for high school. Students conduct oral history interviews, analyze photos, evaluate the relevance and accuracy of primary and secondary sources, discuss changes in immigration and migration over time, and more.

image.caption: On road with tire trouble?
image.alttext: Migrants, family of Mexicans, on road with tire trouble. Looking for work in the peas. California.

resource.title: To Kill a Mockingbird
resource.description: is a lesson plan for teachers that uses primary source materials on the Depression and Southern and African American experiences. The unit emphasizes language arts and offers activities including an analysis of oral histories from Alabama collected between 1936 and 1940, parallel primary source readings on mob behavior and lynching, and visual literacy activity with photographs of Alabama during the Great Depression. The website features more enrichment activities and related readings.

image.caption: Drinking fountain
image.alttext: Drinking fountain on the county courthouse lawn, Halifax, North Carolina. Vachon, John, 1914-1975, photographer.

resource.title: Enhancing a Poetry Unit
resource.description: is a teaching unit that leads students to the famous Federal Writers Project and gets them started writing "found poems." Among the examples is a free verse poem written after reading an account of surviving the Blizzard of 1888.

resource.title: Jackie Steals Home
resource.description: involves high school students in analyzing primary documents related to Jackie Robinson's breaking the color line (when he stepped onto Ebbets field on April 15, 1947) to help them understand racial barriers not only in baseball and other sports, but in society.

image.caption: Jackie Robinson comic book
image.alttext: Half-length portrait of Jackie Robinson in Brooklyn Dodgers uniform, posed, holding baseball bat.

resource.title: Stand Up And Sing: Music And Our Reform History
resource.description: is a lesson in which students (Grades 7-12) analyze lyrics and images of popular sheet music as part of their studies of the political, social, and economic conditions existing during industrialization and reform in the U.S.

image.caption: Can you tame wild wimmen
image.alttext: Can you tame wild wimmen. 1918. Von Tilzer, Harry, 1872-1946. New York, New York, Harry Von Tilzer, 1918

resource.title: Women, Their Rights and Nothing Less
resource.description: is a lesson that uses primary documents to help students (Grades 9-12) learn about the women's suffrage movement that began in the 1840s and led to women?s right to vote nationwide in 1920.

resource.title: American Leaders Speak: Recordings from World War I and the 1920 Election, 1918-1920
resource.description: consists of 59 sound recordings of speeches by American leaders at the turn of the century. Speakers include Warren G. Harding, James Cox, Calvin Coolidge, Franklin D. Roosevelt, Samuel Gompers, Henry Cabot Lodge, and John J. Pershing.

image.caption: Franklin Delano Roosevelt, c1920
image.alttext: Franklin Delano Roosevelt, head-and-shoulders portrait, facing slightly left. Photographer unknown, c1920.

resource.title: Origins of American Animation
resource.description: offers 21 animated films and 2 fragments, which span the years 1900 to 1921. The films include clay, puppet, and cut-out animation, as well as pen drawings. They point to a connection between newspaper comic strips and early animated films, as represented by Keeping Up With the Joneses, Krazy Kat, and The Katzenjammer Kids.

image.caption: Keeping Up with the Joneses
image.alttext: [Men?s Styles] from Keeping Up with the Joneses (1915, Gaumont). Animator: Harry S. Palmer.

resource.title: By Popular Demand: Portraits of the Presidents and First Ladies
resource.description: is an online illustrated reference aid displaying 156 portraits depicting every American president and most first ladies.

image.caption: Timeline
image.alttext: Photo of Theodore Roosevelt

resource.title: Omaha Indian Music
resource.description: offers a sampling of traditional Omaha Indian music. The sound recordings include wax cylinder recordings made in the 1890s, as well as songs and spoken-word segments from the 1983 Omaha harvest celebration pow-wow, segments from an interview with an Omaha elder in 1983, songs and speeches from a performance by members of the Hethu'shka Society in 1985, and portions of an interview with an Omaha musician in 1999. Photos, fieldnotes, and more from the 1983 pow-wow are included.

image.caption: Hethu'shka dancer
image.alttext: Pictured is Charles Lonewolf. Hethu'shka Society concert. Neptune Plaza, Library of Congress, Washington DC. Photographer: Gibbs, John, taken 1985/08/22

resource.title: I Do Solemnly Swear... Presidential Inaugurations
resource.description: is a collection of about 400 items from each of the 62 inaugurations, from George Washington's in 1789 to Bill Clinton's in 1997. It will include items from the 63rd inauguration of 2001. This presentation includes diaries and letters of Presidents and of those who witnessed inaugurations, handwritten drafts of inaugural addresses, broadsides, inaugural tickets and programs, prints, photographs, and sheet music.

image.caption: Reagan?January 20, 1981
image.alttext: The Reagans waving during the Inaugural Parade, January 20, 1981.

interestingfact.text: In accordance with Article II, Section I of the U.S. Constitution, each President recites the oath of office.

resource.title: Panoramic Maps, 1847-1929
resource.description: is a digitalized collection of this once popular cartographic form used to depict U.S. and Canadian cities and towns during the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Known also as bird's-eye views, perspective maps, and aero views, panoramic maps are non-photographic representations of cities portrayed as if viewed from above at an oblique angle. Although not generally drawn to scale, they show street patterns, individual buildings, and major landscape features in perspective.

image.caption: Alexandria, Va.
image.alttext: Birds eye view of Alexandria, Va. Magnus, Charles. New York ; Washington, D.C. : Chas. Magnus, [1863]

resource.title: Taking the Long View: Panoramic Photographs, ca. 1851-1991
resource.description: presents 4000 images of American cityscapes, landscapes, and group portraits.

image.caption: Flood in Delaware, Ohio
image.alttext: Delaware, Ohio flood, March 29th, 1913. Fuller & Harmount, gelatin silver print; 6.5 x 43.5 in., PAN US GEOG - Ohio, no. 31 (E size) P&P

resource.title: Puerto Rico at the Dawn of the Modern Age, 1831-1929
resource.description: portrays the early history of the commonwealth of Puerto Rico through first-person accounts, political writings, and histories drawn from the Library of Congress's general collections. Among the topics it highlights are the land and its resources, relations with Spain, competition among political parties, reform efforts, and recollections by veterans of the Spanish-American War.

image.caption: The rebellion of 1868
image.alttext: Map of the island of Porto Rico. Geography and Map Division, Library of Congress.

resource.title: Quilts and Quiltmaking in America, 1978-1996
resource.description: showcases materials from two American Folklife Centercollections, the Blue Ridge Parkway Folklife Project Collection (1978) and the "All-American Quilt Contest" sponsored by Coming Home, a division of Lands' End, and Good Housekeeping. Together, these collections provide a glimpse into America's diverse quilting traditions. Photographs and recorded interviews with quiltmakers are also available.

image.caption: Quiltmaker
image.alttext: Quiltmaker: Cruise, Crystal. Photographer: Johnson, Geraldine N. September 6, 1978

resource.title: An American Time Capsule: Three Centuries of Broadsides and Other Printed Ephemera
resource.description: comprises 28,000 primary source items dating from the seventeenth century to the present and encompasses key events and eras in American history. Items include a variety of posters, notices, advertisements, proclamations, leaflets, propaganda, manifestos, and business cards. They capture the experience of the American Revolution, slavery, the western land rush, the Civil War, woman suffrage, and the Industrial Revolution from the viewpoint of those who lived through those events.

image.caption: An exhibition of American design
image.alttext: An exhibition of American design. Chicago, Lakeside press. [1947]. Lakeside Press Galleries. Chicago, 1947. Colored illustrations and text.

resource.title: Early Virginia Religious Petitions
resource.description: presents images of 423 petitions submitted to the Virginia legislature between 1774 and 1802. The petitions concern such topics as the historic debate over the separation of church and state, the rights of dissenters such as Quakers and Baptists, the sale and division of property in the established church, and the dissolution of unpopular vestries.

image.caption: The liberty window
image.alttext: The Prayer in the First Congress, A.D. 1774. Stained glass and lead, from The Liberty Window, Christ Church, Philadelphia, after a painting by Harrison Tompkins Matteson, c. 1848

resource.title: Hispano Music and Culture of the Northern Rio Grande
resource.description: is an online presentation of a multi-format ethnographic field collection documenting religious and secular music of Spanish-speaking residents of rural Northern New Mexico and Southern Colorado. The collection consists of approximately 8 hours of audio recordings (146 titles on 36 recording discs), 1 graphic image, and 218 pages of print material including administrative correspondence, recording logs, song text transcriptions, and publications.

image.caption: Juan B. Rael
image.alttext: Juan B. Rael interviewing Manuela 'Mela' Martínez, Taos, New Mexico, circa 1930. Courtesy of the Rael Family.

resource.title: The Spanish-American War in Motion Pictures
resource.description: features films and actualities taped in the U.S., Cuba, and Philippines showing troops, ships, notable figures, and parades, as well as reenactments of battles and other wartime events. These films mark the first U.S. war in which the motion picture camera played a role.

image.caption: Remember the Maine
image.alttext: U.S.S. Maine. c1897. Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Detroit Publishing Company Photograph Collection. Reproduction Number: LC-D41-121.

resource.title: We'll Sing to Abe Our Song!: Sheet Music about Lincoln, Emancipation, and the Civil War
resource.description: includes more than 200 sheet-music compositions about Abraham Lincoln and the war. This collection spans the years from Lincoln's presidential campaign in 1859 through the centenary of Lincoln's birth in 1909. It was compiled by Alfred Stern (1881-1960), the greatest private collector of materials relating to the life and times of Abraham Lincoln.

image.caption: The good old Union wagon
image.alttext: The good old Union wagon : corrected from the original song, called The secession wagon / by S. Matthews. Matthews, S. Cincinnati : A.C. Peters & bro., c1863.

resource.title: Music for the Nation: American Sheet Music, 1870-1885
resource.description: consists of tens of thousands of pieces of sheet music registered for copyright during the post-Civil War era. Included are popular songs, piano music, sacred music and secular choral music, solo instrumental music, method books and instructional materials, and music for band and orchestra. This first release of the online collection consists of over 22,000 musical compositions registered for copyright during the years 1870 to 1879.

image.caption: 'Oh, dem golden slippers,' by James A. Bland. Linda Gill, soloist.
image.alttext: 'Oh, dem golden slippers,' by James A. Bland. Linda Gill, soloist.

resource.title: Born in Slavery: Slave Narratives from the Federal Writers' Project, 1936-1938
resource.description: offers 2,300 first-person accounts of slavery and 500 photos of former slaves. The collection can be searched by name, city, state, topic, or other key words. These narratives were collected in the 1930s as part of the Works Progress Administration (WPA).

image.caption: Bill and Ellen Thomas
image.alttext: Photographic print of Bill and Ellen Thomas, ages 88 and 81, created between 1936 and 1938, Library of Congress Manuscript Division Washington, D.C. 20540 USA.

interestingfact.text: The late 1920s and 1930s witnessed a revival of interest in slave narratives. During this period several independent projects to secure ex-slave testimonies were undertaken. What most clearly distinguished these from earlier efforts was their sociological character. The single-minded moralism that had pervaded earlier narratives diminished substantially.

resource.title: Washington As It Was: Photographs by Theodor Horydczak, 1923-1959
resource.description: gathers 14,000 photographs of the architectural and social life of the Washington, D.C., metropolitan area in the 1920s, 1930s, and 1940s, including exteriors and interiors of commercial, residential, and government buildings, as well as street scenes and views of neighborhoods.

image.caption: U.S. Capitol
image.alttext: Close-up of U.S. Capitol with stairs at night II. LC-H8-CT-C01-087

resource.title: Theodore Roosevelt: His Life and Times on Film
resource.description: features 104 short films which record events in Roosevelt's life from the Spanish-American War in 1898 to his death in 1919. In addition to scenes of Roosevelt, these films include views of world figures, politicians, monarchs, and friends and family members.

image.caption: Scenes of TR
image.alttext: Scenes of TR and his sons Quentin and Archie, 1917-1918 [2] / [production company unknown].

resource.title: Pioneering the Upper Midwest: Books from Michigan, Minnesota, and Wisconsin, 1820-1910
resource.description: portrays the states of Michigan, Minnesota and Wisconsin from the 17th to the early 20th century through first-person accounts, biographies, promotional literature, local histories, ethnographic and antiquarian texts, and colonial archival documents. This collection depicts the land and its resources, the experience of Natives, pioneers and missionaries, soldiers and reformers, as well as the growth of local communities and cultures.

image.caption: Chief Little Crow
image.alttext: 'Chief Little Crow,' With pen and pencil on the frontier in 1851; the diary and sketches of Frank Blackwell Mayer, by Francis Blackwell Mayer (Saint Paul, 1932).

resource.title: By Popular Demand: Votes for Women Suffrage Pictures, 1850-1920
resource.description: offers photos of suffrage parades and pickets, cartoons commenting on the movement, and portraits of Sojourner Truth, Elizabeth Cady Stanton, Susan B. Anthony, and others.

image.caption: National Anti-Suffrage Association
image.alttext: Men looking in the window of the National Anti-Suffrage Association headquarters. [1911(?)]

resource.title: The American Variety Stage: Vaudeville and Popular Entertainment, 1870-1920
resource.description: is a multimedia anthology illustrating the vibrant and diverse forms of popular entertainment, especially vaudeville, that thrived from 1870-1920. Included are 334 English- and Yiddish-language playscripts, 146 theater playbills and programs, 61 motion pictures, 10 sound recordings and 143 photographs and 29 memorabilia items documenting the life and career of Harry Houdini.

image.caption: Harry Houdini
image.alttext: Harry Houdini, full-length portrait, standing, facing front, in chains, ca. 1899

resource.title: Creative Americans: Portraits by Carl Van Vechten, 1932-1964
resource.description: displays 1,395 photographs by Van Vechten, primarily studio portraits of people involved in the arts, including musicians, dancers, artists, literati, theatrical, film, and television actors and actresses.

image.caption: Tallulah Bankhead
image.alttext: [Portrait of Tallulah Bankhead]. Van Vechten, Carl, 1880-1964, photographer. 1934 Jan. 25.

resource.title: William P. Gottlieb: Photographs from the Golden Age of Jazz
resource.description: includes 2,000 digital images taken by writer-photographer William P. Gottlieb. From 1938 to 1948, the "Golden Age of Jazz," swing reached its peak and modern jazz developed. While on assignment for the Washington Post, Down Beat magazine, and Record Changer, Gottlieb photographed and interviewed jazz pioneers primarily in Washington, D.C., and New York City.

image.caption: Billie Holiday
image.alttext: Portrait of Billie Holiday, Downbeat, New York, N.Y., ca. Feb. 1947

interestingfact.text: When the elusive Thelonious Monk disappeared from the jazz scene in 1947, Gottlieb embarked on a mission to track down the jazz giant. With the help of Mary Lou Williams, Gottlieb located Monk and took him to Minton's Playhouse where he had once worked as house pianist.

resource.title: American Life Histories: Manuscripts from the Federal Writers' Project, 1936-1940
resource.description: presents 2,900 life histories from 300 writers from 24 states. These histories describe individuals' families, incomes, occupations, political views, religions, diets, and observations.

image.caption: Lunch time
image.alttext: Bethlehem-Fairfield shipyards, Baltimore, Maryland. Lunch time. Siegel, Arthur S., photographer. 1943 May.

resource.title: By the People, For the People: Posters from the WPA, 1936-1943
resource.description: is a collection of 900 boldly colored and graphically diverse posters produced as part of FDR's New Deal. These striking silkscreens, lithographs, and woodcuts were created to publicize health and safety programs; cultural programs including art exhibitions, theatrical, and musical performances; travel and tourism; educational programs; and community activities.

image.caption: Read the books you've meant to read
image.alttext: In March read the books you've always meant to read. [between 1936 and 1941]. Library of Congress Prints and Photographs Division. Reproduction Number: LC-USZC2-5175.

resource.title: Around the World in the 1890s: Photographs from the World's Transportation Commission, 1894-1896
resource.description: makes available for viewing the nearly nine hundred images of modes of transportation taken by American photographer William Henry Jackson in North Africa, Asia, Australia, and Oceania. The site allows searches by subject and Keyword, and gives archival information about it.

image.caption: Tangier
image.alttext: Tangier - one of the gates. Jackson, William Henry, 1843-1942, photographer.

resource.title: Poet At Work: Recovered Notebooks from Walt Whitman
resource.description: features four Walt Whitman notebooks that disappeared from the Library of Congress in 1942 and that were subsequently returned in 1995. Images of the notebooks are available, as are articles on their recovery and conservation.

image.caption: Cardboard butterfly
image.alttext: LC #220 Whitman's Cardboard Butterfly: Bottom of Butterfly

resource.title: The Digital Classroom
resource.description: encourages teachers of students at all levels to use archival documents and to teach with primary source materials from the National Archives. The site offers discussions on how primary documents give form to history, instructions on building a school archive, and templates for document analysis worksheets.

image.caption: Vietnamese refugees
image.alttext: 'South China Sea . . . Crewmen of the amphibious cargo ship U.S.S. Durham (LKA-114) take Vietnamese refugees aboard from a small craft. The refugees will be transferred later by mechanized landing cr

resource.title: Documenting the American South
resource.description: is a full-text database of primary resources on Southern history, literature, and culture from the colonial period through the first decades of the 20th century. Currently, this database, sponsored by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, includes 3 digitization projects: slave narratives, first-person narratives, and Southern literature.

image.caption: Read yourself -- this once
image.alttext: Frontispiece page from 'The Deliverance: A Romance of the Virginia Tobacco Fields.' New York: Doubleday, Page, & Co., 1904.

resource.title: Oral Language Archive
resource.description: is a growing collection of recordings of native speakers. The website features samples of various languages and a CD with the existing archive can be ordered.

resource.title: NCES Classroom
resource.description: invites students to create their own graphs, solve a math teaser, play a probability game, or take an online quiz in math or science. Students can find tuition, degree, and program information for colleges and universities across the U.S. or look up statistics about their own elementary or secondary school, or the local library.

image.caption: Word search
image.alttext: Image of a word search

resource.title: New Deal Network, Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute
resource.description: provides research and teaching resources devoted to the public works and arts projects of the New Deal, including information on how the Great Depression affected children, and workers programs for women that made dolls to be sold for children in nurseries, schools, and hospitals.

image.caption: The Magpie sings the Depression
image.alttext: A stroll down Broadway, by John Baldwin for the January 1940 issue

resource.title: Teacher and Student Resources at the National Museum of American Art
resource.description: offers the "Pueblo Indian Watercolors" teachers guide on interpreting the meaning of artistic images, an interactive guide on one of America's most powerful African-American painters, William H. Johnson, plus other guides and student activity packets.

image.caption: Life is a Dream, Then You Wake Up
image.alttext: 'Life is a Dream, Then You Wake Up.' Enrique Chagoya, 1995. color monotype on handmade Amate bark paper, 108.2 x 118.4 cm, (42 5/8 x 46 5/8 in.), Smithsonian American Art Museum

resource.title: Department of Anthropology
resource.description: offers guidebooks and source directories on many topics in anthropology, with special concentrations on archeology and Native Americans. The site also contains directories of organizations and periodicals dealing with anthropology. There are links to further material on the Smithsonian's work and exhibitions in this area.

image.caption: Alaska Native collections
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: NASA Oceanography
resource.description: provides online field trips, information about ocean phenomena (such as phytoplankton, carbon, and reefs), remote sensing tools for monitoring ocean changes, and more. This website is based on NASA research and satellite missions focused on global ocean science.

image.caption: Pacific Ocean winds
image.alttext: he SeaWinds scatterometer aboard NASA's QuikSCAT satellite collected the data used to create this multicolored image of winds on the surface of the Pacific Ocean. This image taken on Jan. 8, 2004, sh

resource.title: Oyez. Oyez. Oyez.: Supreme Court Resource
resource.description: features abstracts and other materials on Constitutional law cases decided by the United States Supreme Court. Visitors can learn about the Court, search case law, listen to recordings of the Court in session, and order recordings of Constitutional law arguments and decisions.

image.caption: Justices
image.alttext: A image of the list of names of current Supreme Court justices

resource.title: The Particle Adventure
resource.description: introduces, through an interactive adventure tour, the theory of fundamental particles and forces. It also looks at why physicists want to go beyond the Standard Model theory. In addition, the site offers a discussion board.

image.caption: Chart of fundamental particles
image.alttext: Chart summarizes the world of particles (including quarks, gluons, and neutrinos) and the fundamental forces.

resource.title: Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy
resource.description: is a collection of hundreds of articles on philosophy, many of which are available at the site, that are continually updated by the authors. The articles contain bibliographies, links to related articles in the Encyclopedia and other Internet resources.

image.caption: The Commedia (The Divine Comedy)
image.alttext: Discussion about Dante Alighieri's 'Commedia (The Divine Comedy)'

resource.title: Hands-on Experiments To Test for Acid Mine Drainage
resource.description: invites students to learn about the effects of acid mine drainage on our groundwater and environment through experimentation and observation. The website explains how to make litmus paper, study aquatic organisms, bacteria and algae, examine the weatherization process, and more.

image.caption: Collection techniques
image.alttext: If you get really curious to learn more about the bacteria making these natural colors in the water, there are simple ways to collect them in the field and study them at home or in a lab.

resource.title: This Dynamic Earth: The Story of Plate Tectonics
resource.description: is an online book that introduces the theory of plate tectonics. It includes topics such as understanding plate motions, historical perspective, and more.

image.caption: Hot spot
image.alttext: The Pacific Plate over the fixed Hawaiian 'Hot Spot,' illustrating the formation of the Hawaiian Ridge-Emperor Seamount Chain.

resource.title: NASA Quest
resource.description: is dedicated to bringing space science and NASA people to the classroom. Students learn about NASA's space and aerospace teams, the solar system, and the physical processes of celestial objects, including energy, matter, and gravity. The site also offers lesson plans, web chats and forums, and questions and answers for teachers.

image.caption: Lunar CRater Observation and sensing satellite
image.alttext: The Mission Objectives of the Lunar Crater Observation and Sensing Satellite (LCROSS) are to advance the Vision for Space Exploration (VSE) by confirming the presence or absence of water ice in a perm

resource.title: Aerospace
resource.description: features NASA employees doing aerodynamic design research. Watch and listen as engineers, technicians, mechanics, and designers work to make planes safer, more efficient, quieter, and faster. Photos, career profiles, a chat room, and more complement an archive of frequently asked questions.

image.caption: Experimental planes
image.alttext: X-29 Smoke test

resource.title: Female Frontiers
resource.description: profiles women of NASA who achieved a variety of "women's firsts" -- the first woman programmer, the first woman shuttle commander, the first woman in space, and more. Web chat archives feature conversations with more than a dozen pioneering women.

image.caption: Sally Ride
image.alttext: Photo of Sally Ride, First American Woman in Space.

interestingfact.text: Libby Riddles is a champion sled dog racer who was the first woman to win the Iditerod, the gruelling, thousand-mile dog sled race across Alaska. Her business card reads, Musher, Author, Speaker.

resource.title: NY High School Regents Exam Prep Center
resource.description: helps high school students meet the New York State Regents requirements in mathematics, science, and social studies. The site, developed by a team of Oswego County (NY) teachers, provides practice exams, study strategies, and teacher resources in six areas: U.S. history and government, global history, math, earth science, biology, and chemistry.

image.caption: Mathematics
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Prince William Sound: An Ecosystem in Transition
resource.description: spotlights the ecological issues surrounding the historic 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill and the subsequent recovery operation.

image.caption: Resiliency of the Sound
image.alttext: This photo, taken in 1989, shows shoreline oiling at a "setaside site" in Herring Bay, which was oiled but not cleaned.

resource.title: Ocean and Coastal Response and Restoration
resource.description: allows students to learn about oil spills and hazardous chemical accidents through experiments that can be done at home, in the classroom, or for a science project.

image.caption: The Jupiter
image.alttext: The JUPITER was offloading gasoline at Bay City, Michigan on September 16, 1990, when a fire started on board the vessel.

resource.title: The Office of Science Education
resource.description: features free educational materials and outreach programs at the NIH, a video and slide program of speakers discussing Hollywood movies that have a medical science theme, original stories about medical research in the news, profiles of people in a variety of science-related careers, and articles that explain how various achievements in science happened.

image.caption: Careers in science posters
image.alttext: Picture of Women in Heart Disease Research poster

resource.title: Science@NASA
resource.description: features the latest news in science. Recent topics include skiing on the moon, lightning in hurricanes, something strange about moon shadows, the growing brightness of Venus, moon dust, space radiation's affect on computers, a lunar lawn mower, fireball sightings, and the shape of space-time around Earth.

image.caption: Explosion on the moon
image.alttext: Explosion on the Moon: An artist's concept of the Nov. 7, 2005, explosion. Credit: NASA/MSFC.

interestingfact.text: Hurricanes notoriously lack lightning. Surprisingly though, during the record-setting hurricane season of 2005, three of the most powerful storms -- Rita, Katrina, and Emily -- had lots of lightning. Researchers would like to know why.

resource.title: Ocean Planet
resource.description: features a Smithsonian exhibit on the world's oceans. Visitors can see an overview of the exhibition, find lessons and marine science activities, and read a final report documenting the educational impact of the undertaking.

image.caption: Coral reefs in decline
image.alttext: Coral reefs are in severe decline wherever they are in contact with growing human populations.

resource.title: SeaWiFS Project (Sea-viewing Wide Field-of-view Sensor)
resource.description: provides data on global ocean bio-optical properties for the Earth science community. Resources for teachers include a tutorial on ocean color and slides suggesting how SeaWiFS data can be incorporated into the curriculum for grades 5-12.

image.caption: SeaStar in orbit
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: The Show-Me Center
resource.description: provides information and resources needed to support selection and implementation of middle grades mathematics curricula using standards recommended by the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics. The site features five projects that focus on problem solving, data analysis, geometry, and algebra. Each project offers sample lesson plans.

resource.title: SOHO: The Solar and Heliospheric Observatory
resource.description: features an uninterrupted view of the sun. Learn about some of the sun's most perplexing riddles: the origin of the solar wind, the sun's extensive outer atmosphere, and the stream of highly ionized gas that blows continuously outward throughout our solar system. Find lesson plans, never-before-seen photos of the sun, and answers to common questions.

image.caption: Uninterrupted view of the sun
image.alttext: Composite image of 10 years worth of images from SOHO

interestingfact.text: The sun can be divided into six layers. From the center out, those layers are: the solar interior composed of the core, the radiative zone, the convective zone, the visible surface known as the photosphere, the chromosphere, and finally the outermost layer, the corona.

resource.title: The Space Place
resource.description: is a place where kids can learn how to make balloon-powered nano-rovers and pop rockets, discover what it's like to be a space engineer, and conduct experiments to identify the best materials for use in space. The site includes space facts and crossword puzzles, riddles, an Intergalactic Adventures board game that explores a black hole, and other fun activities.

image.caption: Astronauts
image.alttext: Michael Gernhardt is standing on a Manipulator Foot Restraint attached to the Space Shuttle Endeavour during a space walk.

resource.title: StarChild: A Learning Center for Young Astronomers
resource.description: helps elementary school students learn about the sun and moon, planets, the asteroid belt, meteoroids and comets, astronauts and space suits, space travel and space probes, the Hubble space telescope, the Columbia accident, galaxies, the Milky Way, stars, quasars, black holes, cosmology, and dark matter.

image.caption: Black holes
image.alttext: Black holes were once massive stars that used up all their fuel. As they died out, they collapsed inward due to the pull of their own gravity.

resource.title: BLS Career Information
resource.description: is a place where kids can find information on job opportunities related to the arts, math, science, physical education and outdoors, reading, and social studies. The site also offers resources for teachers, including a links to the Bureau of Labor Statistics Occupational Outlook Handbook.

image.caption: What do you like?
image.alttext: Image of teens

resource.title: Mapping Margery Kempe
resource.description: is a digital library of resources for studying the 15th century cultural and societal context of The Book of Margery Kempe.

image.caption: Iconoclasm
image.alttext: England's Christian history dates back to missionary zeal from both from Irish and Roman sources - Patrick's successors colonizing the north and Augustine reaching Kent.

resource.title: The American Heritage Project
resource.description: is a "virtual archive" prototype being developed by four universities so that researchers and the public can retrieve collections of primary source material.

image.caption: Fire guts four buildings
image.alttext: Fire guts 4 buildings - north side Main Street looking west from Church Street. 3 other buildings damaged. Friday, April 18, 1969. ("Photo by Tony Rumple, Durham, N.C.") Photographs from the Wyatt T.

resource.title: California Heritage Digital Access Project
resource.description: presents more than 28,000 images illustrating California's history and culture. The California Heritage Collection is part of the Online Archive of California, a compilation of guides to archival collections at more than 30 institutions. It includes information about the images, suggestions for their use in K-12 curriculum, and frequently asked questions.

image.caption: Cable car
image.alttext: Cable Car, S.F. LNG56110.8 Contributor: Dorothea Lange Date: 1956 Contributing Institution: Oakland Museum of California

resource.title: SimCalc
resource.description: uses advanced simulation technology to help elementary students learn the concepts of "mathematics of change": problems involving rates, accumulation, approximations, and limits that appear in everyday situations involving money, motion, and varying quantities.

image.caption: Classroom-lab scenario
image.alttext: Graphical Guess My Rule Ms. Kean, a 4th year teacher puts a target linear function graph, whose Y=mX+b formula is hidden, on her computer's classroom display.

resource.title: Teachers Experiencing Antarctic and the Arctic
resource.description: explores the lives and activities of teachers who were selected to travel to the Antarctic and the Arctic to participate in ongoing research projects.

image.caption: Pangaea puzzle
image.alttext: Cutaway view of ice sheet,? exploring the tectonic forces that shape the earth

resource.title: Thomas: Legislative Information
resource.description: is a searchable database of summary versions of legislation, the status of congressional bills, the text and digest of the Congressional Record, committee information, hearings schedules, related calendars, information about how laws are made and enacted, historical documents, frequently asked questions, and more.

image.caption: Original rough draft of Declaration
image.alttext: Thomas Jefferson (1743-1826), 'Original Rough Draught of the Declaration of Independence.' Holograph with minor emendations by John Adams and Benjamin Franklin, June 1776

resource.title: Ocean Surface Topography from Space-Education
resource.description: offers activities for learning about oceans, oceanography, earth science, and related topics. This is the education website of a partnership between the U.S. and France to monitor global ocean circulation, discover ties between the oceans and atmosphere, and improve global climate predictions.

resource.title: Volcano World
resource.description: is a source for information about volcanoes. This site offers links organized by region, country/area, volcano name, and descriptions.

resource.title: Ask-a-Geologist
resource.description: invites students to email government earth scientists with questions about volcanoes, earthquakes, mountains, rocks, maps, ground water, lakes, or rivers.

resource.title: Water Resources of the United States
resource.description: presents real-time and historical water data from across the country, as well as technical information and details about water quality and water research programs. The site links to local resources and up-to-date information on current flood conditions and water levels throughout the country.

image.caption: The breakwater at Capitola
image.alttext: Waves topping the breakwater at Capitola and battering Venetian Courts. (courtesy of Sandy Lydon.)

resource.title: Water Resources Education Resources
resource.description: is a collection of classroom activities that teach students about the properties of water. There is an interactive center where students can give opinions and test their water knowledge, "FrogWeb," which focuses on amphibian declines and deformities, free education posters on wetlands and water use, and more.

image.caption: What's your watershed?
image.alttext: Image that shows the various watershed across the U.S.

resource.title: Cultura
resource.description: lets students in the U.S. communicate with students from France. It offers learners (and teachers alike) on both sides of the Atlantic a unique comparative, cross-cultural approach for gradually constructing knowledge of other values, attitudes and beliefs, in an ever-enlarging construction of the foreign culture.

image.caption: Cultura logo
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: The Why Files
resource.description: feature the latest news in science, math and technology. Learn how infrared "vision" works, the science behind cloning, or the statistical calculations that make political polling possible. Visitors can also join the site's online forum to participate in various science related discussions such as why the night sky is dark, interstellar distances, Einstein's influence, and much more.

image.caption: Sarcastic study
image.alttext: Brain with front region highlighted and arrows pointing.

interestingfact.text: Small is beautiful. But very small -- quantum small -- is weird. Even Einstein thought so. The laws governing teeny particles, he said, are so bizarre they couldn't possibly be a complete explanation of reality.

resource.title: Women and Social Movements in the United States, 1600-2000
resource.description: introduces students to primary documents related to women and social movements in the U.S. between 1830 and 1930, including letters and newspapers articles on the role of African American women in the passage of the woman suffrage amendment.

image.caption: Contemporary women and social movements
image.alttext: WomenWatch is the United Nations internet gateway to information and resources on the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of women.

resource.title: Fermilab LInC
resource.description: presents a course with 20 four-hour sessions for teacher-leaders who commit to helping other educators integrate Internet resources into the curriculum. Materials are available on using the Internet to find information, publishing web (HTML) documents, creating graphics, exploring educational uses of the Internet, using the Internet to facilitate project-based "engaged" learning, and other topics. The site links to areas for students, educators, and other visitors.

resource.title: The Whole Frog Project
resource.description: introduces the concepts of modern, computer based 3D visualization and demonstrates the power of whole body, 3D imaging of anatomy as a curriculum tool. A frog can be seen with or without its skeleton, brain, kidneys, etc., as the user desires, in cross-section slices, or in a rotating movie.

image.caption: Dissection kit
image.alttext: You can interactively dissect a (digitized) frog named Fluffy, and play the Virtual Frog Builder Game. The interactive Web pages are available in a number of languages.

resource.title: The Exploration of the Earth's Magnetosphere
resource.description: looks at the hot (but usually rarefied) gases which fill most of space, which are ruled by magnetic and electric forces rather than by gravity. The site discusses such phenomena as the polar aurora, the radiation belts, the solar wind, magnetic storms, "space weather", and cosmic radiation. It includes a quick overview of the relevant physical sciences, such as magnetism, ions and electrons, plasmas, and includes bits of science history.

image.caption: A GOES Satellite
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: From Stargazers to Starships
resource.description: is a self-contained book-on-the-web course on basic astronomy, Newtonian mechanics, the sun (and associated physics), and spaceflight and spacecraft.

image.caption: The evolution of rockets
image.alttext: Hermann Oberth, a transplanted Romanian, vigorously promoted the idea of spaceflight.

resource.title: America's Library
resource.description: unlocks stories from America's past. Discover what Abraham Lincoln had in his pockets on the night he was assassinated, or jump back into the past to find more about the settlers who landed on Plymouth Rock. Or learn how the oud, the zurna, and the marimba influenced today's modern musical instruments.

image.caption: Coca-Cola
image.alttext: A Coca-Cola sign hangs over a shop in Natchez, Mississippi. Wolcott, Marion Post. "Natchez, Miss." 1940. America from the Great Depression to World War II: Photographs from the FSA-OWI, 1935-1945, Li

resource.title: Jamestown Rediscovery Project
resource.description: presents the artifacts that have been discovered during excavations of 1607 Jamestown on Jamestown Island, Virginia. The website presents images and explanations of the artifacts found by archeologists, a list of related publications, information on exhibits at the project site, and project contacts.

publisher.name: Association for the Preservation of Virginia Antiquities

image.caption: Pocahontas
image.alttext: Photo of a Pocahontas statue.

interestingfact.text: In June of 1606, King James I granted a charter to the Virginia Company to establish a satellite English settlement in the Chesapeake region of North America. By December, 108 settlers sailed from London to Virginia. Some scholars believe they could not have been more ill-suited for the task.

resource.title: Center of Military History
resource.description: features information on U.S. Army history, including online publications, artwork and images, lineage series for different branches of the service, full text listings of medal of honor recipients, frequently asked questions, and links including the master list of Army records.

image.caption: Perimeter patrol
image.alttext: Perimeter patrol -- Vietnam (Michael R. Crook, 1967 -- posted the week of 16 Mar 98)

resource.title: ARS Science 4 Kids!
resource.description: is a series of stories about what scientists do at the Agricultural Research Service. It is geared to kids 8 to 13 years old.

resource.title: Freer and Sackler Galleries: Education Programs
resource.description: feature two online activities about Asian Art, curriculum materials that can be purchased through the Freer and Sackler Galleries museum shop, and other resources that can be retrieved directly from the site. It has information about tours and workshops for school groups, and ImaginAsia, the weekly hands-on workshop designed in conjunction with the exhibitions.

publisher.name: Freer Gallery of Art/Arthur M. Sackler Gallery

image.caption: Ancient Near Eastern art
