resource.title: Virtual Vacationland: Earth Science
resource.description: tours of Maine-related earth science education resources developed by the Bigelow Laboratory for Ocean Sciences. Topics include land topography, coastal tides, ocean temperature, weather and climate, and watersheds and rivers.

image.caption: Bathymetry
image.alttext: Ocean bottom topography is also known as bathymetry (measurement of the depth of of large bodies of water).

resource.title: NIST Time and Frequency Information
resource.description: provides information, tools, and services for timekeeping and frequency measurement. Visitors can download time-setting software for their computer, read about how time is synchronized at radio stations across the country, and monitor the performance of the Global Positioning System (GPS) satellites.

publisher.name: National Institute of Standards and Technology
publisher.agency: National Institute of Standards and Technology

resource.title: MegaMath
resource.description: presents important mathematical ideas and allows students and teachers to experience math in ways that it is experienced by mathematicians and scientists. Through fun activities and real world applications (tied to the NCTM standards), the project allows students to see what mathematicians actually do.

image.caption: Recursion
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: EXCITE (Teaching Epidemiology)
resource.description: is a collection of teaching materials for teaching students about public health and epidemiology. Materials focus on principles and practices of epidemiology, including the scientific method of inquiry, biostatistics, and outbreak investigation. Exercises allow students to use what they've learned to solve real outbreaks.

publisher.name: Centers For Disease Control and Prevention
publisher.agency: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

image.caption: Science olympiad
image.alttext: Test Tubes Icon

resource.title: Healthy Youth
resource.description: offers recommendations to help states, districts, and schools implement health programs and policies that promote healthy behaviors among youth. Recommendations cover topics including, policy development, curriculum development and selection, instructional strategies, staff training, family and community involvement, evaluation, and links between components of a coordinated school health program.

publisher.name: Centers For Disease Control and Prevention
publisher.agency: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

image.caption: Get healthy
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Physical Activity and Health, Adolescents and Young Adults
resource.description: outlines key messages and facts about the importance of physical activity for health promotion. The website offers tips for promoting healthy habits and includes information on building individual and community physical education initiatives.

publisher.name: Centers For Disease Control and Prevention
publisher.agency: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

image.caption: 19 percent
image.alttext: Only 19 percent of all high school students...

resource.title: Infectious Diseases
resource.description: offers fact sheets on diseases and selected prevention and program areas. It also provides information on emerging infectious diseases, travelers' health, and more.

publisher.name: Centers For Disease Control and Prevention
publisher.agency: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

image.caption: Trypanosomiasis, African
image.alttext: Life Cycle of Trypanosma brucei gambiense and Trypanosma brucei rhodesiense

resource.title: Are You a Working Teen?
resource.description: informs working teenagers about their rights and safety responsibilities on the job, hazards they should watch out for, and the laws that protect them from doing dangerous work. It provides additional information such as working hours for teens and a list of places to go if they need help.

publisher.name: Centers For Disease Control and Prevention
publisher.agency: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

resource.title: Tobacco Information and Prevention Source
resource.description: provides educational materials that help to prevent tobacco use among youth, promote smoking cessation, and protect nonsmokers from environmental tobacco smoke. Visitors can order publications, read reports, gather data, and follow suggested guides for quitting smoking.

publisher.name: Centers For Disease Control and Prevention
publisher.agency: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

resource.title: The Centennial of Flight -- The Future of Flight
resource.description: is dedicated to the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the Wright Brothers' first powered flight and the development of aviation over the past century. It offers aerospace-related products and programs that help connect students and teachers to aeronautics and space flight.

image.caption: Chuck Yeager and the X-1
image.alttext: Chuck Yeager and the X-1 research plane that broke the sound barrier. It can be seen today at the Smithsonian Air Space Museum in Washington, DC.

resource.title: Kidd Safety
resource.description: features a quiz about safety at home and outdoors. There is a poster about how to prevent injuries, information about eliminating hazards in the home, and bicycle safety tips.

resource.title: Journey Through Hallowed Ground: Travel through Virginia's Piedmont
resource.description: visits 65 historic places along 75 miles of Route 15 in Virginia's Piedmont. Stops include homes of Thomas Jefferson and James Monroe; sites of some of the bloodiest battles in the Civil War; and other places that evoke the soldiers, statesmen, farmers, and slaves who fought, toiled, and governed there.

image.caption: Gen. George C. Marshall House
image.alttext: Front view of Gen. George C. Marshall House. Photograph courtesy of Scenic America: Deborah L. Myerson

resource.title: Managing Archeological Collections
resource.description: is an online technical assistance and distance learning effort covering all aspects of "curation" -- caring for archeological collections such as objects, records, reports, and digital data -- wherever they may be (in the field, the archeologist's office, the lab, or a repository).

image.caption: American Museum of Natural History
image.alttext: American Museum of Natural History, New York, c.1902.Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs Division, Detroit Publishing Company Collection.

resource.title: Ancient Architects of the Mississippi
resource.description: identifies resources and recommends ways to protect, preserve, and interpret the natural, cultural, and recreational resources of the Lower Mississippi Delta region.

image.caption: Life along the river
image.alttext: Houses of thatch and mud plaster,? Illustration by Michael Hampshire. Use prohibited without permission.

resource.title: Public Archeology in the United States: A Timeline
resource.description: allows visitors to journey through time and see the development of public archaeology in the U.S. Along this timeline, which extends from 1784 to the current decade, visitors can see how public archeology has changed and discover the key events that shaped public archeology in this country.

image.caption: Excavations
image.alttext: Top view of Mound A excavations at Shiloh National Military Park. NPS Photo

resource.title: Our Shared History: African American Heritage
resource.description: tells about the Underground Railroad, African Americans in the Civil War, historic places of the civil rights movement, the Delta blues of the Lower Mississippi Valley, and landmarks dedicated to Booker T. Washington, Martin Luther King, and Frederick Douglass.

image.caption: Little Rock's Central High
image.alttext: On the morning of September 23, 1957 nine African-American teenagers stood up to an angry crowd protesting integration in front of Little Rock's Central High as they entered the school for the first

resource.title: Cultural Resource Management
resource.description: is an online magazine of the National Park Service. The site contains every issue, available in pdf format, from its beginnings as a quarterly 1978 to monthly plus supplements today. The articles are searchable by such categories as archaeology, technology, and ethnography.

image.caption: The red bus rides again
image.alttext: CRM issue Volume 25, No. 05, 'The Red Bus Rides Again!'

resource.title: A New Lease on Life
resource.description: explains how objects such as a letter written by Abe Lincoln and a dress worn by Lady Bird Johnson's are preserved to ensure safety while on exhibit in a museum. The site looks at steps taken by conservators to preserve objects, including examination, stabilization, research, and restoration.

resource.title: American Visionaries: Frederick Douglass
resource.description: features items owned by the famous abolitionist, human rights and women's rights activist, orator, author, journalist, publisher, and social reformer. The site consists of enlargeable images of items in the museum and archival collections at the Frederick Douglass National Historic Site at Cedar Hill, Southeast Washington, DC.

image.caption: A.M.E. Metropolitan Church
image.alttext: African Methodist Episcopal [AME] Metropolitan Church at M Street between 15th & 16th Streets, N.W., Washington, D.C.

resource.title: Symbols in Battle: Civil War Flags in NPS Collections
resource.description: is a collection of historic battle flags that were carried by Southern and Northern military units during the Civil War. The site describes how these flags were designed to identify different regiments and their many purposes during wartime.

image.caption: Storm flag
image.alttext: After the garrison flag flying over Fort Sumter had ripped, soldiers raised this smaller storm flag in its place.

resource.title: American Visionaries: Thomas Moran
resource.description: features paintings and sketches of the noted American landscape painter. Moran's pencil and watercolor field sketches and paintings captured the grandeur and documented the extraordinary terrain and natural features of the Yellowstone region. His artwork was presented to members of Congress by park proponents and helped inspire Congress to establish the National Park System in 1916.

image.caption: Great Springs of the Firehole River
image.alttext: Thomas Moran, 'Great Springs of the Firehole River,' 1871. 20.6 x 28.3 cm (8 1/8 x 11 1/8 in). Yellowstone NP, YELL 8536

resource.title: Legends of Tuskegee
resource.description: links to three sites that look at the achievements and impact of Booker T. Washington, George Washington Carver, and the Tuskegee Airmen. In addition to general historical information, it includes snapshots of original documents and objects from the three museums and narratives that tie the three sites together.

image.caption: Robert Marshall Glass
image.alttext: Photo of Robert Marshall Glass. Captain, US Air Force. December 17, 1920-January 24, 1955

interestingfact.text: In 1936, Benjamin O. Davis, Jr. was the first African American to graduate from West Point Military Academy in 47 years. First assigned to Fort Benning, Georgia, Davis served as an aide to his father, Brigadier General Davis before transferring to the military science staff at Tuskegee Institute, Alabama.

resource.title: Camp Life: Civil War Collections from Gettysburg
resource.description: features photographs and text from three exhibits: living in a camp, existing day to day, and battling boredom.

image.caption: Seated soldiers
image.alttext: Seated Soldiers, October 3, 1863. Culpepper, Virginia. Captain Henry C. Newton, 93rd New York and an unidentified Union officer seated in front of a tent.

resource.title: Nile of the New World: Lower Mississippi River Valley
resource.description: features stories and resources to help students learn about the heritage of this diverse region. Stories form a picture of the Delta's natural, historic, and cultural resources, and specific subject areas offer more detailed information on the area's role during the Civil War, its plantations, timber industry, and more.

image.caption: McKinley Morganfield "Muddy Waters"
image.alttext: Born April 4, 1915, in Rolling Fork, Mississippi, to a sharecropping family, Morganfield moved to the Stovall Plantation near Clarksdale to live with his grandmother after the death of his mother in 1

resource.title: The Battle of Gettysburg, July 1-3, 1863
resource.description: presents elements of the battle and its aftermath, including objects used by the soldiers, a lesson plan on the men's experiences, a history of the preservation efforts at the battlefield, and a database about Civil War soldiers

image.caption: Camp life
image.alttext: Image of a battle tent

resource.title: The Golden Crescent, Crossroads of Florida and Georgia
resource.description: examines the cultural history of the Atlantic Coast from Savannah to Cape Canaveral and inland toward Tallahassee. Maps, texts, and pictures illustrate the area's transformations through its pre-history, colonization, induction into the U.S., reconstruction, struggle for civil rights, and the recent resort boom.

image.caption: Coastal defense
image.alttext: Coastal Georgia and Florida boast many examples of various types of maritime fortifications. The many isolated settlements of colonial North America produced numerous small forts and a handful of larg

resource.title: History: Ask a Question
resource.description: lets students correspond with government historians via email. Historians' names and addresses are listed by expertise with an emphasis towards those researching the national parks, the National Park Service, and American history.

resource.title: Discover: Presidential Log Cabins
resource.description: is a set of materials designed to help 6th to 8th grade students learn about the significance of three log cabin sites occupied by four of our nation's greatest leaders. Through these materials, students discover the rich history associated with these log structures.

resource.title: Celebrate Hispanic American Month
resource.description: highlights publications, properties listed in the National Register, and National Parks related to the creativity, culture, and political experiences of Hispanic Americans.

resource.title: Seattle: A National Register of Historic Places Travel Itinerary
resource.description: explores the city's history and shows how it continues to shape the city's life today. It uses residential, commercial, industrial, and religious locations to create a tour of 37 properties that documents how past and present come together.

resource.title: Baltimore: A National Register of Historic Places Travel Itinerary
resource.description: provides an online tour of residential, commercial, industrial, and religious locations spanning more than 2 centuries of history. Through maps, descriptions, and photographs of places both famous and little-known, the guide shows why residents and visitors have become so fond of Baltimore.

image.caption: B&O Roundhouse
image.alttext: Photos of Baltimore and Ohio Transportation Museum and Mount Clare Station. Photos by Theresa Page & Shannon Bell, National Register of Historic Places

interestingfact.text: The city of Baltimore was founded July 30, 1729.

resource.title: Central Vermont: Explore History in the Heart of the Green Mountains
resource.description: explores Central Vermont's history using 43 historic places that recall past eras when numerous small villages grew slowly until the coming of the railroad, which resulted in a period of rapid growth for Vermont in the last half of the 19th century.

resource.title: Historic Charleston's Religious and Community Buildings
resource.description: explores Charleston's heritage by examining 42 historic places. More than 300 years of history are covered, including the Walled City of the British colony, the growth of the shipping industry and surrounding plantations, the city's role in the events leading up to the Civil War, the resurgence of the community during the late 19th century, and the establishment of one of the most complete and intact historic districts in the country.

image.caption: Fort Sumter
image.alttext: Fort Sumter was one of a series of coastal fortifications built by the United States after the War of 1812. Begun in 1829 and named for South Carolina Revolutionary War patriot Thomas Sumter, the fort

resource.title: Historic Places of the Civil Rights Movement
resource.description: shows 41 churches, houses, and other properties related largely to the post-World War II civil rights movement. The links to these properties consist of photographs and texts, and the exhibit offers a bibliography and links to websites relating to civil rights.

image.caption: Civil rights leaders
image.alttext: Civil Rights Leaders (L to R) John Lewis, Whitney Young, A. Philip Randolph, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., James Farmer,and Roy Wilkins. Photograph courtesy of Representative John Lewis

interestingfact.text: Montgomery's black citizens reacted decisively to the Rosa Parks incident. By December 2, schoolteacher Jo Ann Robinson had mimeographed and delivered 50,000 protest leaflets around town. Black leaders formed the Montgomery Improvement Association to spearhead a boycott and negotiate with the bus company. They named Dexter Avenue Baptist Church's new minister, Martin Luther King, Jr., president.

resource.title: Detroit: A National Register of Historic Places Travel Itinerary
resource.description: exhibits residential, recreational, commercial, industrial, and religious locations to create an online tour of the city. The itinerary features 39 properties in the National Register of Historic Places. Through maps, descriptions, and photographs of places both famous and little-known, this guide explains why Detroit has long been more than just a Motor City.

image.caption: Tiger Stadium
image.alttext: Tiger Stadium Aerial View. Photograph by Mark Hicks, courtesy of the Detroit Tigers

resource.title: Kingston, New York: A National Register of Historic Places Travel Itinerary
resource.description: explores Kingston's over 300 years of history using 24 historic places that recall past eras when settlers and Native Americans warily shared its plains, proud Revolutionaries and angry British armies walked its narrow streets and when coal, limestone and even patent medicines flowed along its canals. The Dutch established Kingston 1652 and it became an active participant in the American Revolution and a major river-port during New York's 19th-century canal and steamboat era.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Rondout II lighthouse
image.alttext: When the harbor entrance was realigned, the current lighthouse, 'Rondout II,' was built in 1915. Constructed of yellow brick on a foundation of concrete and 50-foot wooden pilings

resource.title: Places Where Women Made History: A National Register of Historic Places Travel Itinerary
resource.description: explores 74 sites in Massachusetts and New York associated with women's history. This travel itinerary includes homes of Clara Barton, Emily Dickinson, Harriet Tubman, Susan B. Anthony, Madame C.J. Walker, and others.

image.caption: Edith Wharton
image.alttext: Edith Wharton at her desk at The Mount c. 1905. Courtesy of Edith Wharton Restoration at The Mount.

resource.title: Washington DC: A Guide to the Historic Neighborhoods and Monuments of Our Nation's Capital
resource.description: identifies 96 historic places that bring the 200-year history of our nation's capital to life. Learn about famous national landmarks -- the Mall, Capitol Building, White House -- and about historic neighborhoods and local landmarks that make the city unique.

image.caption: Scottish Rite Temple
image.alttext: Photo of House of the Temple, the headquarters building of the Scottish Rite of Freemasonry, Southern Jurisdicton, USA.

interestingfact.text: The Lincoln Memorial was designed by Henry Bacon, after ancient Greek temples, stands 190 feet long, 119 feet wide, and almost 100 feet high. It is surrounded by a peristyle of 38 fluted Doric columns, one for each of the thirty six states in the Union at the time of Lincoln's death, and two columns in-antis at the entrance behind the colonnade.

resource.title: Teaching with Historic Places
resource.description: uses properties listed in the National Park Service's National Register of Historic Places to enliven history, social studies, geography, civics, and other subjects. TwHP has created products and activities that help teachers bring historic places into the classroom. Lesson plans turn students into historians as they study primary sources, historical and contemporary photographs and maps, and other documents, and then search for the history around them in their own communities.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Glen Echo Park
image.alttext: Glen Echo Park entrance, c. 1938. (From the collection of Richard A. Cook)

resource.title: Remembering Pearl Harbor
resource.description: describes the 1941 Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor and features the USS Arizona, a battleship on which 1,177 sailors and marines perished. Photos, charts, documents, and research questions help students piece together what happened before, during, and after the attack that drew the U.S. into World War II.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: USS Arizona burns and sinks
image.alttext: Shattered by a direct hit, the USS Arizona burns and sinks, December 7, 1941.

interestingfact.text: The attack on Pearl Harbor was the culmination of a decade of deteriorating relations between Japan and the U.S. over the status of China and the security of Southeast Asia.

resource.title: Invention Factory: Thomas Edison
resource.description: is a curriculum-oriented guide to the work and laboratories of the great American inventor. The site contains photographs, maps, and readings about the laboratories and the process of turning research into commercial products.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Miner safety lamps
image.alttext: Edison holding one of his miner safety lamps, 1923.

resource.title: The Building of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal
resource.description: helps students realize the role canals played in western expansion and in the evolution of transportation by focusing on the construction of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal. Students can read about George Washington's influence on the C & O Canal and the men and women who worked on or lived near canal.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Building the canal
image.alttext: The canal was built mainly with hand tools and horse power. Construction did not simply begin at one end and progress steadily to the other end, leaving a finished canal in its wake. (David Demero, C

resource.title: Andersonville: Prisoner of War Camp
resource.description: examines the conditions of Camp Sumter (in Andersonville, Georgia), the largest and most notorious of prisoner of war camps during the Civil War.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Andersonville Prison -- August 1864
image.alttext: Andersonville Prison (looking southeast from the sinks), 1864. (Andersonville National Historic Site, National Park Service)

resource.title: First Battle of Manassas: An End to Innocence
resource.description: looks at the first conflict of the Civil War, the battle of Bull Run. More than 5,000 people perished -- Northern and Southern troops, as well as private citizens who came from Washington, D.C., to watch. Personal stories, maps, and photos show how this battle shocked the nation into realizing that the conflict was not some romantic adventure and that it would be longer and more costly than anyone had imagined.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: The Stone House
image.alttext: The Stone House was the home of the Henry Matthews family during the Civil War. The house served as a hospital following the first battle of Manassas.

resource.title: Woodrow Wilson: Prophet of Peace
resource.description: examines President Wilson's struggle and ultimate failure to reach the ideal of achieving lasting world peace through the League of Nations. Through various activities students can learn about the conflict between Wilson's ideals of world peace and the Senate's policy of isolationism.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: The Wilson house
image.alttext: See caption below.

resource.title: Growing into Public Service: William Howard Taft's Boyhood Home
resource.description: examines the family and setting in Cincinnati where the 27th President and Chief Justice of the Supreme Court grew up. It includes readings, maps, photos, and activities for students.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Taft house
image.alttext: The Taft House, 1868. (William Howard Taft National Historic Site, National Park Service)

resource.title: Life on an Island: Early Settlers Off the Rock-Bound Coast of Maine
resource.description: examines the difficult lives and environment of everyday people on several of the 5,000 islands off the coast of Maine. It features stories about family life and includes a business ledger, personal journal, and other documents.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.alttext: Little Cranberry Island in 1870: The Blue Duck (left center with end chimney) and original Samuel Hadlock store (center). (From tintype by Mr. Bragg. Acadia National Park)

resource.title: Castolon: A Meeting Place of Two Cultures
resource.description: depicts a small trading and farming community in far southwest Texas, near the border with Mexico (in the southwest corner of today's Big Bend National Park). Castolon was a farming, ranching, and storekeeping partnership at Camp Santa Helena, established after the end of the Mexican Revolution (1920).

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Cotton fields
image.alttext: Cotton fields, with the Sierra Ponce in the background. (Big Bend National Park)

resource.title: Decatur House: A Home of the Rich and Powerful
resource.description: examines the life of Stephen Decatur, a naval hero who died as a result of a duel in 1820, and considers the role the house he built played in the political and social scene of the nation's capital up to the 20th century.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Decatur House, 1967
image.alttext: Decatur House, 1967. (Decatur House Collection)

resource.title: Knife River: Early Village Life on the Plains
resource.description: describes village life in the Hidatsa and Mandan tribes during the peak of their culture in the early 19th century (North Dakota). It helps students compare information about these seasonally nomadic Plains villagers with the more popularized film and textbook history of nomadic horse-culture Indians such as the Lakota and Cheyenne.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Hidatsa village?
image.alttext: 'Hidatsa Village, Earth Covered Lodges, on the Knife River,' by George Catlin. (Smithsonian American Art Museum, Gift of Mrs. Joseph Harrison, Jr.)

resource.title: Vieux Carré: A Creole Neighborhood in New Orleans
resource.description: looks at the history of the French Quarter, the heart and soul of modern New Orleans and a constant reminder of the city's Creole, colonial past.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Plan of New Orleans, 1720
image.alttext: Image of the plan of New Orleans, circa 1720

interestingfact.text: The Vieux Carré ("old square") is the original city of New Orleans as laid out by the French military. Today, the Vieux Carré contains a remarkably well-preserved collection of buildings covering a wide range of styles and periods in an approximately 120-block area.

resource.title: Building America's Industrial Revolution: The Boott Cotton Mills of Lowell, Massachusetts
resource.description: features one of the oldest surviving textile mill complexes in the U.S. Learn how technology revolutionized the textile-manufacturing industry, and, in turn, affected mill architecture, city planning, and transportation.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Almy, Brown, and Slater's Mill
image.alttext: Conjectural drawing of Almy, Brown, and Slater's Mill, 1793. (Courtesy Old Slater Mill Association)

resource.title: Weir Farm: Home of an American Impressionist
resource.description: examines the farm acquired by painter Alden Weir (1852-1919), where he summered for nearly 40 years (northeast of New City). At a time railroads were expanding, populations were increasing, and America's agrarian system was being replaced by industry, Weir was an artist who found inspiration in the quiet everyday settings of New England, and, in many ways, defined our vision of the American landscape.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Side saddle
image.alttext: Cora Weir riding side saddle, c. 1900. (Courtesy Weir Farm Trust)

resource.title: Allegheny Portage Railroad: Developing Transportation Technology
resource.description: shows the innovative transportation system used in the 1820s-1840s to tow railroad cars up and down the steep slopes of the Allegheny Mountains.

publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.alttext: A Sectional Canal Boat in the Hitching Shed,' by George Storm, date unknown. (National Park Service)

resource.title: First Lady to the World: Eleanor Roosevelt at Val-Kill
resource.description: is a curriculum-oriented guide to the work of the active First Lady. The site uses a retreat she built on her husband's estate as a focus but gives readings and suggested school assignments about Ms. Roosevelt's career.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

resource.title: Clara Barton's House: Home of the American Red Cross
resource.description: is a curriculum-oriented guide to the life of the famous nurse. The site uses photographs, floor plans, and the like about her home in Glen Echo, Maryland as a focal point but gives readings and suggested school assignments about her career.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.alttext: No. 2 Red Cross Hotel, Johnstown, Pennsylvania, 1889. (Clara Barton National Historic Site)

resource.title: Thaw in the Cold War: Eisenhower and Khrushchev at Gettysburg
resource.description: describes how President Eisenhower's personal diplomacy at his Gettysburg farm helped ease the tensions of the Cold War. The site offers photos and maps of the home as well as readings and suggestions for student assignments.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Eisenhower and Khrushchev
image.alttext: President Eisenhower and Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev pose in front of Aspen Lodge at Camp David, Maryland, September 25, 1959.

resource.title: San Antonio Missions: Spanish Influence in Texas
resource.description: explores a group of 18th-century missions in modern San Antonio to learn about the Spanish influence on native peoples and the patterns of Texas culture. Students can learn about the psychological and cultural factors that led the Coahuiltecan Indians to accept mission life and how irrigation systems, such as acequias, assisted in the development of Texas farmland and other arid areas.

resource.title: Saugus Iron Works: Life and Work at an Early American Industrial Site
resource.description: examines life and work at the first successful integrated ironmaking plant in colonial America (from 1646 until 1668, 10 miles north of Boston).

resource.title: Frederica: An 18th-Century Planned Community
resource.description: recounts British efforts to establish Georgia as a utopia in the American wilderness (1730s) and to fortify the colony against Spanish encroachment, in part through the creation of a fort and military town on St. Simons Island, Georgia.

resource.title: Birthplace of John F. Kennedy: Home of the Boy Who Would Be President
resource.description: takes students to JFK's birthplace and to the neighborhood where he grew up. It was here that JFK's parents began instilling the high standards and ambition that would make the Kennedys one of America's most famous families. Students can investigate the Kennedy's family traditions, values, and interests to consider how family culture and community shapes one's character and personality.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

resource.title: Herbert Hoover: Iowa Farm Boy and World Humanitarian
resource.description: is a curriculum-oriented site using the birthplace of the American president to introduce readings and suggested theme topics for student papers. The site shows photos and drawings of the home in West Branch, Iowa, where Hoover was born.

image.alttext: World War I Posters. (Courtesy of Herbert Hoover Library)

resource.title: Mammoth Cave: Its Explorers, Miners, Archeologists, and Visitors
resource.description: explores a cave in southwestern Kentucky that, with more than 345 miles of explored passageways, is the longest cave in the world.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

resource.title: The Liberty Bell: From Obscurity to Icon
resource.description: helps students analyze -- through maps, readings, and images -- the historical and cultural influences that shaped the symbolic meaning of the Liberty Bell.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

resource.title: Martin Van Buren's "Return to the Soil"
resource.description: is a curriculum-oriented site using the home, named Lindenwald, the eighth President moved to after his term in office to introduce a discussion of Van Buren and his times. The site contains photos and drawings of Lindenwald as well as discussions how Van Buren interacted with other political leaders of the day, like Andrew Jackson and John C. Calhoun. The site offers many questions and suggestions for student assignments.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Entrance hall
image.alttext: Entrance Hall, Lindenwald. (Martin Van Buren National Historic Site)

resource.title: When Rice Was King
resource.description: concentrates on Georgetown County, South Carolina, where rice, rather than cotton, was the principal commercial product. The site contains maps, readings, photos, drawings, as well as a guide for doing a student project.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Slave cabin
image.alttext: Slave cabin, Keithfield Plantation, Georgetown County, South Carolina. (Sherry Piland)

resource.title: Battle of Bunker Hill: Now We Are at War
resource.description: describes how this American Revolution battle spurred colonial unity and sparked the formation of the Continental Army.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Breed's Hill
image.alttext: A miniature showing the redoubt atop Breed's Hill and the colonists waiting for the advancing British troops, June 17, 1775.

resource.title: The Frankish Building: A Reflection of the Success of Ontario, California
resource.description: helps students gauge the impact of the Chaffey brothers and Charles Frankish on Ontario, California, and compare their efforts with those of similarly important figures in their own community's history.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Frankish building
image.alttext: Frankish Building. (Photo by Brent Heath.)

resource.title: Choices and Commitments: The Soldiers at Gettysburg
resource.description: aims to help students understand the Gettysburg Campaign and the major actions of the armies during each day of the battle, as well as the motives and experiences of several participants in the battle. It offers readings, maps, photos, and activities for students.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Trostle house
image.alttext: Photo of Aftermath of the Battle of Gettysburg, Trostle House

interestingfact.text: Gettysburg was a pivotal battle of the Civil War, involving more than 160,000 combatants from both sides. The three days of fighting, July 1-3, 1863, resulted in 51,000 casualties, the greatest number of any Civil War battle. Militarily, it was the South's last attempt at a full-scale invasion of the North.

resource.title: Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site: Home of a Gilded Age Icon
resource.description: looks at this place in western New Hampshire where the sculptor Augustus Saint-Gaudens established a summer home and studio (1885), conceived a host of projects, became the leader of an art colony, battled cancer, and was buried. It is a window on one aspect of the Gilded Age: the role of the artist.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: $20 gold piece
image.alttext: Saint-Gaudens' $20 gold piece. (Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site)

resource.title: The Great Chief Justice at Home
resource.description: offers photos of John Marshall's residence in Richmond, Virginia. This website also describes how Marshall, who wrote 519 opinions in his 34 years as chief justice (1801-1835), transformed the Supreme Court from obscurity into a prominent, powerful institution.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: John Marshall house
image.alttext: Exterior front view, John Marshall House. (Courtesy of Association for the Preservation of Virginia Antiquities)

resource.title: Ybor City: Cigar Capitol of the World
resource.description: reveals how immigrant cigar makers adapted to life in the U.S. in the late 19th and early 20th century while maintaining their ethnic identity. This lesson also describes Cuban immigrant efforts to free Cuba from Spain and their involvement in the Spanish-American War of 1898.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.alttext: Cigar factory workers at the Ybor Factory, 1925. (Florida State Archives)

resource.title: Chattanooga, Tennessee: Train Town
resource.description: helps students see how geography and promotion combined to encourage the growth of Chattanooga, Tennessee, and how railroads shaped the organization and architecture of this and other cities from the mid-1800s to mid-1990s.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.alttext: Chattanooga Terminal Station, 1935. (Chattanooga-Hamilton County Bicentennial Library)

resource.title: Chicago's Black Metropolis: Understanding History through a Historic Place
resource.description: is a curriculum-oriented site concentrating on the area, south of the main business district, where blacks lived in Chicago, Illinois. The site shows photos and maps of historic buildings in the area and gives suggestions for student assignments.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Overton hygenic building
image.alttext: Overton Hygenic Building, 1927. (The Negro in Chicago, 1779-1929, Washington Intercollegiate Club of Chicago, Inc., 1929.)

resource.title: The Battle of Horseshoe Bend: Collisions of Cultures
resource.description: looks at the decisive battle of the Creek War (1813-1814), where Andrew Jackson fought 1,000 American Indian warriors who were trying to regain autonomy. It examines the history of the battle and provides maps, images, and readings.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Horseshoe Bend
image.alttext: Image of Horseshoe Bend

interestingfact.text: It was around 1680 that English traders started talking and writing about the "Creek" Indians. They first applied this name to the people who lived near Ochesee Creek in northern Georgia, where there was active trading of European manufactured goods for deerskins.

resource.title: Gold Fever! Seattle Outfits the Klondike Gold Rush
resource.description: focuses on the pivotal role that Seattle and Pioneer Square played as the chief outfitting and transportation center during the Klondike Gold Rush. It also looks at difficulties stampeders encountered on their journey from Seattle to the Klondike.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Pioneer outfitters
image.alttext: Cooper and Levy Pioneer Outfitters. (Special Collections, University of Washington Libraries, Curtis Photo, Neg. 26368)

resource.title: Iron Hill School: An African-American One-Room School
resource.description: is a curriculum-oriented guide focusing on a school constructed in 1923 in a rural area of northern Delaware, one of more than 80 schools for African-American children built between 1919 and 1928 as part of philanthropist Pierre Samuel du Pont's "Delaware experiment." The site shows photos, maps, and diagrams about the school itself and suggests student activities ranging from philanthropy to school architecture.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Anthoston, Kentucky -- 1916
image.alttext: Photo of the interior of an African-American School in Anthoston, Kentucky, built ca. 1875, photographed 1916.

interestingfact.text: The early 20th century in America, a period characterized by nationwide social reform, is often referred to as the Progressive Era. During this period, more and more people recognized that education was the best guarantee of economic success for young people.

resource.title: Bethlehem, Pennsylvania: A Moravian Settlement in Colonial America
resource.description: looks at this area (along the Lehigh River) that became the center of industry and community for Moravians, a Protestant group that migrated to colonial America seeking opportunity and the chance to spread their religious beliefs.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Moravian chapel
image.alttext: The Moravian Chapel. (Photo by Diane LaBelle)

resource.title: The North Carolina State Capitol: Pride of the State
resource.description: tells the story of this state capitol -- how a committee settled on a location, how a new town (Raleigh) was laid out in 1792, and why the "political temple" erected in mid 1800s stands today among the finest examples of civic Greek Revival architecture in the U.S.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Original state house
image.alttext: Watercolor of original State House by J.S. Glennie, 1811. (Princeton University Library)

resource.title: The Washington Monument: Tribute in Stone
resource.description: focuses on George Washington's life, his impact on our nation, and the design and history of this famous memorial. Students are invited to evaluate proposed plans for the monument and other historical maps, diagrams, and information.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Design & today
image.alttext: Photo of the Washington Monument

interestingfact.text: Disagreements over a proper memorial to Washington continued for the first three decades of the 19th century, with nothing built during this time. Samuel Blodgett published a broadside at the beginning of that period. It records many of the arguments that would appear over those 30 years.

resource.title: Gran Quivira: A Blending of Cultures in a Pueblo Indian Village
resource.description: can help students understand daily life and how it changed for the Pueblo Indians of Gran Quivira, the largest of the three Salinas pueblos located in central New Mexico.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Gran Quivira unit
image.alttext: Photo of the Gran Quivira Unit, Salinas Pueblo Missions National Monument.

interestingfact.text: In the remote Salinas basin in central New Mexico stand the weathered ruins of three Puebloan villages and the 17th-century Spanish colonial missions that make up Salinas Pueblo Missions National Monument. Two ancient southwestern cultural traditions?the Mogollon (muggy-own) and Anasazi?overlapped here and resulted in the Puebloan communities of Abó, Quarai, and Gran Quivira (also known as Las Humanas).

resource.title: Adeline Hornbek and the Homestead Act: A Colorado Success Story
resource.description: explores how Adeline Hornbek, single mother of four, defied traditional gender roles to become the owner of a successful ranch under the Homestead Act.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Representative barn
image.alttext: Representative Barn on Hornbek Homestead. (Florissant Fossil Beds National Monument)

resource.title: The Battle of Bentonville: Caring for Casualties of the Civil War
resource.description: shows how battlefield medical care developed during the Civil War, particularly in the Union Army.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Amputation at Camp Letterman
image.alttext: Amputation being performed in a hospital tent, Gettysburg, July 1863. (National Archives and Records Administration)

resource.title: Siege of Port Hudson: Forty Days and Nights in the Wilderness of Death
resource.description: describes the struggle for control of the vital Mississippi River during the Civil War. It discusses the tactics, theories, and ramifications of this battle between the North and the South. The site features maps, firsthand accounts, and photographs, as well as lessons and activities.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.alttext: A Confederate cannon demolished by Federal artillery fire. The earthworks include a barrel (upper left) with a hole for sharpshooting. This was nicknamed

resource.title: Battle of Mill Springs: The Civil War Divides a Border State
resource.description: focuses on a key Civil War battle to demonstrate how both the Union and the Confederacy attempted to win the loyalty of the citizens of Kentucky. The site presents maps, readings from Northern and Southern perspectives, and drawings and photographs about the battle, weather, and weapons.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: General Zollicoffer's death
image.alttext: The death of General Zollicoffer. (Harper's Weekly Magazine)

resource.title: Fort Morgan and the Battle of Mobile Bay
resource.description: presents firsthand accounts, maps, and more pertaining to this Civil War conflict (August 5, 1864) in which Union Admiral David Farragut led about 20 ships and vessels into the torpedo-filled Mobile Bay.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.alttext: Lighthouse and hot shot furnace, after the Battle of Mobile Bay, 1864. (National Archives)

resource.title: Skagway: Gateway to the Klondike
resource.description: examines the impact of the Klondike Gold Rush on the development of Skagway, Alaska. This lesson allows students to trace the development of Skagway from a homestead, to a gold rush boomtown, to a permanent city.

resource.title: The M'Clintock House: A Home to the Women's Rights Movement
resource.description: is a curriculum-oriented guide to a home in Waterloo, New York in which several early abolitionists, women's rights advocates, and social reformers lived. The site uses photos and drawings of the house as a beginning point to lead into readings about the First Woman's Rights Convention in nearby Seneca Falls in 1848.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: M'Clintock house today
image.alttext: The M'Clintock House Today. (Women's Rights National Historical Park)

resource.title: Californio to American: A Study in Cultural Change
resource.description: looks at an area that was once part of an Indian village, then an outpost shelter for vaqueros (cowhands), and then the site where Californios (Spanish settlers in what is now the state of California) built small adobe dwellings in the midst of their cattle ranges. Successive owners altered one dwelling into the elegant 18-room ranch house there today -- Rancho Los Alamitos.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Rancho Los Alamitos
image.alttext: Rancho Los Alamitos, view from rear patio. (Photo by Beth Boland)

resource.title: Old Courthouse in St. Louis
resource.description: is exhibit about a place which, throughout the 19th century, served not only as a house of justice, but also as a public gathering place for pioneers planning their westward trek across the plains. Its iron-framed dome was the forerunner of many similar domes erected on government buildings throughout the country. The site contains maps, readings, photos, drawings, as well as a guide for doing a student project.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.alttext: The Old Courthouse and St. Louis skyline today. (Photo: Beth Boland.)

resource.title: From Canterbury to Little Rock: The Struggle for Educational Equality for African Americans
resource.description: highlights two historic places and the role each played in the effort toward creating equal educational opportunities for African Americans.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Elizabeth Eckford,... one of the Little Rock Nine
image.alttext: Photo of high school freshman Elizabeth Eckford,... one of the 'Little Rock Nine' who braved a jeering crowd, September 4, 1957. (Photo by and courtesy of Will Counts and the Arkansas Democrat-Gazet

interestingfact.text: Events in Canterbury, Connecticut, in the early 1830s brought race related issues to the forefront when a young teacher named Prudence Crandall admitted an African-American student to her boarding school and subsequently opened a school strictly for black females.

resource.title: Locke and Walnut Grove: Havens for Early Asian Immigrants in California
resource.description: looks at the contributions of early Asian immigrants to the development of California's economic and agricultural industries. The site also identifies obstacles encountered by Asian cultural groups in America and describes life in Walnut Grove and Locke during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Chinese Mason building
image.alttext: Chinese Mason Building, River Road elevation, Walnut Grove. (Photo by Mary L. Manieri for Par Environmental Services)

resource.title: Two American Entrepreneurs: Madam C.J. Walker and J.C. Penney
resource.description: features the life stories of two business people who lived the American Dream and who helped make that dream a reality for others in their communities. It tells how Walker, an African American woman, and Penney, a former tuberculosis patient, built from scratch their multi-million and billion dollar businesses.

publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: The Walker building
image.alttext: Photo of the Walker Building, Indianapolis, Indiana. Indiana Division of Historic Preservation and Archaeology

interestingfact.text: Madam Walker developed, manufactured, and sold formulas for hair care and other beauty products for African American women. She began selling her homemade products door-to-door in 1905 in Denver, Colorado.

resource.title: Outline of Prehistory and History
resource.description: outlines historical features of the Southeast U.S. and the Caribbean culture regions. Learn about the natural history of the area, its native populations, exploration, colonization, and maritime history. The site also includes a feature on underwater archeology.

image.caption: Sarah's Ridge archaic site
image.alttext: Sarah's Ridge Archaic site (Southeast Archeological Center - National Park Service).

resource.title: History & Culture
resource.description: offers educators Park Service resources that help teach about our nation's cultural heritage, and which look at how the NPS is protecting and preserving them. Subjects include archaeology, historic buildings and structures, mapping, military history, and national historic landmarks. The resources may be in the form of learning programs, case studies, lesson plans, teachers' handbooks, and more.

resource.title: DoHistory
resource.description: shows how to piece together fragments of the past and research the lives of ordinary people. It also features an interactive case study built from research conducted for A Midwife's Tale, a book and film based on the 200-year-old diary of midwife/healer Martha Ballard.

resource.description: is a place you can find help for every state of the financial aid process, whether you're in school or out of school. The site helps you apply for financial aid over the Internet and find out about scholarships, college costs, and college admissions information. It is also a gateway to other funding resources.

resource.title: School-Home Links Reading Kit
resource.description: offers four hundred activities for strengthening children's reading and writing skills (one kit for each grade level, kindergarten through 3rd grade). resource.description: is a booklet parents can use to explore with children (ages 2-5) key geographical concepts?location, regions, movement, and others.

resource.title: Museums and Learning: A Guide for Family Visits
resource.description: provides basic information about museums and how they relate to learning, and suggests ways to make museum visits enjoyable learning experiences for families with children ranging in age from 4 to 12 years old.

resource.title: Helping Your Child Learn Math
resource.description: features dozens of fun activities parents can use to help children (K-5th grade) have fun learning geometry, algebra, measurement, statistics, probability and other important mathematical concepts. Activities relate math to everyday life and can be done at home, at the grocery store, or while traveling. It includes sections for parents on what math is like in schools today and a parents' booklist for helping children learn math.

resource.title: Helping Your Child Become a Reader
resource.description: offers dozens of activities families may use to help young children learn the alphabet, play with rhymes, "read" picture books, act out poems, predict what happens next in stories, create a bookcase, enjoy family stories, write notes and stories, and more.

resource.title: NOAA Education Resources
resource.description: offers materials on weather, oceans and coasts, satellites and space, and long-term climate change. The site also contains a photo library, real time satellite imagery, and a radar mosaic of weather patterns.

image.caption: The ocean
image.alttext: One cannot learn about the weather we experience without considering the ocean and its effect on our weather

resource.title: Energy Country Analysis Briefs
resource.description: contains briefs for every country in the world of interest to energy policy makers. Each brief has a narrative section, a map showing the country's location, and a section listing pertinent economic and energy data.

resource.title: EIA's Kids Page
resource.description: invites kids on a fun-filled tour of the various kinds, sources, and uses of energy. Students can take a quick energy quiz, read fun facts, or visit five energy producing facilities.

image.caption: Wave energy
image.alttext: Waves are caused by the wind blowing over the surface of the ocean. There is tremendous energy in the ocean waves.

resource.title: EnviroMapper Storefront
resource.description: lets kids create their own maps, down to the square mile, anywhere in America, choosing various features -- from water discharges to hazardous waste to roads. The site contains reports and maps of EPA's activities in your area.

resource.title: EPA: Students and Teachers
resource.description: presents teaching and learning resources from the Environmental Protection Agency. The site links to the Environmental Education Center (for teachers), EPA Student Center (for middle and high school students), and EPA Explorers Club (ages 5-12). With fact-sheets, interactivegames, and more, EPA's website can help you with many types of information about EPA and the environment.

image.caption: Bird conservation
image.alttext: Photo of flock of ducks flying overhead

resource.title: EPA: Wastes
resource.description: is a place where students and teachers can order educational materials, activity books and games that help raise awareness about solid waste issues, learn how to gain hands-on awareness of waste reduction, recycling, and composting, through solid waste service-learning projects, and learn about careers in solid waste management.

resource.title: Environmental Explorers' Club
resource.description: is a place where kids can learn about the environment and the Environmental Protection Agency. It features plants and animals, air, water, people and the environment, recycling, and a clubhouse area containing art, a game room, a science room, and a trophy room listing the winners of the President's Environmental Youth Award.

image.caption: Environmental basics
image.alttext: Childlike drawing of the earth

interestingfact.text: Weather is the specific condition of the atmosphere at a particular place and time. Climate is the average of weather over time and space. A simple way of remembering the difference is that climate is what you expect (e.g., cold winters) and weather is what you get (e.g., a blizzard).

resource.title: Recycle City
resource.description: shows how people are recycling and reusing products across this fictional city. Click on a map to see how the warehouse, landfill, theatre, cafe, service station, supermarket, factory, and school are reducing waste. Learn about the role of transportation, household supplies, and the materials recovery center.

image.caption: Widget Manufacturing Co.
image.alttext: Widget Manufacturing Co. is a model business for waste reduction. Plant managers, Tyrone Jones and Rosy Littlefeather, give bonuses to Widget workers who come up with new ways to reduce, reuse, or rec

resource.title: Drinking Water; Kids' Stuff
resource.description: teaches kids about the importance of safe drinking water through teaching and learning resources such as an activity on how to build your own aquifer, experiments on the water treatment process, and the drinking water art project.

image.caption: Water cycle adventure
image.alttext: Graphic of the water cycle process: Clouds - Rain/Snow - Groundwater - Bedrock - Vapor - Sun

resource.title: EPA Student Center
resource.description: contains dozens of environmental science resources for students as well as online reference materials.

image.caption: America's wetlands

resource.title: Superfund for Kids
resource.description: introduces children ages 3 and up to the basic concepts of the Superfund program. There are activities, stories, and homework help designed for different age groups.

resource.title: Superfund for Students and Teachers
resource.description: contains information about Superfund and hazardous waste for junior high, high school, and college students, and teachers of all grade levels. The site includes classroom activities, frequently asked questions, and information on environmentaleducation and grants.

image.caption: Waste site activity
image.alttext: Groundwater is rain water or water from surface water bodies, like lakes or streams, that soaks into the soil and bedrock and is stored underground in the tiny spaces between rocks and particles of so

resource.title: Environmental Education
resource.description: contains environmental science resources and is oriented to teachers searching for classroom projects.

image.caption: Youth awards
image.alttext: Since 1971, EPA has sponsored the President?s Environmental Youth Awards (PEYA). The program recognizes young people across America for projects which demonstrate their commitment to the environment.

resource.title: Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy Network
resource.description: features information on energy efficiency in buildings, transportation, industry, and utilities. It looks at renewable energy sources, including hydropower, geothermal, solar, and wind.

image.alttext: Geothermal power plants use the natural heat of the earth to generate electricity for homes and businesses. Geothermal power is a renewable source of energy and does not rely on coal or other fossil f

image.alttext: Image of instructor and student flyer in cockpit

resource.title: FDA's Kid's Page
resource.description: includes a food safety quiz, a piece about how the FDA conducts its investigations, and pages about animals, vaccines, and tobacco. There are also specific pages designed for teens and parents.

resource.title: FEMA for Kids
resource.description: teaches children how to prepare for disasters and how to prevent disasters. Kids can also learn about different types and causes of disasters, share disaster stories, play games, read stories, access research materials, and become a Disaster Action Kid. The site offers disaster prevention resources for parents, teachers, and child care providers.

image.caption: The disaster twins
image.alttext: Robbie and Julia are twins and they live in Eenietown. They attend Booksin School, where they have lots of friends and a teacher named Mrs. Fletcher.

resource.title: Helping Children Prepare for Disasters
resource.description: helps kids put together a disaster supply kit, set up a family disaster plan, read about what they might feel in a disaster, learn about pet protection, read a series of stories about kids who are always prepared for a natural disaster, and join Project IMPACT, a community damage mitigation program.

image.caption: Saving your pets
image.alttext: Childlike image of household-type pets

resource.title: Disaster Resources for Parents and Teachers
resource.description: provides a list of disaster relief documents relating to preparation and early warning systems, making schools more disaster resistant, helping child victims of disasters, talking to children about the threat of biological warfare or terrorist attack, and more.

resource.title: What Disasters Are Happening Now?
resource.description: is a place where students can go to find out about natural disasters in the U.S. and FEMA's efforts to control and combat them. The site links to general information on disasters, disaster history, and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's Weather Radio.

resource.title: The Lincoln Legal Papers
resource.description: documents Lincoln's active and successful professional life as a lawyer before he moved to Washington, D.C. in 1861. The site's editors will select, annotate, and transcribe material from 96,386 documents related to the 5,669 legal cases and activities of Lincoln's varied legal career.

resource.title: Figure This!
resource.description: offers interactive math problems families can use to help children understand estimation, volume, and other important mathematical concepts.

resource.title: FrogWeb
resource.description: is an effort to inform the public about declines and deformities in numerous amphibian species. The site is designed for parents, teachers, and children, and it includes general information about amphibians and their habitats, research currently underway, programs in which the public can help collect amphibian data, and activities to help classes and families learn about amphibian biology and populations.

resource.title: GLOBE -- Global Learning and Observations to Benefit the Environment
resource.description: is a worldwide network of students, teachers, and scientists working together to study and understand the global environment. Students and teachers from more than 9,500 schools in over 90 countries collect data that are then used by scientists and other researchers. It provides teacher guides, workshops, views of the data and the research, a resource library and more.

image.caption: Earth system resources
image.alttext: This is a letter-sized color version of the GLOBE Earth System Poster. This is similar to the black and white version in the Activity Guide for the GLOBE Earth System Poster.

resource.title: H-NET, Humanities Online
resource.description: is an interdisciplinary organization of scholars dedicated to developing the educational potential of the Internet. The site includes discussion areas on a growing list of cultural topics, reviews of current titles, teaching resources, news announcement, and job guides.

image.caption: Reviews
image.alttext: Collage of books, film, and movie projector

resource.title: PREVLINE
resource.description: is a national clearinghouse for alcohol and drug information. It offers fact sheets, video and audio files, news, research briefs, conference calendars, funding opportunities, and a kids section.

publisher.name: Department of Health and Human Services
publisher.agency: Department of Health and Human Services

resource.title: healthfinder® kids
resource.description: is a place where kids can find information on protecting their bodies and minds. It offers more than 75 games and activities, information on safe web navigation, and a link to art contents. The website also has a section for parents and other caregivers of children with links to products and information that promote children's health.

publisher.name: Department of Health and Human Services
publisher.agency: Department of Health and Human Services

resource.title: healthfinder ®
resource.description: is a gateway to consumer health and human services information. It offers health and well-being information on infants, children, teens, adults, and seniors, and looks at issues such as minority and family health. It provides links to online journals, medical dictionaries, databases, and more.

publisher.name: Department of Health and Human Services
publisher.agency: Department of Health and Human Services

image.caption: Achilles tendinitis
image.alttext: Achilles tendinitis is an inflammation and/or degeneration of the Achilles tendon. Copyright © 2005 Nucleus Communications, Inc. All rights reserved.

resource.title: Your Place in Time
resource.description: highlights five generations of the 20th century and looks at everyday technologies that shaped each of those generations. Each exhibit is presented through a series of vignettes. The site offers classroom activities and links for teachers.

publisher.name: Henry Ford Museum and Greenfield Village

image.caption: The next generation
image.alttext: Lauryn Hill CD cover

resource.title: Hoover Dam Learning Packet
resource.description: contains learning activities on the impact of Hoover Dam on the environment and its technical and historical significance. Learn about the history, wildlife, water resources, and hydroelectricity of Hoover Dam.

resource.title: History and Politics Out Loud
resource.description: lets us hear key speeches by Martin Luther King Jr., Winston Churchill, Franklin Roosevelt, Lyndon Johnson, Richard Nixon, and others. Listen to King's "I have a dream" speech, President Roosevelt's speech to Congress declaring war on Japan, Churchill's "iron curtain" speech, and more.

image.caption: Hear history as it happened
image.alttext: HPOL home graphic: old time radio

interestingfact.text: Martin Luther King, Jr.: "...we will be able to speed up that day when all of God's children...will be able to join hands and sing in the words of the old Negro spiritual: 'Free at last! Free at last! Thank God Almighty, we are free at last!'"

resource.title: Humanities Exhibits Interactive
resource.description: examines topics such as border studies, Texas history and culture, ancient and contemporary world cultures, and our literary heritage. It includes annotated images, learning resources, essays, educational worksheets, associated games, and multimedia presentations.

image.caption: Christopher Columbus the Genoese
image.alttext: What did Columbus look like? There are some direct observations, which state that he was handsome, taller than average and heavily built; he had light-colored and lively eyes; blond hair with red tint

resource.title: William Blake Archive
resource.description: brings together Blake's disparate, widely dispersed, and often restricted major visual and artistic works in one searchable website. The archive contains scalable electronic editions of Blake's illuminated works with full, up-to-date bibliographic information about each image.

image.caption: Urizen as the Creator?
image.alttext: William Blake. 'Urizen as the Creator of the Material World' from Europe, A Prophecy. Title Page. Lambeth: Printed by W. Blake, 1794. Rosenwald Collection, Rare Book and Special Collections Division

resource.title: Evolution and the Nature of Science Institutes
resource.description: is a collection of classroom lessons to help biology teachers more effectively teach basic concepts. They were developed and tested during nine years of summer institutes by biology teachers from across the nation.

image.caption: Hominoid skulls
image.alttext: Each of 7 skulls is viewed from 4 different perspectives, offering greater variety of observations and measurement possibilities.

resource.title: Prehistoric Puzzles
resource.description: helps students investigate the prehistory of the African continent. The site includes learning modules on diet, subsistence, ceramic artifact analysis, and other topics.

image.caption: Agriculture
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Freedom: A Documentary History of Emancipation, 1861-1867
resource.description: recounts the personal experiences and the drama of emancipation in the words of the participants: liberated slaves and defeated slaveholders, soldiers and civilians, common folk and the elite, Northerners and Southerners.

image.caption: Free at last
image.alttext: 'Free at Last' makes available in a single volume the most moving and informative documents from the first four volumes of 'Freedom: A Documentary History of Emancipation.'

resource.title: Samuel Gompers Papers Project
resource.description: is a documentary editing project that collects, annotates, and makes available primary sources of American labor history. It includes microfilm, photocopied material, and annotation files for students and researchers.

publisher.name: University of Maryland Department of History

image.caption: Samuel Gompers
image.alttext: Samuel Gompers was president of the American Federation of Labor

resource.title: Multiwavelength Astronomy
resource.description: presents images of our own galaxy and sun, other galaxies and stars, and other heavenly bodies as viewed from different portions (or frequencies) of the electromagnetic spectrum.

image.caption: X-rays from the Cat's Eye
image.alttext: 'X-rays from the Cat's Eye,' Credits: NASA / X-ray: Y. Chu (UIUC) et al., Optical: J. P. Harrington, K. J. Borkowski (UMD), Composite: Z. Levay (STScI)

resource.title: Papers of Marcus Garvey and the Universal Negro Improvement Association
resource.description: offers information about the life of this black nationalist leader, who created a "Back to Africa" movement in the U.S.

image.caption: Commander in chief
image.alttext: Marcus Garvey as commander in chief of the Universal African Legion

resource.title: Kinetic City Cyber Club
resource.description: is the home of the Kinetic City Super Crew, a bunch of cool kids and their talkative supercomputer, ALEC. On board their super train, the Kinetic City Express, the Crew travel the world in a tireless quest for truth, justice, and the perfect deep-dish pizza.

image.caption: A touch of class
image.alttext: Games where users can classify various animals

resource.title: Center for Science and Engineering Education: Berkeley Lab
resource.description: provides a list of educational links related to science. Nuclear science, engineering, astronomy, genetics, particle physics, periodic table updates, and a virtual frog dissection kit are featured.

image.caption: Air pollution
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Amiens Cathedral Project
resource.description: presents a virtual tour of this gothic cathedral with interior and exterior photographs, drawings, computer graphics, and explanatory text.

image.caption: Computerized Amiens Cathedral
image.alttext: Computer graphics of Amiens Cathedral

resource.title: FoilSim: Basic Aerodynamics Software
resource.description: is an interactive simulation software that determines the airflow around various shapes of airfoils.

image.caption: Propulsion
image.alttext: A general derivation of the thrust equation shows that the amount of thrust generated depends on the mass flow through the engine and the exit velocity of the gas.

resource.title: LeRC K-12 Wind Tunnel Homepage
resource.description: offers information about wind tunnels. Learn how to build a wind tunnel, read about wind tunnel history, download flow-simulation software, view experiments for grades 8-12, and link to other wind tunnel websites

image.caption: Wind tunnels of NASA
image.alttext: Drawing of the 16-foot wind tunnel at Ames Research Center.

resource.title: The English Renaissance in Context
resource.description: offers a series of animated tutorials about some of Shakespeare's major plays.

image.caption: Hamlet
image.alttext: Act I, scene i, of 'Hamlet : a tragedy in five acts,' by William Shakespeare, as arranged for the stage by Henry Irving...

resource.title: UCLA Language Materials Project
resource.description: is committed to helping visitors locate teaching and learning materials for less commonly taught languages throughout the world, and makes over 3,500 resources covering 100 languages available. It is designed to help locate books, audio-cassettes, videos, and various multimedia packages that target individual teaching needs.

image.caption: Czech
image.alttext: Czech is spoken by about 12 million people, the majority of whom live in the Czech Republic where it is the official language.

resource.title: The Empire That Was Russia
resource.description: offers photographs of the Russian Empire on the eve of World War I and the coming revolution. Medieval churches and monasteries, railroads and factories, and daily life and work of Russia's diverse population are among the subjects. The photos were taken by Sergei Mikhailovich Prokudin-Gorskii (1863-1944), who, in the early 1900s, formulated a plan for a photographic survey of the Russian Empire that won the support of Tsar Nicholas II.

image.caption: Church of the Resurrection
image.alttext: Sergei Mikhailovich Prokudin-Gorskii. 'Church of the Resurrection in the Grove,' 1910.

resource.title: The Luso-Hispanic World In Maps
resource.description: includes maps created back to the early 16th century, when exploration and new discoveries brought the need for improved information about the world. The maps, most of which are hand drawn, depict portions of five continents and were prepared by cartographers from Spain, Portugal, France, Great Britain, the Netherlands, Latin America countries, and the U.S., among others. The maps represent different national and political interests and perspectives, at various periods of time.

image.caption: 17th century Dutch map
image.alttext: This 17th century Dutch map of the coasts of North America and South America extending from Virginia through the Yucatan Peninsula to Guyana in South America

resource.title: Project Oceanography
