resource.description: describes a marine science education program produced by the University of South Florida. It consists of weekly live television broadcasts to middle school students designed to enhance science education in middle schools and to contribute to staff development of science educators.

image.caption: Starfish
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Whelmer's
resource.description: presents 20 hands-on science activities intended to capture the imagination and spark curiosity.

image.caption: Density balloon
image.alttext: A mylar balloon is used to introduce the concept of density.

resource.title: African Voices
resource.description: explores the diversity of Africa's cultures and their influence on work, family, and community. Sculptures, textiles, interviews, proverbs, prayers, folk tales, and songs are included.

image.caption: Menelik II
image.alttext: Painting of Menelik II, Emperor of Ethiopia, leading troops against Italian forces

interestingfact.text: The Nile Valley gave birth to two great African civilizations: ancient Nubia to the south and Egypt to the north.

resource.title: Arctic Studies Center
resource.description: provides resources on museum exhibitions, including Viking expeditions, the Kennewick man controversy, masks and dances of the various Indian groups, and native animals.

image.caption: The Vikings
image.alttext: Image of a Viking longboad

resource.title: Mine Safety and Health Administration Kid's Page
resource.description: helps students, parents, and teachers understand how to prevent accidents at operating and abandoned mines. The site tells why mines are important and how minerals are essential to our health. It also presents historical accounts of how children were exploited as mine workers.

resource.title: At Home in the Heartland
resource.description: explores family life in Illinois from 1700 to the present and examines contributions of various cultural groups to the state. It includes maps, timelines, historical artifacts, and lesson plans for teachers Grades 3-12.

image.caption: Television, 1950
image.alttext: Image of 1950 TV, made by RCA Victor, Camden, NJ. Bristol Model, Wood, glass, metal

interestingfact.text: Catalogs can provide a wealth of information about the objects of everyday life found in many American homes. Catalogs illustrate prices, advertising methods, trends in purchasing and style, and can be used for actual object identification. In some cases catalogs show the length of time certain items were sold and used without changes in form. For example, almost identical irons are pictured in the Montgomery Ward catalog from 1872 until 1945.

resource.title: Anti-Railroad Propaganda Poster: The Growth of Regionalism, 1800-1860
resource.description: uses a poster decrying the disruptive influence of railroads on local culture to launch a discussion on local differences and their effect on American politics. Explanatory text, materials for teachers, and links to further resources accompany the documents. This lesson correlates to the National History Standards and the National Standards for Civics and Government. It also has cross-curricular connections with history, government, and art.

image.caption: Outrage!
image.alttext: Anti-railroad poster that says, 'Mothers look out for your children.' Implying that a train will run over a child.

resource.title: Images of the American Revolution
resource.description: focuses on the American Revolution, which encouraged the founding fathers' desire to create a government that would, as stated in the Preamble, insure domestic tranquility and provide for the common defense. This lesson correlates to the National History Standards and the National Standards for Civics and Government.

image.caption: Valley Forge -- Washington and Lafayette
image.alttext: Valley Forge -- Washington and Lafayette. Winter 1777-78. Copy of engraving by H. B. Hall after Alonzo Chappel. ARC Identifier: 532877

resource.title: Petition of Amelia Bloomer Regarding Suffrage in the West
resource.description: gives a facsimile of the handwritten petition of the suffragist, editor, and temperance leader. This lesson relates to the expression of First Amendment rights, including speech and petition, to the expansion of suffrage by means of the 19th Amendment, and to the amendment process described in Article V. This lesson correlates to the National History Standards and the National Standards for Civics and Government.

image.caption: Hope Webbing company employees
image.alttext: This photograph was taken c. 1918. It is of some of the employees of the Hope Webbing Company; all of whom are wearing bloomers.

resource.title: The Civil War as Photographed by Mathew Brady
resource.description: asks students to visualize the Civil War by studying dozens of period photographs, and illustrates how the Civil War threatened the very purpose of the Constitution as stated in the Preamble. This lesson correlates to the National History Standards and the National Standards for Civics and Government. It also has cross-curricular connections with history, American studies, and language arts.

image.caption: The 6th Maine Infantry on parade
image.alttext: A company of the 6th Maine Infantry on parade after the battle of Fredericksburg. ARC Identifier: 524587. At time of the charge across the stone wall at foot of Marye's Heights, General Joseph Hook

resource.title: Affidavit and Flyers from the Chinese Boycott Case
resource.description: introduces students to one instance in which immigrants overcame the ramifications of the Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882 through the U.S. judicial system. This lesson correlates to the National History Standards and National Standards for Civics and Government. It also has cross-curricular connections with history, government, language arts, and math.

image.caption: Labor union flyer
image.alttext: Labor Union Flyer -- National Archives and Records Administration, Records of the U.S. Circuit Courts. Record Group 21, ARC Identifier: 298113

resource.title: Letters, Telegrams, and Photographs Illustrating Factors That Affected the Civil War
resource.description: allows students to analyze a variety of documents to identify events, actions, and individuals who contributed to the Civil War's outcome. This lesson correlates to the National History Standards and the National Standards for Civics and Government. It also has cross-curricular connections with your history, government, and American literature.

image.caption: Saint Louis, ca.1862.
image.alttext: Photograph of the first ironclad gunboat built in America, the Saint Louis , ca.1862. ARC Identifier: 533123

resource.title: United States v. Thomas Cooper: A Violation of the Sedition Law
resource.description: presents facsimiles of 8 printed and hand-written documents surrounding the case of Thomas Cooper, a lawyer and newspaper editor in Sunbury, Pennsylvania, who was indicted, prosecuted, and convicted of violating the Sedition Act after he published a broadside in 1799 that sharply criticized President John Adams. The case is famous in the annals of the Bill of Right?s First Amendment. This lesson correlates to the National History Standards and the National Standards for Civics and Government.

image.caption: Newspaper broadside
image.alttext: Newspaper Broadside Filed in United States v. Thomas Cooper. Record Group 21, Records of the District Courts of the United States, National Archives and Records Administration. ARC Identifier: 278967

resource.title: Maps of Indian Territory, the Dawes Act, and Will Rogers' Enrollment Case File
resource.description: encourages students to study a variety of documents to understand the impact of a particular piece of legislation and relates to the powers granted to Congress in Article I, Section 8 , of the Constitution, related to making laws. It correlates to the National History Standards and the National Standards for Civics and Government. It also has cross-curricular connections with with history, government, global studies, and music.

image.caption: Oklahoma, 1885
image.alttext: Map of Indian Territory (Oklahoma), 1885. National Archives and Records Administration Records of the General Land Office, Record Group 49

resource.title: Alexander Graham Bell's Patent for the Telephone and Thomas Edison's Patent for the Electric Lamp
resource.description: introduces students to significant inventions of the late 19th century and examines the power of Congress to pass laws related to the granting of patents. It correlates to the National History Standards and the National Standards for Civics and Government. It also has cross-curricular connections with history, government, language arts, and science.

image.caption: Patent drawing
image.alttext: Thomas Edison's Electric Lamp Patent Drawing. Record Group 241. Records of the Patent and Trademark Office, National Archives and Records Administration, ARC Identifier: 302053

resource.title: Petition Signed by Thomas A. Edison for Sunday Openings at the World's Columbian Exposition
resource.description: focuses on petitioning the federal government, peaceably assembling, and exercising freedom of speech and religion, all of which are protected by the First Amendment to the Constitution. This lesson correlates to the National History Standards and the National Standards for Civics and Government.

image.caption: The documents
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Tally of the 1824 Electoral College Vote
resource.description: focuses on the complex system of election rules by examining the vote tally of the 1824 Presidential election, in which the winning candidate, John Quincy Adams, received fewer popular votes than the runner-up, Andrew Jackson.

image.caption: The documents
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Fugitive from Labor Cases: Henry Garnett and Moses Honner
resource.description: encourages students to analyze historic documents related to two fugitive slave cases and determine the impact events of the period 1850 to 1860 had on them. The Henry Garnett and Moses Honner cases demonstrates the political crisis in the 1850s arising over the issue of slavery and the necessity for the enactment of the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments to the U.S. Constitution. This lesson correlates to the National History Standards and the National Standards for Civics and Government.

image.caption: 1860 warrant for Moses Honner
image.alttext: Moses Honner, 1860 Warrant. ARC Identifier: 279023

resource.title: Photographs of Lewis Hine: Documentation of Child Labor
resource.description: encourages students to analyze dozens of photographs taken in the early 1900s depicting working conditions for child laborers. This lesson correlates to the National History Standards and the National Standards for Civics and Government. It has cross-curricular connections with history, government, language arts, and business law.

image.caption: Shoe-shining parlor
image.alttext: Boy Working in a Shoe-Shining Parlor, Indianapolis, IN. August 1908

resource.title: The Lewis and Clark Expedition
resource.description: presents 13 documents and photos related to the 1804-6 expedition into the newly acquired Louisiana Territory. The documents include a list of Indian presents Lewis purchased, his receipts for wine and tobacco, Jefferson's letter to Madison announcing the purchase of Louisiana, and Jefferson's message to Congress communicating the discoveries of the expedition.

image.caption: Indian petroglyphs
image.alttext: Close up of Indian petroglyphs mentioned in the journal of Lewis and Clark located on a limestone cliff at the mouth of the Nemaha River near Troy, Kansas, 1974. ARC Identifier: 557117

resource.title: The Sioux Treaty of 1868
resource.description: examines Native American sovereignty and the Constitutional power granted to the president and the Senate to make treaties with foreign nations. The site presents the Treaty and related documents, including a photograph of the Indian leader, Spotted Tail. Explanatory text, materials for teachers, and links to further resources accompany the documents.

image.caption: Spotted Tail
image.alttext: Image of Spotted Tail, a Brulé Sioux Chief of great renown

interestingfact.text: The Black Hills of Dakota are sacred to the Sioux Indians. In the 1868 treaty, signed at Fort Laramie and other military posts in Sioux country, the United States recognized the Black Hills as part of the Great Sioux Reservation, set aside for exclusive use by the Sioux people.

resource.title: The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo
resource.description: presents documents pertaining to the treaty that brought an official end to the Mexican-American War. Materials for teachers and links to other resources accompany the documents.

image.caption: The documents
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Eli Whitney's Patent for the Cotton Gin
resource.description: provides facsimile reproductions of the handwritten patent application and its accompanying drawing, together with explanatory text and lesson plans. This lesson correlates to the National History Standards and the National Standards for Civics and Government

image.caption: Drawing of cotton gin
image.alttext: Cotton Gin Patent Drawing

resource.title: Migration North to Alaska
resource.description: encourages students to use primary documents on Alaska to study topics related to the migration of people, ideas, and culture throughout history. It offers suggestions for projects that use the Archives' photographs, letters, drawings, and it highlights economic, social, and political factors that prompted thousands to migrate to Alaska.

image.caption: Klondike outfits at Dyea, 1898
image.alttext: Starting point for the trail to the Northern Gold Fields. National Archives and Records Administration, Donated Materials in the National Archives. D.L. Brainard's Picturesque Alaska

resource.title: National History Day
resource.description: tells beginning researchers how to navigate the vast primarysources holdings at the National Archives. Five activity worksheets provide step-by-step instructions on how to effectively find records.

resource.title: Teaching With Documents: Lesson Plans
resource.description: organizes primary documents into key periods of U.S. history: the Revolution, expansion and reform, the Civil War and Reconstruction, industrialization, the emergence of modern America, the Great Depression and World War II, postwar U.S., and contemporary U.S. It includes worksheets for analyzing various kinds of primary documents: written texts, artifacts, cartoons, maps, photos, posters, and recordings.

image.caption: Paul Robeson and Moore shipyard workers
image.alttext: Photograph of Paul Robeson Leading Moore Shipyard Workers in Singing the Star Spangled Banner. Oakland, CA, September 1942

resource.title: The Amistad Case
resource.description: presents documents produced around and during the historic 1841 trial of 53 Africans, captured and sold as slaves, and subsequently accused of murder for commandeering the slave ship, Amistad, and killing its captain and cook. The site also contains a detailed lesson plan.

image.caption: The first court proceedings
image.alttext: The Court ordered the immediate release of the Amistad Africans. The first court proceedings in the Amistad case took place in Hartford's Old State House.

resource.title: Building an Archives
resource.description: describes the adventure of acquiring, researching, and displaying important documents of the nation housed by the National Archives. The site also has a discussion of how students can start archives of their own schools. The neoclassical revival National Archives Building is located half-way between the White House and the Capitol on Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington, DC.

resource.title: Constitutional Issues: Separation of Powers
resource.description: explores the important Constitutional mechanism providing for the separation of powers of government among three branches so that each branch checks the other two. Lesson plans use the New Deal to help teach this concept.

image.caption: Statement by Frank E. Gannett
image.alttext: National Archives and Records Administration. Records of the Justice Department. Record Group 60

resource.title: Observing Constitution Day
resource.description: features a discussion about the Constitutional Convention and the Constitution. Lists of delegates, issues involved in the creation and ratification of the document, and its implementation are included.

image.caption: Signers of the Constitution
image.alttext: The Signers of the Constitution -- Image courtesy of Office of the Curator, Architect of the Capitol.

resource.title: The Don Henry Story: The Documents
resource.description: offers teaching activities using primary documents (tied to academic standards) on a student who became a leader in campus organizations, volunteered to fight in the Spanish Civil War with the Lincoln Brigade, and died on a battlefield in Aragon in September 1937.

resource.title: Little House in the Census: Almanzo and Laura Ingalls Wilder
resource.description: displays records from the 1880 and 1990 census schedules showing that Laura Ingalls, Almanzo Wilder, and families of the popular Little House on the Prairie series were not mere characters but were real people. Teaching activities are included to help students learn more about the census.

image.caption: Laura Ingalls Wilder
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: The U.S. Recognition of the State of Israel
resource.description: is a lesson plan on the history, conflicts, and U.S. involvement surrounding Israel before and after its proclamation of statehood. This lesson correlates to the National History Standards and the National Standards for World History. It also has cross-curricular connections with history, government, geography, and language arts.

image.caption: Israeli flag
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: The United States Enters the Korean Conflict
resource.description: features President Truman's statement, on June 27, 1950, announcing his order to send U.S. air and naval forces to help defend South Korea. Also included are teaching suggestions and links to hundreds of related documents from the Truman Presidential Library.

image.caption: Truman's statement
image.alttext: Statement, dated June 27, 1950, by President Harry S. Truman, announcing his order to send U.S. air and naval forces to help defend South Korea and explaining the rationale for his decision.

resource.title: Lincoln's Spot Resolutions
resource.description: provides background information and lessons (correlated to academic standards) that incorporate the use of textbooks, maps, and discussions based on primary documents such as the U.S. Constitution.

image.caption: President Lincoln
image.alttext: President Abraham Lincoln (ARC Identifier: 528389)

resource.title: The Unfinished Lincoln Memorial
resource.description: provides lessons that use photographs of the memorial of President Lincoln and other information for teaching students history, civics, and government. This lesson correlates to the National History Standards and the National Standards for Civics and Government.

resource.title: Powers of Persuasion -- Poster Art of World War II
resource.description: provides a standards-based lesson on how the use of posters during WWII helped win over the hearts and minds of the American people.

image.caption: We Can Do It!
image.alttext: Rosie the Riveter--the strong, competent woman dressed in overalls and bandanna--was introduced as a symbol of patriotic womanhood.

resource.title: History in the Raw
resource.description: discusses the importance of primary documents and uses them to illustrate historical concepts such as the subjective nature of written history, the intimate view of historical people's lives that primary documents can provide, and the importance of developing analytical skills when reconstructing history.

resource.title: Jackie Robinson: Beyond the Playing Field
resource.description: offers primary documents illustrating how this groundbreaking African American baseball player advocated for civil rights. It incorporates the material into lessons on civil rights history, character education, and civic responsibility.

image.caption: Jackie Robinson
image.alttext: Photo of Jackie Robinson

interestingfact.text: "Life is not a spectator sport. . . . If you're going to spend your whole life in the grandstand just watching what goes on, in my opinion you're wasting your life." -- Jackie Robinson

resource.title: The Fight for Equal Rights: Black Soldiers in the Civil War
resource.description: provides a lesson that uses primary documents such as the Emancipation Proclamation. This lesson correlates to the National History Standards and the National Standards for Civics and Government. It also has cross-curricular connections with history, government, and language arts.

image.caption: Sgt. Henry Stewart
image.alttext: Sgt. Henry Stewart, Company E, 54th Massachusetts Infantry. Courtesy of the Massachusetts Historical Society, Boston

resource.title: Constitutional Issues: Watergate and the Constitution
resource.description: examines Constitutional issues surrounding the resignation of President Nixon and looks at the specific question: Should the Watergate Special Prosecutor seek an indictment of the former President?

image.caption: President Nixon
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Woman Suffrage and the 19th Amendment
resource.description: looks at the 150th anniversary of the Seneca Falls Convention of 1848, features historical documents about woman suffrage, and a script that the National Archives commissioned about the decades long struggle for a woman's right to vote. The site includes teaching activities and a list of related websites.

image.caption: Kaiser Wilson poster
image.alttext: Photograph of Suffragist with 'Kaiser Wilson' Poster

resource.title: The Zimmermann Telegram
resource.description: is lesson plan aims to help students understand the causes of World War I and why the U.S. intervened. In January of 1917, British cryptographers deciphered a telegram from German Foreign Minister Arthur Zimmermann to the German Minister to Mexico, von Eckhardt, offering U.S. territory to Mexico in return for joining the German cause. This telegram helped draw the United States into the war.

image.caption: Decoded message
image.alttext: Zimmermann Telegram - Decoded Message. Record Group 59: General Records of the Department of State, 1756 - 1979. National Archives and Records Administration ARC Identifier 302022

resource.title: The Online Exhibit Hall
resource.description: presents information on the current live and online exhibitions at the National Archives. It features famous documents including the Emancipation Proclamation, the Marshall Plan, the Apollo 11 Flight Plan, and the Magna Carta.

image.caption: Be Patriotic poster
image.alttext: Original design for the 'Be Patriotic' poster, by Paul Stahr, ca. 1917-18. Gouache on paper, 27 7/8 x 20. Herbert Hoover Library, National Archives and Records Administration.

subject.subcategory: Other History & Social Studies: U.S. History Time Periods

resource.title: U.S. Electoral College
resource.description: provides information and statistics on presidential elections, past and present. For the 2004 election, it includes popular vote totals by state, Electoral College members, and state laws and requirements. It also offers past electoral results and an electoral college calculator.

image.caption: Presidential election results
image.alttext: Composite stylized image of 2004 Presidential Rlection with GOP and Dem images and hat.

interestingfact.text: Try your hand at predicting who will win the next presidential election. You can create your own election results by clicking on a different button in one of three columns. After you have made your selections, see your results.

resource.title: Genealogy
resource.description: describes the research facilities at the National Archives and offers online resources such as genealogical data and research guides, microform catalogs and finding aids, information on policy issues affecting genealogists, publication lists, schedules of workshops and courses, and links to other genealogical resources on the web.

image.caption: Army enlistment records
image.alttext: The AAD resource has 9.2 million records for enlistments in the Army, Enlisted Reserve Corps, and Women's Army Auxiliary Corps for the period 1938?1946.

resource.title: Inaugural Quiz
resource.description: challenges visitors to test their knowledge about inaugurations and presidential history with a 10 question quiz.

image.caption: The bicentennial inauguration
image.alttext: The Bicentennial Inauguration -- cover of the 1989 Bush inaugural dinner program.

interestingfact.text: Which President wore a ring to his inauguration that contained a lock of hair cut from Lincoln's head after he was shot?

resource.title: The Archival Research Catalog (ARC)
resource.description: is a searchable database of the cornerstone documents of our government. It has more than 126,000 digitized copies of the National Archives' most popular and significant manuscripts, photographs, maps, drawings and other documents.

image.caption: A woman welder
image.alttext: A woman welder at the Inglewood, California, plant of North American Aviation works on a sub-assembly for one of the huge tanks that go into B-25 bombers, October 1942 (ARC Identifier 196382)

subject.subcategory: Other History & Social Studies: U.S. History Time Periods

resource.title: Presidential Libraries
resource.description: provides an overview of the Presidential Library system. It also serves as a gateway to the websites of the repositories that preserve and make available the papers, records, and other historical materials of U.S. presidents since Herbert Hoover.

image.caption: Presidential libraries
image.alttext: Image of Bush Library located in College Station, Texas

interestingfact.text: The presidential library system is made up of eleven presidential libraries. Each presidential library contains a museum and provides an active series of public programs.

resource.title: The National Science Center
resource.description: offers a virtual tour of Fort Discovery, an interactive environment where you learn and experience technologies involved with communications, electronics, automation and computers. Visitors can also explore NSC resources for distance learning program opportunities, classroom lesson plans and project ideas, general facility information, special events and more.

resource.title: Park Geology Tour -- Geologic Features
resource.description: offers geologic field notes, maps, and photographs of the national parks. The site is organized around 14 thematic areas, such as fossils, plate tectonics, and volcanoes.

image.caption: Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore
image.alttext: The closer to Lake Michigan, the younger the feature, whether sand dune, wetland, or forest.

resource.title: Coffee Break
resource.description: is a collection of short reports on recent biological discoveries. Each report is about 400 words, and is based on a discovery recently published peer-reviewed literature. It incorporates interactive tutorials that show how "bioinformatics" tools are used as a part of the research process. Past topics include how salmonella gains entry into human cells, new clues on Alzheimer's pathology, how living organisms tune in to the time of day, and many more.

image.caption: Freshness date
image.alttext: Do brains have a freshness date? the effect of aging on the human brain

resource.title: The Collection of the National Gallery of Art
resource.description: is the homepage for one of the finest art collections in the world, illustrating major achievements in painting, sculpture, and graphic arts from the Middle Ages to today. Visitors can search the collection by specific artist, title, or a combination of criteria, review research on the Gallery's World War II paintings, tour the collection by medium and school, or download a Gallery Guide in English, French, German, Italian, or Spanish.

image.caption: View of Dordrecht from the Dordtse Kil
image.alttext: Jan van Goyen, Dutch, 1596 - 1656. 'View of Dordrecht from the Dordtse Kil,' 1644. Oil on panel, 64.7 x 95.9 cm (25 x 37 3/4 in.). Ailsa Mellon Bruce Fund, 1978.11.1.

interestingfact.text: Throughout the twentieth century, artists in the vanguard have repeatedly challenged convention by exploring new avenues of expression and seeking alternative forms to embody new ideas. In the early years of the century, the so-called fauve artists ("wild beasts") in France, led by Henri Matisse, experimented with vivid, highly saturated colors and bold brushwork to evoke intense emotional responses.

resource.title: A Design for the East Building
resource.description: presents drawings by the architect I.M. Pei and his design team for the National Gallery's East Building, which opened to the public in 1978.

image.caption: Scale model
image.alttext: Scale model of East and West Buildings showing early design for Third Street facade, spring 1971

resource.title: East Building Architectural Tour
resource.description: shows several photographs and accompanying discussion of the East Building of the National Gallery of Art, which opened in 1978. The tour is centered around the architectural features of the building itself rather than the artworks exhibited.

image.caption: Spiral staircase
image.alttext: East Building, spiral staircase to one of the tower galleries. Photograph Lyle Peterzell, Department of Imaging and Visual Services, National Gallery of Art

resource.title: East Building Virtual Tour
resource.description: allows multiple zooming-ins and navigation around and inside the East Building of the National Gallery of Art, which opened in 1978.

image.caption: Atrium
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Selections from the 20th-Century Collections
resource.description: showcases prominent pieces of art by Pablo Picasso, Georgia O'Keeffe, Jackson Pollock, Mark Rothko, Andy Warhol, David Smith, and Alexander Calder.

image.caption: Family of Saltimbanques -- details
image.alttext: Pablo Picasso, Spanish, 1881 - 1973, 'Family of Saltimbanques,' 1905. oil on canvas, 212.8 x 229.6 cm (83 3/4 x 90 3/8 in.) Chester Dale Collection

resource.title: The Gallery's American Collection Online
resource.description: features American paintings from the late 1700s-1900s. Included are works by John Copley, Henry Tanner, John Sargent, James Whistler, Gilbert Stuart, and more. Much art of the American colonial period consisted of portraits, as settlers sought to establish their identities in a new world. After the new nation achieved its independence, landscapes and scenes of native flora, fauna, and folk customs began to express its unique qualities and illustrate its untapped resources.

image.caption: Cattleya Orchid and Three Brazilian Hummingbirds
image.alttext: Martin Johnson Heade, 'Cattleya Orchid and Three Brazilian Hummingbirds,' 1871. Gift of The Morris and Gwendolyn Cafritz Foundation, 1982.73.1

resource.title: Selections from Audubon's The Birds of America (1827-1838)
resource.description: shows 34 paintings from John James Audubon's "The Birds of America," one of the greatest picture books ever produced.

image.caption: Louisiana Heron
image.alttext: Robert Havell [American, 1793 - 1878], Louisiana Heron, 1834, hand-colored etching and aquatint on Whatman paper. Gift of Mrs. Walter B. James.

resource.title: Mary Cassatt -- The Color Prints, 1889-1894
resource.description: tours 12 pieces by an artist who was one of the few Americans to work in the 19th century French avante-garde style. Cassatt is well known for her perceptive depictions of women and children.

image.caption: Afternoon Tea Party
image.alttext: Mary Cassatt, American, 1844 - 1926. 'Afternoon Tea Party,' 1890-1891. drypoint, aquatint, and gold paint on laid paper, plate: 34.77 x 26.35 cm (13 11/16 x 10 3/8 in.)

resource.title: Northern European Painting of the 15th-16th Centuries
resource.description: explores the paintings (and accompanying texts) to holdings at the National Gallery of Art. The Gallery states that "the 15th and 16th centuries saw the rise of capitalism and a burgeoning middle class, the creation of modern nation states, and the upheaval of the Protestant Reformation. For artists, an innovation of equally far-reaching importance was the perfection of oil paints in the Low Countries, which allowed northern painters to depict the world with unprecedented precision.

image.caption: Ill-Matched Lovers
image.alttext: Quentin Massys, Netherlandish, c. 1465/1466 - 1530, 'Ill-Matched Lovers,' c. 1520/1525. oil on panel, 43.2 x 63 cm (17 x 24 13/16 in.) Ailsa Mellon Bruce Fund, 1971.55.1

resource.title: French Renaissance Ceramics
resource.description: tours three 16th century objects made of the rare "Saint-Porchaire" ware, which is recognized by its richly patterned layer of colorful paste decoration inlaid into a "clay skin." Read what's know about the unique Saint-Porchaire process and view these mysterious Renaissance ceramics.

image.caption: Salt -- details
image.alttext: French 16th Century, probably Saint-Porchaire (Deux-Sevres). 'Salt,' c. 1540/1560. Widener Collection -- 1942.9.353

resource.title: The French Painting Collection
resource.description: presents French paintings from the 19th century. The site includes paintings from the "academic" style that dominated the first half of the century as well as paintings from the latter half of the century by artists who came to be known as impressionists -- Edouard Manet, Camille Pissarro, Vincent Van Gogh, Paul Cezanne, Claude Monet, and Mary Cassatt.

image.caption: Mounted Trumpeters of Napoleon's Imperial Guard -- details
image.alttext: Théodore Gericault, 'Mounted Trumpeters of Napoleon's Imperial Guard,' 1813/1814. Chester Dale Fund, 1972.25.1

resource.title: Works on Paper from the Edgar William and Bernice Chrysler Garbisch Collection
resource.description: features a once privately-held collection of 19th century American paintings.

resource.title: Byzantine Art and Painting in Italy
resource.description: tours Italian Byzantine paintings of the 1200s and 1300s. The site includes an overview of the genre, historical background, and information on the featured artists, the paintings, their provenance, a bibliography, exhibition history, and full-screen images.

image.caption: The Calling of Peter and Andrew -- details
image.alttext: Duccio di Buoninsegna, Sienese, c. 1255 - 1318. 'The Calling of the Apostles Peter and Andrew,' 1308/1311, tempera on panel, 43.5 x 46 cm (17 1/8 x 18 1/8 in.) Samuel H. Kress Collection -- 1939.1.

resource.title: Venetian Painting in the Early Renaissance
resource.description: offers seven paintings from the last quarter century of the 1400s. In the mid-1400s, Venice was the most powerful city in Italy but by the end of the fifteenth century the city's fortunes had begun to change. Venetian artists nevertheless maintained their prestige, legendary splendor, and international reputation. Grounding their art in the senses, they appealed to the eye and the spirit through brilliant color, glowing light, and the beauties of nature.

image.caption: Saint Jerome Reading -- details
image.alttext: Giovanni Bellini, Venetian, c. 1430/1435 - 1516. 'Saint Jerome Reading,' 1505, oil on panel, painted surface: 47 x 37.5 cm (18 1/2 x 14 3/4 in.) Samuel H. Kress Collection -- 1939.1.217

resource.title: Giorgione and the High Renaissance in Venice
resource.description: presents seven paintings by this influential painter (1500-20) and others whose work marks the beginning of the Venetian High Renaissance. Giorgione introduced new subjects (mythological scenes and pastorals) and several technical innovations.

image.caption: Portrait of a Venetian Gentleman -- details
image.alttext: Giorgione and Titian, 'Portrait of a Venetian Gentleman,' c. 1510. Samuel H. Kress Collection -- 1939.1.258

resource.title: Raphael
resource.description: features paintings that epitomize the artists' High Renaissance style. Tracing the process by which he transformed the fifteenth-century style of his earliest teachers into something new and of enduring influence.

image.caption: Saint George and the Dragon -- details
image.alttext: Raphael, 'Saint George and the Dragon,' c. 1506. Andrew W. Mellon Collection -- 1937.1.26

resource.title: Mannerism
resource.description: offers seven Italian paintings covering 1520-40, the period just after the popular High Renaissance. This period is known for its emphasis on self-conscious artifice over realistic depiction.

image.caption: A Young Woman and Her Little Boy -- details
image.alttext: Agnolo Bronzino, Florentine, 1503 - 1572. 'A Young Woman and Her Little Boy,' c. 1540, oil on panel, 99.5 x 76 cm (39 1/8 x 29 7/8 in.) Widener Collection -- 1942.9.6

resource.title: Venice and the North
resource.description: examines some of the works that were painted by artists from northern Italy, areas in modern-day Lombardy and the Veneto that were largely under Venetian control in the sixteenth century. In Lombardy in particular, patrons and painters shared a preference for detailed, realistic works. In part this may reflect the conservatism of provincial buyers who were unfamiliar with sophisticated and "progressive" urban styles, or it may simply express a more rural sensibility.

image.caption: A Concert -- details
image.alttext: Cariani, 'A Concert,' c. 1518-1520. Bequest of Lore Heinemann in memory of her husband, Dr. Rudolf J. Heinemann -- 1997.57.2

resource.title: Titian and the Late Renaissance in Venice
resource.description: features seven paintings by Titian (Tiziano Vecellio), the preeminent artist among Venetian painters during the 16th century. At the time (1540), Venice reigned as one of the most powerful city-states in Europe, and Venetian painters assumed a position of artistic supremacy in Europe that they would occupy for the rest of the century.

image.caption: Saint John on Patmos -- details
image.alttext: Titian, Venetian, c. 1490 - 1576. 'Saint John the Evangelist on Patmos,' c. 1547, oil on canvas, 237.6 x 263 cm (93 1/2 x 103 1/2 in.) Samuel H. Kress Collection -- 1957.14.6

resource.title: The Italian Cabinet Galleries
resource.description: contains paintings and precious objects similar to those found in the private chambers or studies of Italian Renaissance princes, humanists or wealthy merchants. Most small finely detailed objects like paintings, bronzes, gems, coins, medals, rock crystal vessels, clocks, arms, ivory carvings and maiolica dishes, were meant to be handled and admired at close range. Many of the objects reflect the Renaissance fascination with classical Greece and Rome.

image.caption: Venus and Cupid in a Landscape
image.alttext: 'Venus and Cupid in a Landscape,' Circle of Giorgione, c. 1505/1515. Samuel H. Kress Collection.

resource.title: Fresco Cycle with the Story of Procris and Cephalus
resource.description: offers nine frescoes depicting the mythological tale of Princess Procris and Prince Cephalus of Attica, a story of wedded bliss ravaged by distrust found in Book VII of the Metamorphoses by the ancient Roman poet Ovid (43 B.C.-A.D. 17). These nine paintings by Bernardino Luini are the only examples of an Italian Renaissance fresco series in America. Visitors can learn about the artist, the fresco technique, and more.

image.caption: The Despair of Cephalus -- Details
image.alttext: Bernardino Luini, 'The Despair of Cephalus,' c. 1520/1522. Samuel H. Kress Collection, 1943.4.58

resource.title: Venetian Painting in the Later Sixteenth Century
resource.description: shows seven paintings by the three most important challengers -- Jacopo Tintoretto, Veronese, Jacopo -- to Titian's dominance over Venetian art in the 16th century.

image.caption: Rebecca at the Well -- details
image.alttext: Veronese, Venetian, 1528 - 1588. 'Rebecca at the Well,' 1580/1585, oil on canvas, 145.5 x 282.7 cm (57 1/4 x 111 1/4 in.) Samuel H. Kress Collection -- 1952.5.82

resource.title: El Greco
resource.description: was a Greek-born artist whose emotional style vividly expressed the passion of Counter-Reformation Spain. The exhibit showcases the most important collection of his work outside his adopted home of Spain. El Greco's "manneristic"style paintings featured elongated figures and strong contrasts of color and light.

image.caption: Saint Ildefonso -- details
image.alttext: El Greco (Domenikos Theotokopoulos), Spanish, 1541 - 1614, 'Saint Ildefonso,' c. 1603/1614. oil on canvas, 112 x 65.8 cm (44 1/8 x 25 7/8 in.) Andrew W. Mellon Collection -- 1937.1.83

resource.title: Painting in Siena in the 14th and Early 15th Centuries National Gallery of Art
resource.description: tours 10 paintings distinctive for their linear and decorative style. The painters used gold and strong color to create pattern and rhythm.

image.caption: Joachim and the Beggars -- details
image.alttext: Andrea di Bartolo, 'Joachim and the Beggars,' c. 1400. Samuel H. Kress Collection -- 1939.1.43

resource.title: Spanish Painting in the Seventeenth Century
resource.description: looks at seven paintings from what has been called the "Golden Age of Spanish Painting." The paintings are described in detail, and full-screen images are available.

image.caption: The Needlewoman -- details
image.alttext: Diego Velázquez, 'The Needlewoman,' c. 1640/1650. Andrew W. Mellon Collection -- 1937.1.81

resource.title: Seventeenth-Century French Painting
resource.description: showcases pictures from about 1626 to 1653. Leading French painters of the period traveled to Rome, where they were influenced by contemporary Italian artists as well as High Renaissance masters and classical antiquity. In this age of the monarchs Louis XIII and Louis XIV, French tastes stressed rationality, order, and idealization rather than realism or natural life.

image.caption: Omer Talon -- details
image.alttext: Philippe de Champaigne, 'Omer Talon,' 1649. Samuel H. Kress Collection -- 1952.5.35

resource.title: The Emergence of New Genres
resource.description: exhibits six Italian paintings of the late 16th and early 17th centuries that show the establishment of landscape, still life, and genre paintings as subjects worthy of attention by the finest artists for the first time since antiquity. (Genre scenes are realistic depictions of ordinary people and everyday activities.) The site describes each painting in detail, and full-screen images can be downloaded.

image.caption: Still Life with Fruit and Carafe -- details
image.alttext: Pensionante del Saraceni, Roman, active c. 1610/1620. 'Still Life with Fruit and Carafe,' c. 1610/1620, oil on canvas, 50.4 x 71.6 cm (19 7/8 x 28 3/8 in.) Samuel H. Kress Collection -- 1939.1.159

resource.title: Netherlandish Painting in the 1400s
resource.description: tours eight small versions of the painted panels found in church altarpieces for use in private devotions at home. The panels, produced by artists from France, Germany, and the Low Countries between about 1400 and 1550, depicted the lives and possessions of middle class people.

image.caption: Saint Veronica -- details
image.alttext: Hans Memling, Netherlandish, active c. 1465 - 1494. 'Saint Veronica,' obverse, c. 1470/1475. oil on panel, painted surface: 30.3 x 22.8 cm (11 15/16 x 9 in.) Samuel H. Kress Collection -- 1952.5.4

resource.title: The Early Renaissance in Florence
resource.description: tours 8 paintings by Italian masters including Filippo Lippi and Fra Angelico. The artwork reflects the humanistic outlook and mastery of perspective and light that defined Renaissance art. The site contains full-screen images, bibliographies, and the provenances of the paintings.

image.caption: The Feast of Herod -- details
image.alttext: Benozzo Gozzoli, Florentine, c. 1421 - 1497. 'The Feast of Herod and the Beheading of Saint John the Baptist,' 1461-1462. tempera (?) on panel, 23.8 x 34.5 cm (9 3/8 x 13 9/16 in.)Samuel H. Kress

resource.title: Netherlandish and Spanish Altarpieces
resource.description: looks at five paintings commissioned by Ferdinand and Isabel of Spain for Spanish churches or convents. Because they worked for the glory of the monarchy and the Church, the artists worked anonymously and their identities are a subject of research.

image.caption: The Marriage at Cana -- details
image.alttext: Master of the Catholic Kings Castilian, active c. 1485/1500. 'The Marriage at Cana,' c. 1495/1497, oil on panel, original painted surface: 137.1 x 92.7 cm (54 x 36 1/2 in.) Samuel H. Kress Collect

resource.title: Antwerp in the Early 1500s
resource.description: tours seven paintings from an era when Antwerp was the mercantile center of Europe. The new wealth created during this time served as a magnet for artists who wanted to experiment with new styles and subject matter. The site offers full screen images, bibliographies, exhibition histories, and conservation notes for the works.

image.caption: The Temptation of Saint Anthony -- details
image.alttext: Follower of Pieter Bruegel the Elder, 'The Temptation of Saint Anthony,' c. 1550/1575. Samuel H. Kress Collection -- 1952.2.19

resource.title: Sir Anthony Van Dyck
resource.description: shows paintings and descriptions of the National Gallery of Art's holdings of the famous Flemish painter. According to the Gallery, "With elaborate settings, symbolic accessories, and suggestions of movement, Van Dyck made his models seem at once grand and alive, inaugurating a style of formal portraiture that is still emulated today.

image.caption: Susanna Fourment and Her Daughter -- details
image.alttext: Sir Anthony van Dyck, Flemish, 1599 - 1641. 'Susanna Fourment and Her Daughter,' 1621, oil on canvas, 172 x 117 cm (67 11/16 x 46 1/16 in.) Andrew W. Mellon Collection -- 1937.1.48

resource.title: Sir Peter Paul Rubens
resource.description: was an artist, diplomat, linguist, and scholar. His style -- rich texture, vivid color, and lively movement -- has influenced Western art to the present day. The exhibit looks at his innovative use of small oil studies and models for his work and examines how he influenced the Baroque style and many other budding young artists. It includes eight paintings of scenes from Greek and Biblical stories.

image.caption: Deborah Kip ... and Her Children -- details
image.alttext: Sir Peter Paul Rubens (and possibly Jacob Jordaens) 'Deborah Kip, Wife of Sir Balthasar Gerbier, and Her Children,' 1629/1630, reworked probably mid 1640s. Andrew W. Mellon Fund -- 1971.18.1

resource.title: Frans Hals
resource.description: was a leading portraitist in 17th century Haarlem, a Dutch city. This exhibit examines his style and technique and provides a timeline of his life, and features Hal's famous portraits of civic guards and of the directors of charitable institutions in 17th Haarlem.

image.caption: Willem Coymans -- details
image.alttext: Frans Hals, Dutch, c. 1582/1583 - 1666. 'Willem Coymans,' 1645, oil on canvas, 77 x 64 cm (30 1/4 x 25 in.) Andrew W. Mellon Collection -- 1937.1.69

resource.title: Dutch Still Lifes and Landscapes of the 1600s
resource.description: looks at Dutch paintings that focused on the natural world. Paintings depicting aspects of the natural world were so characteristic of the Netherlands that, during the 17th century, the Dutch words stilleven and landscape were adopted into English as "still life" and "landscape."

image.caption: Lady and Gentleman on Horseback -- details
image.alttext: Aelbert Cuyp, Dutch, 1620 - 1691. 'Lady and Gentleman on Horseback,' c. 1655, reworked 1660/1665, oil on canvas, 123 x 172 cm (48 1/2 x 67 3/4 in.) Widener Collection -- 1942.9.15

resource.title: Dutch Landscapes and Seascapes of the 1600s
resource.description: look at Dutch depictions of city and countryside, both real and imaginary. The Dutch valued seascapes and insisted on accurate renderings. Genre incidents from everyday life animate most Dutch landscapes and seascapes, and there was an emphasis on ocean air and sun glowing through the ever-present clouds.

image.caption: A Scene on the Ice -- details
image.alttext: Hendrick Avercamp, 'A Scene on the Ice,' c. 1625. Ailsa Mellon Bruce Fund -- 1967.3.1

resource.title: Johannes Vermeer and Dutch Scenes of Daily Life in the 1600s
resource.description: tours eight paintings depicting everyday scenes. They are typical of "genre" paintings from this period, which marks the emergence of Dutch national identity. Vermeer's specialty was painting quiet middle-class households. The site presents the images, their exhibition history, bibliographies, and conservation notes.

image.caption: The Dancing Couple -- details
image.alttext: Jan Steen, 'The Dancing Couple,' 1663. Widener Collection -- 1942.9.81

resource.title: Francisco de Goya
resource.description: was one of Spain's greatest painters and an internationally influential printmaker during the late 18th and early 19th centuries. In 1774, Goya received his first royal commission -- painting decorative scenes of daily life to be woven into tapestries. In 1799 he was appointed first court painter, the highest artistic position attainable.

image.caption: María Teresa de Borbón y Vallabriga -- details
image.alttext: Francisco de Goya, 'María Teresa de Borbón y Vallabriga, later Condesa de Chinchón,' 1783. Ailsa Mellon Bruce Collection -- 1970.17.123

resource.title: Chardin and Portraiture
resource.description: showcases an artist who was called the "great magician" for his still lifes and scenes of everyday activity. Jean Siméon Chardin was a member of the Royal Academy who painted figures, mostly women and children, engaged in simple acts of middle-class life. His treatment of the domestic world?contemplative and self-contained?was unprecedented in France and take on the quality of still life.

image.caption: Soap Bubbles -- details
image.alttext: Jean Siméon Chardin, French, 1699 - 1779. 'Soap Bubbles,' probably 1733/1734, oil on canvas, 93 x 74.6 cm (36 5/8 x 29 3/8 in.) Gift of Mrs. John W. Simpson -- 1942.5.1

resource.title: The Rococo and Watteau
resource.description: features the work of Antoine Watteau, who experimented with the ingredients of rococo -- emphasizing color, a lighthearted approach, and close observation -- and developed a new, free, delicate painting technique that captured the pleasure-seeking spirit of the early 18th century.

image.caption: Diana and Endymion -- details
image.alttext: Jean-Honoré Fragonard, French, 1732 - 1806. 'Diana and Endymion,' c. 1753/1755, oil on canvas, 95 x 137 cm (37 3/8 x 53 7/8 in.) Timken Collection -- 1960.6.2

resource.title: Boucher and Fragonard
resource.description: looks at two painters who came to prominence during the Enlightenment in Europe. They worked in the rococco style. Boucher was also the principal designer for Sèvres porcelain and the Beauvais tapestry works.

image.caption: The Old Bridge -- detail
image.alttext: Hubert Robert, French, 1733 - 1808, 'The Old Bridge,' probably c. 1775. oil on canvas, 91.3 x 121 cm (35 7/8 x 47 5/8 in.). Samuel H. Kress Collection -- 1952.5.50

resource.title: Neoclassicism
resource.description: is an exhibit that features the works of French artists who painted in the time of Napoleon. With the revolution, French painting resumed its moral and political purpose and embraced the style known as neoclassicism. After 1789, artists increasingly sought noble themes of public virtue and personal sacrifice from the history of ancient Greece or Rome.

image.caption: David Johnston -- details
image.alttext: Pierre Paul Prud'hon, French, 1758 - 1823. 'David Johnston,' 1808, oil on canvas, 54.6 x 46.4 cm (21 1/2 x 18 1/4 in.) Samuel H. Kress Collection -- 1961.9.84

resource.title: Constable and Turner: British Landscapes of the Early 1800s
resource.description: features two landscape painters who were influential champions of romanticism, an artisticmovement of the late 1700s to mid-1800s that emphasized an emotional response to nature. Turner often infused his dramatic seascapes and landscapes with literary or historical allusions and blended his oil paints in fluid layers of translucent color, called glazes. Constable, preferred more straightforward depictions of placid rural scenery in thick, opaque oils.

image.caption: Rotterdam Ferry-Boat -- details
image.alttext: Joseph Mallord William Turner, British, 1775 - 1851, 'Rotterdam Ferry-Boat,' 1833, oil on canvas, 92.3 x 122.5 cm (36 3/8 x 48 1/4 in.) Ailsa Mellon Bruce Collection -- 1970.17.135

resource.title: Britain's Royal Academy of Art in the Late 1700s and Early 1800s
resource.description: features artists in this elite English society. For more than a century, London's Royal Academy established the highest cultural standards in the English-speaking world. It trained young artists, mounted exhibitions to display works to fellow artists, critics, and collectors, and presented lectures and published catalogues to elevate public taste. The academy's members included Sir Joshua Reynolds, the portraitist Thomas Gainsborough, and the landscapist Richard Wilson.

image.caption: Mrs. Alexander Blair -- details
image.alttext: George Romney, British, 1734 - 1802. 'Mrs. Alexander Blair,' 1787-1789, oil on canvas, 127 x 101.5 cm (50 x 40 in.) Widener Collection -- 1942.9.77

resource.title: British and American Grand Manner Portraits of the 1700s
resource.description: looks at works in the "Grand Manner" or "Great Style." The terms are used to describe paintings that used visual metaphors. The Grand Manner came to include portraiture?especially at full length and in life size?accompanied by settings and accessories that conveyed the dignified status of the sitters. Classical architecture, for instance, signified one's civilized demeanor, and whole woodland glens implied natural sincerity.

image.caption: The Frankland Sisters -- details
image.alttext: John Hoppner, British, 1758 - 1810. 'The Frankland Sisters,' 1795, oil on canvas, 155 x 125 cm (61 x 49 1/4 in.) Andrew W. Mellon Collection -- 1937.1.111

resource.title: Gilbert Stuart: Works
resource.description: portrayed virtually all the notable men and women of the Federal period in the U.S., and was declared the "Father of American Portraiture" by his contemporaries. Stuart portrayed American and European figures, including George Washington, John and Abigail Adams, John Jay, and Robert Liston. In 1805 he painted the Gibbs-Coolidge Set, the only surviving depiction of the first five presidents.

image.caption: Abigail Smith Adams -- details
image.alttext: Gilbert Stuart, American, 1755 - 1828. 'Abigail Smith Adams (Mrs. John Adams),' 1800/1815, oil on canvas, 73.4 x 59.7 cm (28 7/8 x 23 1/2 in.) Gift of Mrs. Robert Homans -- 1954.7.2

resource.title: Gilbert Stuart: Paints the First Five Presidents
resource.description: looks at the Gibbs-Coolidge paintings, the only surviving complete set of portraits depicting the first five U.S. presidents. Commissioned by Colonel George Gibbs of Rhode Island, it was painted in Boston during the last phase of Stuart's career. The set descended through four generations of the Coolidge family.

image.caption: John Adams -- details
image.alttext: Gilbert Stuart, American, 1755 - 1828. 'John Adams,' c. 1821, oil on wood, 66 x 54.5 cm (26 x 21 1/2 in.) Ailsa Mellon Bruce Fund -- 1979.4.1

resource.title: John Singleton Copley
resource.description: features one of the foremost artists in colonial America. Virtually self-taught as a portraitist, he created powerful characterizations of his Boston sitters. After he emigrated to London in 1774, Copley began to specialize in narrative scenes from history and joined the influential artistic institution, the Royal Academy of Art. Copley demonstrated a genius, in both his American and British periods, for rendering surface textures and capturing emotional immediacy.

image.caption: The Red Cross Knight -- details
image.alttext: John Singleton Copley, American, 1738 - 1815. 'The Red Cross Knight,' 1793, oil on canvas, 213.5 x 273 cm (84 x 107 1/2 in.) Gift of Mrs. Gordon Dexter -- 1942.4.2

resource.title: British and American History Paintings of the 1700s
resource.description: feature works that imaginatively re-create historical events. "History paintings" also illustrated heroic or moralizing episodes from religion, mythology, and literature. In depicting significant events that appealed to the conscience, history painting earned its reputation as a demanding and rewarding form of art?both for the creator and the viewer.

image.caption: The Corinthian Maid -- details
image.alttext: Joseph Wright, British, 1734 - 1797. 'The Corinthian Maid,' 1782-1784, oil on canvas, 106.3 x 130.8 cm (41 7/8 x 51 1/2 in.) Paul Mellon Collection -- 1983.1.46

resource.title: American Portraits of the Late 1700s and Early 1800s
resource.description: features paintings by Charles Willson Peale, Mather Brown, Thomas Sully, Edward Savage, and others. The site includes information on the pieces' provenances, exhibition histories, and related bibliographies.

image.caption: Lady with a Harp: Eliza Ridgely -- details
image.alttext: Thomas Sully, American, 1783 - 1872. 'Lady with a Harp: Eliza Ridgely,' 1818, oil on canvas, 214.5 x 142.5 cm (84 7/16 x 56 1/8 in.) Gift of Maude Monell Vetlesen -- 1945.9.1

resource.title: British Conversation Pieces and Portraits of the 1700s
resource.description: presents six "conversation" scenes, including informal group portraits as well as imaginary views of daily life. Pictures were commissioned by families or friends to portray them sharing common activities such as hunts, meals, or musical parties.

image.caption: Portrait of a Gentleman -- details
image.alttext: Joseph Wright, British, 1734 - 1797. 'Portrait of a Gentleman,' c. 1770-1773, oil on canvas, 128 x 102 cm (50 3/8 x 40 1/8 in.) Andrew W. Mellon Collection -- 1940.1.11

resource.title: Whistler, Sargent, and Tanner -- Americans Abroad in the Late 1800s
resource.description: shows several paintings of three American painters who not only studied abroad but chose to remain abroad. The paintings are described in detail, and full-screen images can be downloaded.

image.caption: Street in Venice -- details
image.alttext: John Singer Sargent, American, 1856 - 1925. 'Street in Venice,' 1882, oil on wood, 45.1 x 53.9 cm (17 3/4 x 21 1/4 in.) Gift of the Avalon Foundation -- 1962.4.1

resource.title: Patrons and Artists in Late 15th-Century Florence
resource.description: tours eight paintings from one of the greatest art centers in the history of Western culture.

image.caption: The Triumph of Camillus -- details
image.alttext: Biagio d'Antonio and Workshop, detail: 'The Triumph of Camillus,' c. 1470/1475. Samuel H. Kress Collection -- 1939.1.153

resource.title: American Impressionists of the Late 1800s and Early 1900s
resource.description: offers seven paintings that help show how the invention of collapsible tin tubes to hold premixed oil paints (John Rand, 1841) freed the artist to leave the studio and explore the subject matter first-hand. The Americans built on the masterful work done by French impressionists, but focused on different subjects.

image.caption: Mother and Mary -- details
image.alttext: Edmund Charles Tarbell, American, 1862 - 1938. 'Mother and Mary,' 1922, oil on canvas, 112.1 x 127.5 cm (44 1/8 x 50 3/16 in.) Gift of the Belcher Collection, Stoughton, Massachusetts -- 1967.1.1

resource.title: Romantics and Realists
resource.description: compares and contrasts the romantic and realists schools through seven French paintings (1812-1875). The romantic movement, according to poet Charles Baudelaire, was "a manner of feeling." The realists, in the next generation, were guided by observation and the idea that "painting is an essentially concrete art."

image.caption: Christopher Columbus ... at La Rábida -- details
image.alttext: Eugène Delacroix, French, 1798 - 1863. 'Christopher Columbus and His Son at La Rábida,' 1838, oil on canvas, 90.3 x 118 cm (35 1/2 x 46 1/2 in.) Chester Dale Collection -- 1963.10.127

resource.title: Selected African American Artists
resource.description: presents several works by African American artists such as Romare Bearden, Willie Cole, and Sam Gilliam.

image.caption: Tree
image.alttext: Bob Thompson, American, 1937 - 1966. 'Tree,' 1962, oil on canvas, 198.6 x 274.8 cm (78 3/16 x 108 3/16 in.) Collection of Barney A. Ebsworth -- 2000.39.3

resource.title: Selected Photographs from the Collection
resource.description: offers six photographs that celebrate some recent additions to the Gallery's growing collection. These photos suggest that great photographers do not simply record the world; they transform it.

image.caption: Vanderbilt Avenue
image.alttext: Berenice Abbott, 'Vanderbilt Avenue from East 46th Street,' October 9, 1935. Gift of Marvin Breckinridge Patterson and Anonymous Gift -- 1998.65.1

resource.title: Marble Sculpture from France
resource.description: tours seven sculptures representing 250 years of French history, from before the birth of Louis XIV to the Second Empire. Both artistic styles and the sources of patronage changed dramatically during these years. The online exhibit offers an analysis of the social environment of the times and how it influenced subject matter and styles.

image.caption: Painting and Sculpture -- details
image.alttext: Jean-Pierre-Antoine Tassaert, French, 1727 - 1788, 'Painting and Sculpture,' 1774/1778. marble, 98.3 x 87.2 x 63.8 cm (38 5/8 x 34 1/4 x 25 1/8 in.) Samuel H. Kress Collection -- 1952.5.110

resource.title: Winslow Homer Watercolors -- A Survey of Themes and Styles
resource.description: presents a sampling of the artists' paintings with descriptions of the artistic and cultural elements of the works.

image.caption: The Milk Maid -- details
image.alttext: Winslow Homer, American, 1836 - 1910. 'The Milk Maid,' 1878. watercolor over graphite, 50.3 x 36 cm (19 3/4 x 14 3/16 in.) Gift of Ruth K. Henschel in memory of her husband, Charles R. Henschel -

resource.title: Italian Painting of the 16th Century
resource.description: is featured in a collection of High Renaissance art. The tour looks at the different styles of Raphael, Titian, and other artists and examines how their artwork differed from the next generation of Italian painters.

image.caption: Bindo Altoviti -- details
image.alttext: Raphael, 'Bindo Altoviti,' c. 1515. Samuel H. Kress Collection -- 1943.4.33

resource.title: Italian Renaissance Ceramics
resource.description: presents 27 ceramic pieces created in Italy in the 15th to mid 16th centuries.

image.caption: The sacrifice of the Greeks
image.alttext: Broad-rimmed bowl with the sacrifice of the Greeks at Aulis and the omen of the serpent devouring nine birds, interpreted by the priest Calchas; arms of Anne de Montmorency, 1535

resource.title: Italian Sculpture of the 15th Century
resource.description: tours seven sculptures, providing images of the works, bibliographies, and exhibition histories.

image.caption: Lorenzo de' Medici -- details
image.alttext: Florentine 15th or 16th Century, probably after a model by Andrea del Verrocchio and Orsino Benintendi, 'Lorenzo de' Medici,' 1478/1521. Samuel H. Kress Collection -- 1943.4.92

resource.title: Medieval Metalwork and Enamels
resource.description: features eight pieces that are a part of the decorative arts exhibit at the National Gallery of Art. The works are from different centuries. Each of the object types originally served sacred purposes.

image.caption: Morse with the Trinity -- details
image.alttext: French 15th Century (setting western European late 19th Century). 'Morse with the Trinity,' c. 1400/1410 (Trinity and Angels); 1884/1897 (setting) Widener Collection

resource.title: Manet's The Dead Toreador and The Bullfight
resource.description: explores why the artist, stung by critical comments in 1864, cut his painting Incident in a Bullfight in two and then painted The Dead Toreador and The Bullfight on the resulting two canvasses. Using x-rays and intensive scientific analysis of the two existing paintings, historians have discovered fascinating connections between these seemingly unrelated works.

image.caption: The Dead Toreador
image.alttext: Édouard Manet, 'The Dead Toreador,' 1864. National Gallery of Art, Washington, Widener Collection

resource.title: Education at the National Gallery of Art
resource.description: provides easy access to free-loan educational materials, programs, and resources for teachers, educational activities and events, as well as internship and volunteer opportunities at the Gallery.

image.caption: School Tours
image.alttext: Roy Lichtenstein, 'Brushstroke,' 1965. Gift of Roy and Dorothy Lichtenstein, 1996.56.139

resource.title: Teacher Exchange: Curriculum Ideas
resource.description: offers interdisciplinary curriculum ideas from alumni of the Gallery's Teacher Institute. Each resource offers an explanation of each teachers' curriculum and the resources that he or she used at the Gallery. Topics range from mythology and interdisciplinary learning, to renaissance art and long-distance learning, to visual art and rural elementary schools, and more.

image.caption: Portrait of a Lady
image.alttext: Rogier van der Weyden, Netherlandish, 1399/1400 - 1464. 'Portrait of a Lady,' c. 1460. oil on panel, painted surface: 34 x 25.5 cm (13 3/8 x 10 1/16 in.) panel: 37 x 27 cm (14 1/16 x 10 5/8 in.) An

resource.title: NGA Classroom
resource.description: offers studies, brochures, and classroom activities for some of the Gallery's most intriguing exhibitions. Get lesson ideas for how to teach Mary Cassatt's "Little Girl in a Blue Armchair," or read a detailed explanation of the archetypal "action painter" Jackson Pollock. Twenty-four studies are available and topics span the Gallery's holdings.

image.caption: Self-portrait
image.alttext: Vincent van Gogh, Self-Portrait, 1889

resource.title: Triumph of the Baroque, Architecture in Europe (1600-1750)
resource.description: presents two centuries of European architectural history and explores the most famous architects of the baroque era. Learn how painting, sculpture, architecture, landscape, and urban planning during this era converged to produce buildings and structures with a heightened sense of drama and power.

image.caption: Model for the Villa Pisani, Stra
image.alttext: Girolamo Frigimelica (architect) and Giovanni Gloria and/or Sante Benato (model makers), 'Model for the Villa Pisani, Stra,' c. 1716, Musei Civici Veneziani, Museo Correr, Venice.

resource.title: The Drawings of Annibale Carracci
resource.description: explores the first exhibition devoted solely to the powerful and evocative drawings of Annibale Carracci (1560-1609). From his early experiments with naturalism to his late, almost abstract, style, Annibale revolutionized our way of looking at the world around us and at the art of the past.

image.caption: A Man Weighing Meat
image.alttext: 'A Man Weighing Meat,' c. 1582-1583; red chalk on beige paper, 278 x 170 (10 15/16 x 6 11/16). The Royal Collection © 1999 -- Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II

resource.title: The Golden Age of Chinese Archaeology
resource.description: illustrates the achievements of Chinese culture through the presentation of masterpieces dating from the Neolithic Period through Five Dynasties (5000 B.C. to A.D. 924), many discovered since the late 1970s and not seen before in the United States.

image.caption: Jade coiled dragon
image.alttext: Jade coiled dragon, Hongshan Culture (c. 4700-2920 B.C.) Liaoning Provincial Institute of Archaeology, Shenyang

resource.title: Master Painter in the Age of Rembrandt
resource.description: features one of the most esteemed Dutch artists of the seventeenth century, Gerrit Dou (1613-1675), also known as Rembrandt's first pupil. Included are many of Dou's best portraits and still lifes, as well as scenes of daily life, including images of mothers with children, painters in their studios, scholars, shopkeepers, schoolmasters, musicians, and astronomers.

image.caption: Astronomer by Candlelight
image.alttext: Gerrit Dou, 'Astronomer by Candlelight,' c. 1665, oil on panel, arched top, 32 x 21.2 (12 5/8 x 8 3/8), The J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles

resource.title: Twentieth-Century American Art: The Ebsworth Collection
resource.description: explores one of the premier private holdings of American modernist paintings, sculptures, and works on paper. It includes masterpieces by Patrick Henry Bruce, Alexander Calder, Georgia O'Keeffe, Andy Warhol, and others.

image.caption: Le Tournesol (The Sunflower)
image.alttext: Edward Steichen, 'Le Tournesol (The Sunflower),' c. 1920, tempera and oil on canvas, National Gallery of Art, Washington, Gift of the Collectors Committee 1999.43.1

resource.title: The Impressionists at Argenteuil
resource.description: examines the role of the small suburban town of Argenteuil, France, in the development of the impressionist movement. The site features impressionist paintings by six influential artists -- Boudin, Caillebotte, Manet, Monet, Renoir, and Sisley.

image.caption: Woman with a Parasol
image.alttext: Claude Monet, 'Woman with a Parasol -- Madame Monet and Her Son,' 1875. National Gallery of Art, Collection of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Mellon.

resource.title: Modern Art and America: Alfred Stieglitz and His New York Galleries
resource.description: brings together for the first time in more than 50 years a representative collection of paintings, sculptures, and photographs exhibited in the galleries of one of the most influential figures in early twentieth-century art. An aim of this website it to "reveal more clearly the nature of his [Stieglitz's] contribution to American art."

image.caption: Hell
image.alttext: Auguste Rodin, 'Hell,' c. 1900-1908, pencil and watercolor. André Bromberg Collection (exhibited at 291, 1910)

resource.title: Anatomy of an Exhibition: Art Nouveau, 1890-1914
resource.description: offers a glimpse behind the scenes of the planning and construction of the Art Nouveau exhibit at the National Gallery of Art. It includes conversations with the curator and designer, photo essays of craftspeople who created the exhibition spaces, timelines of the Art Nouveau period and the exhibition production process, a time-lapse movie of the exhibition's construction, and a streaming audio tour of 15 works.

image.caption: La Loïe Fuller
image.alttext: Jules Chéret, French (1836-1932). 'La Loïe Fuller,' 1893. lithograph, Victoria and Albert Museum, London

resource.title: Picasso: The Early Years, Brochure
resource.description: presents the first comprehensive survey of Picasso's work before cubism, from the academic and realist work of his youth to his emergence as a brilliant stylist in late 1906.

image.caption: Family of Saltimbanques
image.alttext: Pablo Picasso [Spanish, 1881 - 1973], 'Family of Saltimbanques,' 1905. oil on canvas, 212.8 x 229.6 cm (83 3/4 x 90 3/8 in.) Chester Dale Collection 1963.10.190

resource.title: Prints Abound: Paris in the 1890s
resource.description: features a selection of printed images that appeared as posters, albums, books, periodicals, music primers, song sheets, and folding screens. The prints and color lithography offered painters such as Pierre Bonnard, Edouard Vuillard, and Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec a wider audience for their artwork, which was often misunderstood by the Salon, the organizer of state-sponsored exhibitions.

image.caption: Poster for France Champagne
image.alttext: Pierre Bonnard, 1867-1947. 'Poster for France Champagne,' 1891, color lithograph. Virginia and Ira Jackson Collection, Promised Gift to the National Gallery of Art

resource.title: Saint Gaudens' Memorial to Shaw and the Massachusetts 54th Regiment
resource.description: focuses on the powerful memorial created to honor one of the first African-American units of the Civil War. Six sections of in-depth material explore the artist and his working methods, historical background on Shaw and the regiment, the memorial and its conservation, text from the exhibition, and teaching resources.

image.caption: Details
image.alttext: Augustus Saint-Gaudens, 'Shaw Memorial' (detail), 1900, patinated plaster.

resource.title: Tilman Riemenschneider: Master Sculptor of the Late Middle Ages
resource.description: exhibits over 50 works of an artist (W'rzburg, Germany, 1483-1531), who demonstrated proficiency -- at the beginning of his career -- in a variety of media, sculpting limewood, alabaster, sandstone, and marble with equal facility.

image.caption: Virgin Annunciate
image.alttext: Tilman Riemenschneider, 'Virgin Annunciate,' c. 1500. Musée du Louvre, Paris

resource.title: Carleton Watkins: The Art of Perception
resource.description: unveils striking landscape photographs taken by this famous nineteenth-century American artist (1829 -1916). It includes his best-known studies of Yosemite and other celebrated works from California, Washington, and Oregon.

image.caption: Arch at the West End Farallons
image.alttext: Carleton Watkins, 'Arch at the West End Farallons,' 1869. Albumen print from wet-collodion negative. Collection of Stanford University Libraries, Cecil H. Green Library, Department of Special Coll

resource.title: Max Weber's Modern Vision
resource.description: presents 11 paintings by this influential painter (1881-1961), who was among the first artists to carry the modernist revolution to the U.S.

image.caption: Interior of the Fourth Dimension -- details
image.alttext: Max Weber, 'Interior of the Fourth Dimension,' 1913. Gift of Natalie Davis Spingarn in memory of Linda R. Miller and in Honor of the 50th Anniversary of the National Gallery of Art. 1990.78.1

resource.title: Thirty-Five Years at Crown Point Press
resource.description: tours the achievements of a community studio that coincided with an increase of interest in collaborative printmaking among painters, sculptors, and other artists. It also looks at the skilled printers who produced editions of multiple original impressions.

image.caption: Abstraction, Belief, Desire
image.alttext: Pat Steir, 'Abstraction, Belief, Desire,' 1981

resource.title: Art for the Nation: Collecting for a New Century
resource.description: offers 14 in-depth studies of works by various artists represented in the National Gallery of Art. The studies include information on the artist, technique, and history behind each painting.

image.caption: The Mountain Nymph, Sweet Liberty
image.alttext: Julia Margaret Cameron, 'The Mountain Nymph, Sweet Liberty,' June 1866, albumen print from collodion negative, National Gallery of Art, Washington, New Century Fund 1997.97.1

interestingfact.text: Almost all of Jasper Johns' images incorporate art history, art-making, found images, and references to his earlier works and experiences. Scholars have probed these sources, speculating on their many possible meanings. Learn more about the elements that make up Perilous Night.

resource.title: Thomas Moran
resource.description: was one of the major landscape painters of his day, and painted some of America's most prominent natural treasures, including the Rocky Mountains, the Grand Canyon, and Yellowstone. He also arranged for the first government-sponsored survey of Yellowstone, and his images "were later reported to have played a decisive role in the debate that led to the establishment of Yellowstone as the first national park in March 1872."

image.caption: Shoshone Falls on the Snake River
image.alttext: Thomas Moran, 'Shoshone Falls on the Snake River,' 1900, Gilcrease Museum, Tulsa, Oklahoma

resource.title: Jackson Pollock Web Feature
resource.description: takes an in-depth look at the life and work of this American original. His drip paintings were the culmination of his synthesis of tradition and modernism. The site examines the artist, his paintings, and his process.

image.caption: Orange Head
image.alttext: Jackson Pollock, 'Orange Head,' 1938-1942, Collection Lee Krasner Pollock, Courtesy Jason McCoy Inc., New York

interestingfact.text: A derisive reviewer who nicknamed Pollock "Jack the Dripper" had inadvertently grasped the crux of his pioneering contribution. To achieve the complex and subtle structural interlace that characterizes his mature work, Pollock had indeed dripped, poured, and spattered his pigments across the vast expanse of raw canvas.

resource.title: Mark Rothko
resource.description: presents selected paintings and drawings by this abstract artist who was known for his use of color, surface, proportion, and scale and for his contributions to the "New York School" style of painting. The site features paintings of scenes from the New York Subway, landscapes, and his floating rectangles.

image.caption: Untitled
image.alttext: Mark Rothko, 'Untitled,' late 1920s, National Gallery of Art, Gift of The Mark Rothko Foundation, Inc., 1986.43.204

resource.title: National Gallery of Art Sculpture Garden
resource.description: Explains the works of art, artists, construction process, and the history of this important attraction on the National Mall.

image.caption: Thinker on a Rock
image.alttext: Barry Flanagan, 'Thinker on a Rock,' 1997. National Gallery of Art, Washington. Gift of John and Mary Pappajohn

resource.title: Johaness Vermeer's Woman Holding a Balance
resource.description: examines Vermeer's use of light, proportion, symbolism, and other techniques in this 17th century masterpiece. How the museum restored the painting is also explained.

image.caption: Woman Holding a Balance
image.alttext: Johannes Vermeer, Woman Holding a Balance, c. 1664, National Gallery of Art, Widener Collection

resource.title: Watson and the Shark by John Singleton
resource.description: is a painting inspired by an event that took place in Havana, Cuba, in 1749. Fourteen-year-old Brook Watson, an orphan serving as a crew member on a trading ship, was attacked by a shark while swimming alone in the harbor. As his shipmates launched a valiant rescue effort, the shark continued its attack on the boy. The story of the rescue and facts about Watson's life are chronicled in the online exhibit.

image.caption: The story
image.alttext: John Singleton Copley's 'Watson and the Shark' was inspired by an event that took place in Havana, Cuba, in 1749.

resource.title: Highlights of the Gallery's History
resource.description: is a timeline chronicling the Gallery's birth and development. Milestones are illustrated by images of important gifts, exhibitions, Gallery projects, and historical documents.

image.caption: The West Building
image.alttext: An aerial view of the West Building showing the design and layout of the skylights. Copyright © 2007 National Gallery of Art, Washington D.C.

resource.title: NGAKids
resource.description: features child-focused stories, activities, and information on the Gallery's collections. Visitors can explore the nuances of Jacques-Louis David's famous Napoleon in His Study, identify colors and shapes in a Kandinsky abstract painting, or follow Lizzy and Gordon through the Sculpture Garden via an animated musical tale. The site also links to family-oriented resources, events, and publications for children of all ages.

image.caption: Ginevra de' Benci
image.alttext: Leonardo da Vinci, Ginevra de' Benci, c. 1474/1478, oil on panel, National Gallery of Art, Ailsa Mellon Bruce Fund

resource.title: NGA Online Tours
