resource.description: offers a number of collection tours, in-depth study tours, architecture tours, and "virtual walking tours." Visitors can choose a tour by school or medium and explore the collections of painting, sculpture, and graphic arts, or tour the Gallery's East Building. Many guides are available in English, French, German, Italian, and Spanish.

image.caption: Watson and the Shark
image.alttext: John Singleton Copley's 'Watson and the Shark' was inspired by an event that took place in Havana, Cuba, in 1749.

resource.title: The Shaw Memorial
resource.description: focuses on the powerful memorial created by Saint-Gaudens to honor one of the first African-American units of the Civil War. Six sections of in-depth material explore the artist and his working methods, historical background on Shaw and the regiment, the memorial and its conservation, text from the exhibition, and teaching resources.

image.caption: Details
image.alttext: Detail of the Shaw Memorial

interestingfact.text: obert Gould Shaw was a young Bostonian with impeccable family connections, strongly abolitionist parents, and battle experience. Born October 10, 1837, he was the only son of Francis Gould and Sarah Sturgis Shaw.

resource.title: NIDA Goes to School
resource.description: contains brief guides and research reports on various drugs and the effects of drug abuse on the body and the brain. It also links to the journal, "NIDA Notes," and to five differently-organized NIDA search engines.

image.caption: The brain and addiction
image.alttext: Stylized graphic of the brain.

resource.title: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences (NIEHS) Kids' Pages
resource.description: teach children about the connection between their health and the environment and encourage the pursuit of careers in health, science, and the environment. The site includes brainteasers, puzzles, stories, and science activities.

publisher.name: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

resource.title: Environmental Health Science Education
resource.description: aims to increase student interest and preparation in the environmental health sciences so that they are aware of science career opportunities, and to increase public awareness about the impact of environmental agents on human health so that all citizens can lead healthy andproductive lives.

publisher.name: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

image.caption: Teachers
image.alttext: Image of books and glasses and and apple

resource.title: NIST in Your House
resource.description: illustrates the impact that the National Institute of Standards and Technology has on daily life. Visitors can read about the standards that help ensure the safety and suitability of construction materials, packaging, consumer electronics, home appliances, timing, cooling and heating equipment, and health products.

publisher.name: National Institute of Standards and Technology
publisher.agency: National Institute of Standards and Technology

image.caption: The backyard grill
image.alttext: Childlike drawing of an outdoor grill

resource.title: National Library of Medicine
resource.description: is the entry point to the largest medical library in the world. Find answers to health questions, abstracts from 4300 biomedical journals, information about clinical research studies, a directory of health organizations, a catalog of books, journals, and audiovisuals in the NLM collections, a single web interface that searches multiple NLM retrieval systems, and additional information by subject.

image.caption: Tabulae sceleti et musculorum corporis humani
image.alttext: Bernhard Siegfried Albinus: Tabulae sceleti et musculorum corporis humani

resource.title: History of Medicine Homepage
resource.description: features all book-length material in the National Library of Medicine (NLM) printed before 1914, thousands of later pamphlets and dissertations, and all pre-1871 journals. It includes Arabic, Persian, and early western manuscripts, reprints of more than 1,300 important Chinese medical works, prints and photographs, films, and videocassettes. The site also offers information on the Library's services and programs.

image.caption: Dream anatomy, 1690
image.alttext: Image of 'Ontleding des menschelyken lichaams...' Amsterdam, 1690. Copperplate engraving with etching. National Library of Medicine.

interestingfact.text: Hippocrates was a Greek physician of the 5th century B.C., whom many consider the "Father of Medicine". Some sixty treatises are preserved today under his name and are generally referred to as the "Hippocratic corpus," though not all were written by Hippocrates himself or even by his students.

resource.title: The Visible Human Project
resource.description: offers comprehensive databases of three-dimensional images of the human body. The long-term goal is to produce a system of knowledge structures that will link visual knowledge forms to symbolic knowledge formats such as the names of body parts.

image.caption: The visible human dissector
image.alttext: The Visible Human Dissector from Touch of Life Technologies (TOLTECH), Aurora, Colorado.

resource.title: The Dinosaur Homepage
resource.description: displays featured bones from the Museum's large collection. Each photograph may be enlarged and comes with a text. The bones can be viewed by dinosaur type and by time period. The site also offers a geologic timeline, an anatomy lesson, and a discussion of misconceptions about dinosaurs

image.caption: Triceratops horridus
image.alttext: This skeleton measures 17 feet from nose to tip of tail. It is the world's first Triceratops skeleton ever mounted.

resource.title: The New Netherland Project
resource.description: is an effort to transcribe, translate, and publish all Dutch documents in New York repositories relating to the 17th century colony of New Netherland. One of the collection's highlights is the letter from Peter Schaghen to directors of the West India Company announcing the purchase of Manhattan island.

image.caption: Fort Amsterdam
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Mathew Brady Portraits
resource.description: survey the life and work of this pioneering photojournalist and portraitist best known for his photographs of the Civil War. Visitors can read about Brady's contributions toward legitimizing photography as an art form, see who Brady photographed, and learn about the photographic processes that he used.

image.caption: General Ulysses S. Grant
image.alttext: In June 1864, Mathew Brady photographed General Ulysses S. Grant at City Point in Virginia.

resource.title: Lost and Found Sound
resource.description: is a call to listeners to send in their home recordings of the last 100 years to be shaped into stories that capture the rituals and sounds of everyday life. For example, the site features lost creation songs from the Mojave people, 20th century wars on tape, and a program on the disappearance of languages.

resource.title: Teacher's Corner at Badlands National Park
resource.description: is a guide to visiting the South Dakota park and to a series of classroom activities that teach about the park.

resource.title: Bent's Old Fort National Historic Site's Learning Page
resource.description: examines the people and construction of Bent's Fort, and the Santa Fe Trail. Built originally in 1833, this adobe fort became a center of trade with Indians and trappers. For much of its 16-year history, it was the only major permanent white settlement on the Santa Fe Trail. It provided explorers, adventurers, and the U.S. Army a place to get supplies, wagon repairs, livestock, good food, water, company, rest and protection in this vast "Great American Desert."

resource.title: Cabrillo National Monument: Cabrillo as Classroom
resource.description: describes several classroom resources about the monument near San Diego, CA. Featured is the "Cabrillo Tidepool Study," a 4-week on-line unit designed for students at the 5th grade level. It covers many life science topics including ecosystems, adaptation, life-cycle, food web, and conservation, and it integrates language arts and math activities.

resource.title: The Chihuahuan Desert Lab On-Line Manual
resource.description: is a comprehensive program designed to enhance high school science, math and technology studies by involving students in monitoring natural resources in Carlsbad Caverns and Guadalupe Mountains National Parks. It offers a resource-based curriculum, science projects, an online manual for teachers, and an evaluation.

image.caption: Insect drawings -- PDF
image.alttext: Pencil drawing of a ladybird beetle

resource.title: Carlsbad Caverns National Park
resource.description: is the website of this park in the Guadalupe Mountains (New Mexico) that contains 86 known caves, including Carlsbad Cavern, home of one of the world's largest underground chambers. The website offers a cultural history of the area and a teacher's guide "About Bats, Caves, and Deserts."

image.caption: Green Lake
image.alttext: Each visitor on the tour will get a close-up view of the Green Lake, which isn't really green and isn't really a lake.

resource.title: Effigy Mounds National Monument Teacher's Guide
resource.description: provides more than 40 lesson ideas developed by teachers to help students learn about Eastern Woodland Native Americans who lived in the upper Mississippi River valley (southwestern Wisconsin and northeast Iowa) from about 500 BC to 1300 AD and who built "effigies" -- ceremonial burial mounds shaped to represent bears, eagles, falcons, bison, deer, turtles, lizards, and other creatures.

image.caption: Spring burning ritual
image.alttext: The spring burning ritual tends to give the deep rooted prairie plants a survival advantage over shallow rooted weeds.

resource.title: The Everglades Ecosystem: Everglades National Park
resource.description: looks at the habitats, animals and endangered species of the Everglades, as well as water management ("the critical issue for the Everglades"). It also examines threats to what remains of this "river of grass" -- population growth, water quality, loss of species, introduction of non-native species, and more.

image.caption: Alligator
image.alttext: This is the most incredible ecosystem of all the worlds within the world of the park; for in a sense the alligator is the Gator holekeeper of the Everglades.

resource.title: Everglades Educational Resources
resource.description: provides classroom activities, resources for teachers, a list of current articles, links to recommended readings, and field guides about Everglades National Park. It also tells how to plan class visits to the park.

image.caption: Heron tile game
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Gettysburg National Military Park Teacher's Guide
resource.description: provides sample lesson plans, essay questions, ideas for bulletin boards and student projects, a Civil War reading list, and other resources teachers may use to guide students through the Battle of Gettysburg.

resource.title: Gettysburg Battlefield -- Virtual Tour
resource.description: describes with photos and text the three-day battle that marked the turning point in the Civil War. The site gives detailed descriptions of each day of the battle and further texts about the various generals involved.

image.caption: The life of a soldier
image.alttext: Heavy marching order by Charles Reed -- (Hardtack and Coffee)

resource.title: Teacher's Guide to Independence National Historical Park
resource.description: helps teachers plan a trip to see Independence Hall, Congress Hall, Old City Hall, the Liberty Bell, the First and Second Banks of the U.S., Franklin Court, and other historic buildings and artifacts (in Philadelphia) associated with our nation's founding. Lessons are for Grades 4-6; however, many can be adapted for other grades.

resource.title: LearnNPS
resource.description: links educational programs to over fifty national parks, monuments, historic sites, and so forth, of the National Park Service. Information at the sites range from general visitor information to more detailed background guides to comprehensive educational kits for the classroom.

resource.title: Knife River Indian Villages -- Teachers Guide
resource.description: offers information and activities about the American Indians of the Northern Plains who lived in the area of the Knife River where it enters the Missouri. This area is now Knife River Indian Villages National Historic Site.

image.caption: Buffalo hunt
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Environmental Education
resource.description: offers activities for elementary students and families visiting Lake Mead National Recreation Area to learn about desert plants, animals, food chains, and "communities" in the Mojave Desert (AZ and NV).

resource.title: Petersburg National Battlefield -- Education
resource.description: gives materials for different grade levels to prepare students for field trips to the site of an important Civil War battle south of Richmond, VA. This resource guide is based upon Standards of Learning Objectives for Virginia Public Schools.

image.caption: City Point
image.alttext: During the siege of Petersburg General Grant's headquarters was at City Point, Virginia, eight miles behind Union lines.

resource.title: Wildlife Management Activity Guide for Teachers
resource.description: presents learning activities developed by teachers to help high school students learn about wildlife management on the Upper Peninsula of Michigan.

image.caption: Au Sable light station
image.alttext: Lake Superior's Au Sable Light Station, built in 1874 by the U.S. Lighthouse Service, is located within Pictured Rocks National Lakeshore.

resource.title: Kid's Korner at Tumacácori National Historical Park
resource.description: is a site where children can learn about customs and games of the first Europeans who came to southern Arizona and the native people who lived there in the 1600s. The site includes instructions for making adobe bricks, constructing a pump drill, creating a Native American calendar, and other activities.

resource.title: Educator's Guide, Vicksburg National Military Park
resource.description: is a guide for teachers taking their students to the site of the important Civil War campaign. The guide brings to bear the viewpoints of the arts, language arts, mathematics, science, and social studies as they pertain to this campaign.

resource.title: Whitman Mission National Historic Site -- The Learning Place
resource.description: offers a teaching guide about the mission of Marcus and Narcissa Whitman at Waiilatpu, an important way station in the early days of the Oregon Trail. The Whitmans labored to bring Christianity to the Cayuse, but deep cultural differences and a measles epidemic led to violence in which the Cayuse killed the Whitmans and 11 others in November, 1847. The park preserves the site of Whitman's buildings and Mill Pond, a short segment of the Oregon Trail, and the grave where the victims are buried.

resource.title: White Sands National Monument Fact Sheets
resource.description: is a resource page about one of the world's great natural wonders -- the glistening white sands of New Mexico. These sands rise from the heart of the Tularosa basin, which is located in New Mexico at the northern end of the Chihuahuan Desert.

resource.title: National Audiovisual Center
resource.description: is a centralized resource for federally developed training and education materials. Its collection offers more than 9,000 audiovisual and media training productions in subject areas including occupational safety and health, fire services, law enforcement, and foreign languages. Information and educational materials are available on areas including history, health, agriculture, and natural resources.

resource.title: Margaret Sanger Papers Project
resource.description: looks at the work of this advocate for women's reproductive freedom. Sanger worked to help develop simpler, less costly, and more effective methods of birth control. Bibliographies, biographies, selected papers, a newsletter, and links to documents on and off the website help illustrate the life of this remarkable individualist.

resource.title: Oberlin History as American History
resource.description: offers exhibits that tell about the lives and histories of the people of Oberlin, Ohio. The website features the story of an Amistad captive, Oberlin women and the struggle for equality, and the city's cooperative tradition. It also includes city maps and pictures, letters and essays related to the city's founding and development, newspaper articles regarding the Niagara movement, and census data.

image.caption: Class of 1855
image.alttext: Oberlin College Lady Graduates, class of 1855. (courtesy Oberlin College Archives)

resource.title: World Factbook
resource.description: provides in-depth country profiles with information on geography, people, government, economy, communications, transportation, military, and transnational issues. It includes maps of major regions and links to other geopolitical and geographical information.

image.caption: Turkey and Black Sea region
image.alttext: Reference map of the Middle East

interestingfact.text: A doubly landlocked country is one that is separated from an ocean or an ocean-accessible sea by two intervening countries. Uzbekistan and Liechtenstein are the only countries that fit this definition.

resource.title: Oceanography: A Science and Technology Focus Site
resource.description: explores ocean habitats, regions, and more. Learn how waves are created and where hydrothermal vents are found, or conduct one of the site's experiments to find out why big ships don't sink.

image.caption: California sea lion
image.alttext: A California sea lion rests on the rocks (courtesy of Dan Costa, UCSC).

resource.title: Genomics Primer
resource.description: gives an overview of the science of genetics and the Human Genome Project. Learn about genomes, DNA, genes, chromosomes, and more. Find audio and video files about genetics and the Human Genome Project, images of genomes, research news, frequently asked questions, and a page for students.

image.caption: Genes to proteins
image.alttext: Although genes get a lot of attention, it?s the proteins that perform most life functions and even make up the majority of cellular structures.

resource.title: To Know Ourselves
resource.description: tells about the Human Genome Project and provides general information about and links to the coordinated effort to determine the complete sequence of the DNA in the human genome. It surveys the project's goals, the tools being used to map genetic code, the spin-off technologies generated by the project, and the ethical, legal, and social implications of knowing our genetic blueprint.

image.caption: The inner workings of microbes
image.alttext: Learning about the inner workings of microbes can lead to discovery of ways to isolate and use their components to develop new, synthetic nanostructures that carry out some of the functions of living

resource.title: Ancestors in the Americas
resource.description: is a companion website for the PBS series by the same name and explores the history and stories of Asian Americans. A timeline shows events that shaped Asian American history, and a resource section allows further exploration of the Asian American experience. The site includes guides with discussion questions for teachers and an online discussion.

image.caption: European colonizations in Asia
image.alttext: French, Dutch and British vie for parts of India.

resource.title: Crucible of Empire: The Spanish-American War
resource.description: examines the 1898 war with Spain, which steered the U.S. toward becoming a world power. Learn about Teddy Roosevelt, the Rough Riders, and the sinking of the U.S.S. Maine. Find a timeline of events, photos of major figures, newspaper articles and headlines from 1890s, sheet music, classroom activities, historical resources, and a quiz.

image.caption: Headlines during war
image.alttext: February headline New York Journal regarding Spanish-American War era.

resource.title: Napoleon
resource.description: is a PBS film that chronicles the life of the infamous French leader. The resources offered here are designed to help you use the PBS "Napoleon" video series and companion website in secondary social studies, civics, religion, and language arts classes. The site is organized into four areas: the man and the myth, Napoleon and Josephine, politics in Napoleon's time, and Napoleon at war. There are four lesson plans, an interactive battlefield simulator, video clips, and more.

image.caption: Bonaparte, 1796-97
image.alttext: Napoleon at Rivoli during the First Italian Campaign, 1796-97.

interestingfact.text: On June 22, 1815, Napoleon abdicated his throne for the second time after his defeat at Waterloo. With no hope of escape, he put himself at the mercy of Great Britain. He wished, he said, "to reside in a country house near London." The British turned him down.

resource.title: Frank Lloyd Wright
resource.description: offers several pictures of 10 buildings of the famous American architect, as well as discussion of his life and work. The site offers films clips of Wright being interviewed.

image.caption: The Guggenheim
image.alttext: Drawing of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York City

resource.title: The Great War (World War I)
resource.description: features interviews with 19 historians who were consulted in the making of the 8-part PBS series on World War I. Maps, bibliographies, online links, and a timeline are also at the site.

image.caption: Total war
image.alttext: Soldiers in trenches along the western front

resource.title: The Fight in the Fields: Cesar Chavez and the Farmworkers Struggle
resource.description: tells the story of a man, a union, and a time when millions of Americans joined a just cause. The Fight in the Fields is a portrait of Cesar Chavez, the charismatic leader of the United Farmworkers Union (UFW), and the history and impact of the UFW.

image.caption: Elegy for a hero
image.alttext: Painting by Octavio Ocampo

resource.title: Jazz, A Film by Ken Burns
resource.description: is the companion website to the Ken Burns PBS series that aired in January 2001. Explore cities and clubs where jazz developed; listen to excerpts of bebop, cool jazz and other styles; discover what makes jazz "jazz" and the theory behind the art form often called the purest expression of American democracy. The site provides biographies of nearly 100 musicians, transcripts of interviews that went into the making of the show, a "virtual piano," a study guide and more than a dozen lessons.

image.caption: Ella Fitzgerald
image.alttext: Photo of Ella Fitzgerald. Image courtesy of William Gottlieb

interestingfact.text: In jazz, composed music and improvised music merge in a unique fashion. It has been said that the best improvised music sounds composed, and that the best composed music sounds improvised.

resource.title: The U.S.-Mexican War
resource.description: is an online companion to a PBS documentary about the war, its background, and consequences. It features references, a timeline, a bulletin board public discussion, and is available both in English and Spanish.

image.caption: Manifest Destiny
image.alttext: American Progress by George Crofutt

resource.title: Liberty! The American Revolution
resource.description: is an online companion to the 6-part PBS series. It begins in the aftermath of the French and Indian War and ends with the creation of the Constitution. Chronologies, short bibliographies, images, and online links are offered for many aspects of the 2 1/2 decade chapter of American history.

image.caption: Daily life in the colonies
image.alttext: Image of daily life in the colonies.

interestingfact.text: On October 19, 1781, in Yorktown, Virginia, Charles Lord Cornwallis signed orders surrendering his British Army to a combined French and American force. As Cornwallis' 8,000 man force became prisoners-of-war, the British band played the "The World Turned Upside Down," a tune that underscored the strange turn of events which had brought defeat at the hands of the provincial forces of America, to the most powerful country in Europe.

resource.title: Citizen Kurchatov: Stalin's Bombmaker
resource.description: tells the story of a complex, world-class physicist who became the driving force the Soviet Union's race to develop the atomic and hydrogen bomb.

image.caption: Hazards of testing
image.alttext: Photo of Soviet H-Bomb explosion

interestingfact.text: On November 1, 1952, the United States detonated the first hydrogen device, code named "Mike," near the island of Elugelab in the Eniwetok Atoll. It yielded 10.4 megatons, over five hundred times more explosive than the bomb dropped on Hiroshima. The island of Elugelab was completely wiped away, leaving a crater over one mile wide.

resource.title: The West
resource.description: is an online companion to the 8-part PBS documentary. The site is divided into sections dealing with an overall tour, events in the West, places, people, and archives.

image.caption: Yosemite Valley
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Africans in America
resource.description: is an online companion to the four-part PBS series, covering the period 1450 to 1865. There are historical narratives, resource banks of images, documents, stories, biographies, commentaries, and a teacher's guide.

image.caption: A Ride for Liberty
image.alttext: Eastman Johnson's painting, 'A Ride for Liberty -- The Fugitive Slaves'

resource.title: Andrew Carnegie: The Richest Man in the World
resource.description: is an online companion to film documentary on a man who was fond of saying "The man who dies rich, dies disgraced." Carnegie amassed a fortune, then gave it away. Millions of dollars went to support education, a pension plan for teachers, and the cause of world peace. Most famous as a benefactor of libraries, he funded nearly 3,000 around the world. The site has dozens of images and texts dealing with the great industrialist, his contemporary millionaires, and his times.

image.caption: Andrew Carnegie
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Eleanor Roosevelt
resource.description: brings to life one of the century's most influential women. See the Roosevelt family tree, newspaper columns written by Mrs. Roosevelt, a clip from a TV appearance, a timeline, and a guide for teachers.

image.caption: Eleanor Roosevelt
image.alttext: Image of Eleanor Roosevelt

resource.title: George Wallace: Settin' The Woods on Fire
resource.description: features the political and personal life of George Wallace. Four times governor of Alabama and four times a candidate for president, he was feared as a racist demagogue and admired as a politician who spoke his mind. This site helps traces Wallace's rise from his roots in rural Alabama to the assassination attempt that transformed him. The site includes descriptions of significant events such as desegregation and politics in 1968.

image.caption: 1968 campaign
image.alttext: During the 1968 campaign, George Wallace's blunt outspokenness on the stump was appealing to many.

resource.title: A Science Odyssey
resource.description: highlights some the most spectacular discoveries in science and technology during the 20th century. The site includes an Educator's Guide with activities, discussion questions, and information for using A Science Odyssey in the classroom. A resource list supplies information on books, websites, and other videos related to the programs or activities.

image.caption: Medicine and health
image.alttext: Image of operating room from years ago

resource.title: Building Big
resource.description: helps kids think about structures they see every day and the impact of technology on society. You can use the television series, website, and activity guide to help teach basic physical science concepts. The website includes animated interactive labs on basic engineering concepts and problem solving activities; historical overviews that introduce bridges, domes, skyscrapers, dams, and tunnels, and the forces that affect them; and a database of engineering marvels.

image.caption: The Eiffel Tower
image.alttext: Photo of the Eiffel Tower -- Paris, France

interestingfact.text: The Channel Tunnel, also called the Euro Tunnel or Chunnel, is a 32-mile rail tunnel beneath the English Channel. It took just three years for tunnel boring machines from France and England to chew through the chalky earth and meet hundreds of feet below the surface of the English Channel. Today, trains roar through the tunnel at speeds up to 100 miles per hour and it's possible to get from one end to the other in only 20 minutes.

resource.title: Between the Lions
resource.description: is based on the PBS children's TV series, and presents a new story each week with related interactive games and activities for kids 4-7. It also recommends books for each episode and offers more than 300 tips and resources for helping kids learn to read.

image.caption: Gawain's word
image.alttext: See caption below.

resource.title: A Midwife's Tale, The American Experience
resource.description: is a companion to the PBS documentary constructed around the diary kept by a Maine woman kept from 1785 to 1812. Besides interviews with contemporary historians, images from the diaries, and background material, the site provides a complete transcript of the broadcast itself.

image.caption: After the Revolution
image.alttext: When Martha Ballard began her diary in 1785, the Revolutionary War had been over for just a year.

resource.title: TR: The Story of Theodore Roosevelt
resource.description: is an online companion to a 4-hour PBS documentary. It features photographs, newspapers, motion pictures, and sound recordings; family diaries and letters; and interviews with scholars, historians, and Roosevelt family members.

image.caption: TR in a rowboat
image.alttext: Negative #243321, Courtesy Department of Library Services, American Museum of Natural History

resource.title: American Masters: Alfred Stieglitz
resource.description: presents an essay, timeline, video clips, and interviews examining this photographer, artist, and art impresario. Stieglitz was a powerful force in the arts of the early 20th century and an important interpreter of emerging modern culture. This web site is a companion to first full-length film biography of the photographer, "Alfred Stieglitz: The Eloquent Eye."

image.caption: Timeline
image.alttext: Image of an older Alfred Stieglitz

resource.title: R. Buckminster Fuller: Thinking Out Loud
resource.description: is a spinoff from the PBS series about the architect, designer, engineer, poet, philosopher, author, and global iconoclast, best known for the geodesic dome.

image.caption: Guinea Pig B
image.alttext: Guinea Pig B is a name Bucky gave himself, to signify that his life was an experiment.

resource.title: New York: A Documentary Film
resource.description: is a place where kids can explore the history of New York and activities that will help them learn more about their own towns and get involved in their communities. Visitors are introduced to 12 little-known locations in the city, can sit in the back of an animated New York cab driven by a bantering celebrity, or explore the views of 32 luminaries who discuss the city that inspired them.

image.caption: Rudoloph Giuliani
image.alttext: Before becoming the 107th Mayor of the City of New York in 1993, Giuliani served as Associate Attorney General in the Department of Justice, and as U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

resource.title: World Wise Schools
resource.description: program aims to broaden U.S. students' perspectives by promoting cultural awareness and encouraging service to their communities and beyond. Students can communicate with currently serving Peace Corps volunteers; teachers can find Peace Corps volunteer speakers; and program materials are offered to teachers free -- including books, videos, slide shows, podcasts, standards-based lessons, and e-newsletters. All materials are based on Peace Corps volunteer experiences.

image.caption: Teaching gallery
image.alttext: South African outdoor classroom

resource.title: Looking at Ourselves and Others
resource.description: introduces students to the concepts of perspective, culture, and cross-cultural relations. The guide is designed to help students recognize and appreciate differences in perception among individuals and cultures, define culture and recognize its role in developing perceptions of ourselves and others, challenge assumptions, promote cross-cultural awareness, and provide opportunities to practice the behaviors that make cross-cultural communication possible.

image.caption: Web version
image.alttext: Image of an African baby's face while being held

resource.title: Water Sources in Cape Verde and West Africa
resource.description: allows students to research five methods of obtaining and/or conserving water, create displays, and give oral presentations of what they have learned to the diverse members of a simulated Cape Verdean community.

image.caption: Port of Praia
image.alttext: Shipping in the port of Praia was once centered on slavery.

resource.title: Celebrating Our Connections Through Water
resource.description: explains to students how they can collect data about the role of water in celebrations around the world, organize it in a retrieval chart, and use the information to create learning stations for a Water Day Celebration.

image.caption: Selected anecdotes -- PDF
image.alttext: Selected Anecdotes From Peace Corps Volunteers

resource.title: The Hare and the Water: A Tanzanian Folktale
resource.description: helps students explore the literary elements of a Tanzanian folktale, connect its message to contemporary Tanzanian life, create original conclusions, and thematically illustrate the folktale using oil pastels.

image.caption: The story -- PDF
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Water Uses and Children's Lives in East Africa
resource.description: asks students to compare their interactions with water to those of children in Kenya and Tanzania and discover that access to water helps to define children's roles in the family. They can then demonstrate their understanding through essays and pictures.

image.caption: Map of Tanzania -- PDF
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Water: From Neglect to Respect
resource.description: helps students use graphing, estimating, and writing skills to discover the ways they are dependent upon water to maintain their standard of living.

image.caption: Children of Ha Sekhohola Primary School
image.alttext: The children of Ha Sekhohola Primary School gather around the citibeng, or borehole, to fetch water between classes.

resource.title: Splish-Splash: Daily Use of Water
resource.description: helps students learn about the daily use of water in Kenya and Ghana as they read stories by Peace Corps Volunteers and compare the stories to their own daily use of water.

image.caption: Photo narratives for Kenya -- PDF
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Barrels and Buckets: Access to Water
resource.description: teaches students about access to water in Kenya, Ghana, and their own community as they read stories by Peace Corps Volunteers.

image.caption: Water pipe
image.alttext: This water pipe is used for pumping water from the Volta River to the town of Adidome, where people then fetch water from standpipes.

resource.title: Precious Drops: The Value of Water
resource.description: offers students the chance to learn the value of water by reading stories by Peace Corps Volunteers in Kenya and Ghana. They compare their own community to what they learn from reading.

image.caption: Photo narratives for Ghana -- PDF
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Climate and Water in Ghana
resource.description: shows the dramatic contrast between the rainy and dry seasons in West Africa and helps students define and identify the features of climate. They apply this knowledge to the study of how climate affects people and the environment.

image.caption: A boy sweeps off the borehole
image.alttext: A boy sweeps off the borehole at the school compound. This is one of the daily chores for the children. The yellow-and-brown uniforms are worn by children throughout Ghana.

resource.title: Water: A Source of Life and Culture
resource.description: asks students to research and analyze the role of water in daily life and create symbols to represent their findings. The students' symbols are then arranged to create a contemporary work of art.

image.caption: Map of Afria
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Narrative Cartoons
resource.description: is based on essays and photos provided by Peace Corps Volunteers. It asks students to create narrative cartoons that illustrate the lives of a young people in an African country.

image.caption: Narrative cartoons
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Visual Messages: Creating a Photomontage
resource.description: uses essays and photos provided by Peace Corps Volunteers to help students create a photomontage that focuses attention on environmental issues in the United States and Africa. Students challenge themselves to ask the question, "What is the photograph communicating?"

image.caption: Photomontages
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Water Pressure
resource.description: explores population increases and the stress on natural resources. Students then examine water usage in the United States and Africa.

image.caption: Water use -- PDF
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Water-Borne Illnesses
resource.description: helps students learn about water pollution, water-related illnesses, and sanitation procedures. They then draft a simulated plan to submit to the World Health Organization to deal with water-related problems in African communities.

image.caption: Water filtration
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Narrative vs. Expository Texts
resource.description: is written for students with limited English language skills, and uses the vignettes from Peace Corps Volunteers to compare and contrast expository and narrative texts. Students then go on to write essays of both types.

image.caption: Lesotho narrative texts -- PDF
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Madagascar Adventure
resource.description: explores agricultural practices in Madagascar and analyzes the effects on the people, the environment, and the endangered lemurs. Students then create technology-enhanced presentations.

image.caption: Madagascar stories
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Water: The Flow of Women's Work
resource.description: helps students compare the division of labor around water-related work in their own homes to families in rural Lesotho to gain an understanding of the multiple factors influencing gender role formation.

image.caption: Rondavel
image.alttext: Cow dung and soil were mixed with water to form a smear that was dabbed on both the inside and outside of the walls of this rondavel.

resource.title: Bringing Water to a Lesotho Village
resource.description: invites students to conduct research and then simulate a Lesotho village water committee that is designing a water supply system to improve living and health conditions.

image.caption: Lesotho -- PDF
image.alttext: Topographical Map of Lesotho

resource.title: Water Safari, A Journey of Life
resource.description: invites students on a virtual safari through African countries using the Water in Africa Web site. They can then create a water journal that demonstrates how water affects the cultural and physical features of each location.

image.caption: Kribi, Cameroon
image.alttext: This is part of the beach at Kribi, in Cameroon. The president of Cameroon has a home where he sometimes stays on this beachfront.

resource.title: Water: Source of Health; Source of Illness
resource.description: helps students examine the connections between water and disease in four West African countries and then devise a strategy to fight one water-borne illness in rural Africa.

image.caption: Purified water
image.alttext: This is Augustine at the SNEC plant, tasting the water after it's been purified.

resource.title: A Sense of Water
resource.description: asks students to discover how the need for water can be felt, seen, and heard in the song, voice, craft, religion, and ritual of a culture. They then capture this "sense of water" in a narrative poem.

image.caption: Mauritania -- PDF
image.alttext: Map of Mauritania

resource.title: Perseus Project: Digital Library on Ancient Greek and Roman Culture
resource.description: is an evolving digital library for the study of the ancient world. The website offers information on art and archeology, provides texts and translations, a historical overview, essays, maps, and an encyclopedia.

image.caption: Hercules
image.alttext: The most popular of Greek heroes, Hercules was celebrated in stories, sculptures, paintings, and even in the geography of the ancient world.

resource.title: Online Poetry Classroom
resource.description: aims to provide professional development opportunities for high school teachers, set new benchmarks for poetry education, and create an online community of teachers and poets dedicated to teaching poetry. The website includes information on annual summer institutes.

image.caption: T. S. Eliot
image.alttext: Photograph of T.S. Eliot bt Angus McBean, © Harvard Theatre Collection. Used by permission.

resource.title: Profiles in Science
resource.description: presents the archival collections of prominent 20th century biomedical scientists such as Julius Axelrod, Martin Rodbell, Joshua Lederberg, and Oswald T. Avery. The collections include books, journals, pamphlets, diaries, letters, manuscripts, photographs, audio tapes and materials.

image.caption: Barbara McClintock
image.alttext: Barbara McClintock in the lab at Cold Spring Harbor in 1947.

resource.title: Consumer Action Handbook
resource.description: provides advice and consumer tips on such topics as cars, shopping from home, avoiding consumer and investment fraud, home improvement and financing, and credit cards. Also included are thousands of names, addresses, phone numbers, and web site and e-mail addresses for national consumer organizations, better business bureaus, corporations, trade associations, state and local consumer protection offices, state agencies, military consumer offices, and Federal agencies.

resource.title: Pulse of the Planet
resource.description: provides a two-minute "sound portrait" of Planet Earth each weekday that is broadcast over 300 public and commercial stations around the world. This website includes an effort to learn about the ways people observe or celebrate the seasons of the year.

image.caption: Looking for lemurs
image.alttext: A mother lemur holds her small baby.

resource.title: Romantic Circles High School
resource.description: is a real-time multi-user environment that includes "online classrooms" designed and occupied by classes across the country, a library of Romantic electronic texts, a teachers' lounge, and shared spaces for special events and social interaction. The class is meeting inside Villa Diodati, the house that Lord Byron rented in the summer of 1816 and that served as the impetus for Mary Shelley's Frankenstein.

resource.title: The Papers of Jefferson Davis Project
resource.description: is publishing a multi-volume edition of his letters and speeches, several of which can be found on this website. A timeline, information on Davis and his family, photographs, and information about the project is offered.

image.caption: Jefferson Davis, c1860
image.alttext: Probably the most famous photographic image of Davis, taken by Mathew B. Brady in Washington just before the Civil War.

resource.title: National Youth Violence Prevention Resource Center
resource.description: is a central source of information on prevention and intervention programs, publications, research, and statistics on violence committed by and against children and teens.

image.caption: Celebration of hope
image.alttext: Celebrate National COA Week, February 11-17, 2007.

resource.title: National Marine Sanctuary
resource.description: provides information about our nation's marine sanctuaries -- how they were established, how they're managed, their scientific and educational programs, and events that occur in them throughout the year. Within the 13 sites are a range of creatures, habitats, historical artifacts, and flourishing maritime cultures.

image.caption: Copper rockfish
image.alttext: Copper rockfish are highly variable in coloration and therefore sometimes have different local names.

resource.title: Mysteries of Catalhoyuk
resource.description: is an educational website devoted to the famous archeological site in Turkey of one of the oldest cities in the world. The website depicts not only end-products of discoveries and interpretations but goes through the entire history of a 25 year excavation process.

image.caption: Would you live here?
image.alttext: Image of the different rooms of a Çatalhöyük house

interestingfact.text: One of the most amazing finds at Çatalhöyük are the layers and layers of murals painted on the inside plaster walls of buildings. Each mural presents this sort of mystery.

resource.title: SEAsite
resource.description: offers language instruction materials as well as cultural, political, and social information about countries in Southeast Asia including Thailand, Indonesia, Burma, Vietnam, and the Philippines.

image.caption: Vietnam
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: SEC Mutual Fund Cost Calculator
resource.description: enables investors to estimate and compare the costs of owning mutual funds. Mutual fund costs take a big chunk out of any investor's return, making it important for investors to know what costs they are paying and which cost structure is best for them. By using the Cost Calculator investors will find answers quickly to questions like this: Which is better, a no-load fund with yearly expenses of 1.75% , or a fund with a front-end sales charge of 3.5% with yearly expenses of 0.90%?

resource.title: U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission: Teachers and Students
resource.description: offers tips, fact sheets, and online tools for learning about the basics of saving and investing, helping students understand the importance of planning for their financial future, and identifying questions to ask about our investments. Learn about mutual funds. Try the online retirement calculator. Take an online quiz to "test your money smarts."

image.caption: Savings posters
image.alttext: Sneakers cost $75.00.

interestingfact.text: Over the past decade, American investors increasingly have turned to mutual funds to save for retirement and other financial goals.

resource.title: Integrating Mathematics, Science and Language: An Instructional Program
resource.description: is a bilingual curriculum and resources guide and is designed to help elementary school teachers organize instruction to increase achievement of Hispanic primary-grade children whose first language is not English. The guide offers a curriculum plan, instructional strategies and activities, suggested teacher and student materials, and assessment procedures.

image.caption: The human body -- PDF
image.alttext: Image of skin and blood cells

resource.title: The Joseph Henry Papers Project
resource.description: documents the life of Joseph Henry (1797-1878), the most revered American scientist of his times and the first Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution. Henry's pioneering work in electricity and magnetism helped bring about the invention of the telegraph, the electric motor, and the telephone.

image.caption: Joseph Henry
image.alttext: Joseph Henry, painting by Henry Ulke, 1875. National Portrait Gallery.

resource.title: The Lemelson Center
resource.description: explores the exciting world of invention. It features virtual exhibits and in-depth explorations of the electric guitar, the Quartz watch, the light bulb, and other inventions.

image.caption: Jimi Hendrix
image.alttext: With the same model of guitar that Buddy Holly played a decade earlier, Jimi Hendrix was blues rock's master of manipulated sound in the late 1960s.

resource.title: Encyclopedia Smithsonian
resource.description: is an index of 140 topics for which the Smithsonian Institution offers online resources: American history, art, automobiles, butterflies, canines, cats, clocks, computers, dinosaurs, electricity, engineering, gardens, gems, inventors, jazz, Latino history, military history, musical instruments, oceanography, photography, political history, railroads, rain forests, sciences, sports, Stradivarius violins, telephones, television, World War I, zoology, and more.

image.caption: Billy Joel
image.alttext: Host of Piano 300 Billy Joel, Celebrating Three Centuries of People and Pianos

resource.title: SLAC Education & Outreach
resource.description: aims to educate a new generation of scientists and to promote science literacy among the general public. The center offers programs for graduates and undergraduates as well as educational materials and resources, including a physics education project, information on equipment donations for schools, and a virtual visitors center.

image.caption: Polarized electron gun
image.alttext: In the polarized electron gun, polarized laser light knocks electrons off the surface of a semiconductor and an electric field accelerates them toward the end of the accelerator pipe.

resource.title: Supreme Court of the United States
resource.description: provides information on the High Court's docket, calendar and schedule, opinions and orders, and visitation schedule. It offers advice on how to file a case with the court, court rules, and links to related websites.

image.caption: About the Court
image.alttext: Front of Supreme Court Building

resource.title: The Anti-Drug
resource.description: has tips for parents for preventing drug use by their children. The site offers a brochure, methods for connecting with children, and suggestions on how you can talk openly and honestly with your kids about drugs.

publisher.name: The National Youth Anti-Drug Media Campaign

resource.title: The Official U.S. Time
resource.description: features an actual clock, accurate to 0.3 seconds depending on your Internet connection, that will display on your screen. There are three high-school level exhibits about time: "A Walk through Time," "Calendars through the Ages," and "The Quartz Watch." Learn that the first quartz clock goes back to 1927!

resource.title: For Kids
resource.description: is the Treasury Department's website for students. Kids can learn about money, saving, and investing, the history of the Treasury, and find out about tours of the Treasury building.

image.caption: Interactive money
image.alttext: Image of new $50 bill

interestingfact.text: The 1925 Lexington-Concord Sesquicentennial half dollar commemorates two battles that took place in April: the battles of Lexington and Concord, Massachusetts. The first shot fired is known as "the shot heard 'round the world" because it marked the start of the American Revolutionary War.

resource.title: The Handbook of Texas Online
resource.description: is a multidisciplinary encyclopedia of Texas history, geography, and culture. It comprises more than 23,000 articles on people, places, events, historical themes, institutions, and other topics.

resource.title: Museum of Paleontology
resource.description: features online exhibits and activities that allow you to experience the excitement of discovering and reconstructing a dinosaur, see underwater photos of a great white shark, trace the pattern of events that led to the diversity of life, and more.

image.caption: Proboscidea
image.alttext: African Elephant. Photo by Gerald and Buff Corsi, © 2002 California Academy of Sciences.

resource.title: Art and Life in Africa Project
resource.description: describes material that has been developed for a CD-ROM being produced at the University of Iowa. Links to further resources on the web have been added.

image.caption: Young Fulbe woman
image.alttext: Photographs of Burkina Faso, 1970-2004, by Christopher Roy

resource.title: Project SkyMath: Making Mathematical Connections
resource.description: uses real-time weather data, involves classrooms in hands-on mathematics. It is designed for middle school mathematics teachers and contains all of the information needed to use the 16 classroom activities.

publisher.name: The University Corporation for Atmospheric Research

image.caption: Layered atmosphere
image.alttext: The atmosphere has five different layers that are determined by the changes in temperature that happen with increasing altitude.

resource.title: Schools Online
resource.description: offers K-12 science, environmental, and character education activities. Join Squirmin' Herman the Worm in his underground world, or assist Detective LePlant as he explores the mysteries of plant science. There are lesson plans and activities for teachers on incubation and embryology.

image.caption: Incubation and embryology
image.alttext: Image of chicks

resource.title: Courts to Classes
resource.description: helps students learn about the federal court system. Teachers can use the site to connect court-related issues to students' everyday lives. Visitors can learn about the "Open Doors of Justice Program," use a lesson plan on the differences between civil and criminal cases, participate in a mini-moot court, and more.

image.caption: Contemporary topics
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Kids Pages
resource.description: is a gateway to information from the U.S. Department of Agriculture. From this page, students can find sites on nutrition, soil conservation, aquaculture, farming, forest fires, and more.

resource.title: USDA for Kids
resource.description: serves as a gateway to Department of Agriculture kids' pages and programs. It includes food guide pyramids, weather maps, tips for preventing foodborne illnesses, information about national forest campgrounds, and more.

resource.title: Drug Descriptions
resource.description: examines the Controlled Substances Act and provides information on narcotics, depressants, stimulants, hallucinogens, cannabis, steroids, clandestine laboratories, inhalants, drug abuse and AIDS, state drug abuse prevention and treatment programs, and penalties for controlled-substance related infractions.

image.caption: This is your brain
image.alttext: This photo of the brain of a meth user may look complicated. But the conclusions are easy to understand. This image shows that after a long period of abstinence from methamphetamine

resource.title: Get It Straight: The Facts About Drugs
resource.description: is an online prevention book written by kids for kids. It features information about controlled substances and intoxicants, and their effects. The book is helpful as a research tool for classroom assignments, and is also fun to read and share with friends. There are questions, activities, and role playing scenarios.

image.caption: Inhalant abuse
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Cyberethics for Teachers: A Lesson Plan for Teachers of Elementary and Middle School Children
resource.description: looks at issues in the field of computer crime, including predatory behavior and breaking into systems to vandalize and/or steal information and intellectual property. The site also offers a "Code of Responsible Computing" as developed by the Computer Learning Foundation.

resource.title: George Washington Appoints First Marshals, 1789
resource.description: tells the history of the U.S. Marshal service and explains how the Marshals' role in law enforcement has evolved over time.

resource.title: Inside the Courtroom: The Role of the Federal Prosecutor
resource.description: tells how prosecutors are appointed and explains how they carry out their duties.It features a case history, a glossary of legal terms, and descriptions of the duties of other federal court personnel.

resource.title: Fire Administration Kids Page
resource.description: offers tips that can help children and families remain safe from fire. It discusses the importance of using and maintaining smoke alarms and shows how to draw up a family fire escape plan. The site features a fire safety coloring book, a crossword puzzle, and an interactive game that challenges them to spot common household fire hazards.

image.caption: Hazard house
image.alttext: Image of a house with possible hazards

resource.title: U.S. Geological Survey: Education
resource.description: is an earth science education resource offering information on plants and animals, land, water, and maps. The site features a list of U.S. Geological Survey educational materials, activities and lessons for the classroom, and information about careers in the natural sciences.

image.caption: 1906 ground motion
image.alttext: Image that portrays the shaking over a 155 mile by 70 mile area covering the San Francisco Bay region.

resource.title: H.I.P. Pocket Change
resource.description: explores the history of coins. Teachers can find lesson plans on charting history with pennies, or showing students 293 ways to make change for a dollar. Students can learn how to start their own coin collection, travel back through history using coins as their guide, or design a future coin.

image.caption: Europe's one currency
image.alttext: Photo of Euro bills and coins

interestingfact.text: In 1999, the U.S. Mint began striking a new quarter every ten weeks to honor one of the 50 states?that is, five new quarters every year. The quarters are struck in the same order as the states' birthdays. Delaware's was the first quarter struck because it was the first state to sign the Constitution. Hawaii, which was the last to join the Union, will be the final quarter that will be minted.

resource.title: US Patent and Trademark Kids Pages
resource.description: invites kids to learn about inventors and intellectual property -- patents, trademarks, copyrights and trade secrets. Kids can take a patent trivia quiz, read fun facts, and learn how to apply for a patent for their own inventions.

resource.title: Celebrating America's Freedom
resource.description: is a collection of stories about some of America's most beloved customs and national symbols. Learn about the Purple Heart, the Star-Spangled Banner, and how to display the flag. Find information that can help when planning activities around national observances such as Memorial Day and Veterans Day.

resource.title: Veterans Day
resource.description: features a teachers guide that suggests classroom activities and provides information about organizing a school assembly, the Veterans History Project, the history of Veterans Day, respecting the flag, and more.

image.caption: Veterans Day school kit
image.alttext: Image of the American flag

interestingfact.text: Veterans Day is to thank and honor all those who served. Memorial Day is for remembering and honoring military personnel who died in the service of our country.

resource.title: The Bridge
resource.description: is a place where teachers can find marine science education resources that are screened by science educators and research scientists. The site features "Scuttlebutt", a discussion list, and tells about the National Ocean Sciences Bowl (NOSB), a fast-paced academic competition for high school students.

image.caption: Chesapeake Bay data buoys
image.alttext: Chesapeake Bay Recent Marine Data -- To view marine data, click a station on the map

resource.title: Papers of George Washington
resource.description: features Washington's correspondence, documents and articles, maps and images, and links to other George Washington resources on the web.

image.caption: The Lansdowne Portrait
image.alttext: 'The Lansdowne Portrait,' by Gilbert Stuart, 1796. Image courtesy National Portrait Gallery, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D.C.

resource.title: Virtual Trade Mission
resource.description: looks at the challenges and opportunities presented by a global economy. Multimedia experiential learning programs provide participants in schools, workplace learning centers, and civic forums with an introduction to emerging markets and trade and investment opportunities.

publisher.name: Department of Commerce, International Trade Administration
publisher.agency: Department of Commerce, International Trade Administration

image.caption: New Zealand 2006
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: The Global Volcanism Program (GVP)
resource.description: presents documentation of the eruptions of all volcanoes during the past 10,000 years. Visitors can review volcanic activity reports, view geographic and geologic information for all Holocene volcanoes (those with known activity during the last 10,000 years), and order research and publications by Smithsonian volcanologists and their colleagues.

image.caption: Merapi
image.alttext: Incandescent rockfalls accompanying slow growth of the summit lava dome descend from beneath a cloudcap covering the summit of Merapi volcano in this 1993 nighttime view. Photo by Ruska Hadian, 1993

resource.title: VRoma Project
resource.description: is a community of teachers and students who help to create online resources for teaching Latin and ancient Roman culture and who use these resources in their courses. Students and instructors can interact live and share resources for the study of the ancient world.

image.caption: Pompeii sundial
image.alttext: View of sundial in Pompeii

resource.title: Truman Presidential Library and Museum
resource.description: helps students and educators work with primary source materials. The project offers documents, photographs, records, cartoons, and other archival material for research projects.

image.caption: Nov. 2, 1948
image.alttext: President Truman holding Nov. 3, 1948 edition of 'Chicago Daily Tribune' with a headline that proclaims 'Dewey Defeats Truman.'

interestingfact.text: ore than once, Truman had said he might like to try his hand at politics. In late 1921, he got his chance. Jim Pendergast and his father, Mike, asked him to run for the Jackson County Court. Truman was elected Eastern Judge and later served two terms as Presiding Judge.

resource.title: Beyond Discovery
resource.description: traces the origins of technological and medical advances. Learn about the genetics of ear wax, a vaccine to control malaria, DNA barcoding, aging and the human brain, a genetic classification of dog breeds, the discovery of the first "speech and language" gene, how living organisms tune in to the time of day, and more.

image.caption: Designer seeds
image.alttext: The mature cotton boll pictured at right was protected by a gene for Bt; other bolls show damage from cotton pests (Photo courtesy of the U.S. Department of Agriculture-Agricultural Research Service).

resource.title: Images from the History of Medicine
resource.description: is a collection of nearly 60,000 images that illustrate the social and historical aspects of medicine. The collection includes portraits, pictures of institutions, caricatures, genre scenes, and graphic art in various media.

image.caption: Tumors of the eyelid
image.alttext: Bartisch, Georg, 1535-ca.1607, author. [Tumors of the eyelid] [Dreszden: Matthes Stöckel], 1583.

resource.title: American Roots Music
resource.description: is the website for the PBS series by the same name. It includes summaries of episodes, oral histories, information about songs and artists, and more.

image.caption: Riley
image.alttext: B.B. King is also one of its most prolific performers. A singer-guitarist who was born in Mississippi, who made his mark in Memphis

resource.title: Ancient Near East and the Mediterranean World
resource.description: displays deteriorated research materials relating to the history, art, and archaeology of the ancient Near East and the ancient Mediterranean world. Most of the materials were published between 1850-1950 and are drawn from the University of Chicago Library's Ancient Near East and Classics Collections.

image.caption: The Hill of Ophel
image.alttext: Excavations on the Hill of Ophel, Jerusalem 1923-1925, Frontispiece (b)

resource.title: Aramaic Lexicon
resource.description: will cover all dialects and periods of ancient Aramaic, one of the principal languages of antiquity, with a literature of central importance to history and particularly to the Jewish and Christian religions.

publisher.name: Hebrew Union College, Jewish Institute of Religion

resource.title: Archeology for Interpreters, A Guide to the Knowledge of the Resource
resource.description: can help students learn about archeological methods and how archeological interpretations are made. It is organized around questions that include: What is archeology? What do archeologists do? How do archeologists determine how old things are?

image.caption: Cultural traditions
image.alttext: Nez Pierce tribal traditions are preserved at Montana's Big Hole National Battlefield.

resource.title: Around the World in 1896
resource.description: is a lesson in which students take a trip around the world in 1896 using an online collection of 900 images. The collection includes photos of railroads, elephants, camels, horses, sleds and sleighs, sedan chairs, rickshaws, and other types of transportation, as well as city views, street and harbor scenes, landscapes, and people in North Africa, Asia, Australia, and Oceania.

image.caption: A hand-car in the Bolan Pass
image.alttext: Four turbanned natives pushing Pangborn in hand-car in Bolan Pass. Jackson, William Henry, 1843-1942, photographer.

resource.title: A Date Which Will Live in Infamy
resource.description: shows the typewritten draft of the December 8, 1941, speech in which Franklin Roosevelt asked Congress to declare war on Japan. The draft shows Roosevelt's hand-written edits, including his change of the phrase "a date which will live in world history" to "a date which will live in infamy." Students can also listen to the beginning of the speech.

image.caption: ...live in infamy...
image.alttext: Anotated Typewritten Copy 'Day of Infamy' Speech. Franklin D. Roosevelt Library Speeches of President, Franklin D. Roosevelt, 1933-1945

interestingfact.text: On December 8, at 12:30 p.m., Roosevelt addressed a joint session of Congress and the nation via radio. The Senate responded with a unanimous vote in support of war; only Montana pacifist Jeanette Rankin dissented in the House. At 4:00 p.m. that same afternoon, President Roosevelt signed the declaration of war.

resource.title: ABC's of Nuclear Science
resource.description: introduces the object that contains almost all of the mass in the universe, the atomic nucleus. Antimatter, beta rays, fission and fusion, the structure of the atomic nucleus, how elements on the earth were produced, how we use the nucleus in every day life, and the effects of radiation in the environment are among the topics. The site includes nearly a dozen experiments that can be done in chemistry and physics classes, along with "A Teacher's Guide to the Nuclear Science Wall Chart."

image.caption: Nuclear wall chart
image.alttext: Image of nuclear energy

resource.title: Adoration of the Magi
resource.description: is a streaming slideshow that lets viewers hear an explanation while viewing this Renaissance painting of thee kings bearing gifts for the Christ Child.

image.caption: The Adoration of the Magi -- details
image.alttext: Fra Angelico and Fra Filippo Lippi, 'The Adoration of the Magi,' c. 1440/1460. Samuel H. Kress Collection, 1952.2.2

resource.title: American Masters: Edward Curtis
resource.description: offers an essay, timeline, and other information about this photographer who took more than 40,000 images and recorded rare ethnographic information from over 80 American Indian tribal groups, ranging from the Eskimo or Inuit people of the far north to the Hopi people of the Southwest. This is the companion website for a PBS film about Curtis, "Coming to Light."

image.caption: Timeline
image.alttext: Image of Edward Curtis

resource.title: American Revolutionary War: Morristown National Historic Park
resource.description: describes the mansion and environs where General Washington and his aides were headquartered for 200 days. It was here in the Ford Mansion that he met with officers, scouts, spies, statesmen, and foreign diplomats. His troops -- the Continental Army of over 10,000 soldiers -- were encamped on the windswept hills and farmland nearby, where they built a "log-house city" of more than 1,000 structures. Washington had selected this site in Morristown, NJ, for strategic reasons.

image.caption: General George Washington's suit
image.alttext: Worn by George Washington on the day of his inauguration, April 30, 1789. It was not worn during the ceremonies, but sometime during that day.

resource.title: Ashland, Oregon -- From Stagecoach to Center Stage
resource.description: highlights 32 historic places in this community located 14 miles north of California at the foot of Mt. Ashland. These places together illustrate the development of Ashland from a small transportation and farming center founded in 1852 into a community with a strong cultural identity.

image.caption: John McCall house
image.alttext: Newly restored, the McCall House is currently a bed and breakfast. Photograph courtesy of Millis McLaughlin

resource.title: All History Is Local: Students as Archivists
resource.description: tells how students at the Arkansas School for Mathematics and Sciences analyzed archival materials, developed digital collections, and made their projects available online in the Arkansas Memory Project. This learning activity, modeled after the Library of Congress's American Memory project, is designed so that teachers and students from other states and communities may adapt it to create their own local history Memory Projects.

image.caption: Hot Springs --1910
image.alttext: Panoramic View, Hot Springs, Arkansas, 1910

resource.title: Asian-Pacific Heritage Month
resource.description: provides information about the historical contributions of Asian and Pacific peoples in the U.S. and territories. It includes links to Pacific Islander heritage and Asian American heritage websites.

resource.title: Ask Dr. Global Change
resource.description: offers a searchable collection of answers to questions about global warming, ozone depletion, greenhouse gases, and other issues related to climate change. Students can also submit questions of their own and explore related links.

image.caption: Impacts, adaptation and vulnerability
image.alttext: Cover of publication, 'Climate Change 2001: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability'

resource.title: Attu: North American Battleground of World War II
resource.description: is the site of the only land battle on the North American continent during World War II. In June 1942, Japanese forces invaded Attu and other Aleautian islands. Americans feared the islands would be used as a staging area to attack the mainland. The U.S. had to regain the Aleutians at all costs.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Massacre Bay
image.alttext: Seventh Infantry Division troops landing at Massacre Bay, Attu, May 1943. (Courtesy Elmendorf Air Force Base History Office, Alaska)

resource.title: A Visual Sourcebook of Chinese Civilization
resource.description: features units on Chinese history, culture, and society. Each unit organizes photos, maps, and art around a theme: China's geography, archaeology, religion, calligraphy, military technology, painting, homes, gardens, clothing, and the graphic arts. Questions highlight key facets of Chinese culture: Why is calligraphy highly ranked as an art form in China? Over what kinds of terrain did Chinese civilization spread?

image.caption: Paintings
image.alttext: Chinese paintings

resource.title: A Walk Through Time
resource.description: looks at the evolution of timekeeping?how humans have measured the passage of time throughout history. The site describes and shows depictions of ancient calendars, sun and water clocks, mechanical and quartz clocks, and world time scales and time zones.

publisher.name: National Institute of Standards and Technology
publisher.agency: National Institute of Standards and Technology

image.caption: Ancient calendars
image.alttext: Artist's drawing of Stonehenge

interestingfact.text: April 1 has long been an opportunity for children to tease their teachers.

resource.title: Chicago Anarchists on Trial: Evidence from the Haymarket Affair, 1886-1887
resource.description: showcases more than 3,800 images of original manuscripts, broadsides, photographs, prints, and artifacts relating to the violent 1886 confrontation between Chicago police and labor protesters that was a pivotal setback in the struggle for American workers' rights.

image.caption: Deeply troubled by events?
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Children in Urban America
resource.description: shows how children experienced city life during the last century and a half. The site features hundreds of documents and images about children in Milwaukee County, Wisconsin, drawn from newspapers, government, and other official records, oral histories and memoirs, and other sources.

resource.title: Copyright on the Web
resource.description: answers 11 questions students, teachers, & parents may have about using web images, sound recordings, and text in papers, presentations, and web projects.

resource.title: Create a Graph
resource.description: helps students create their own graphs and charts. This online tool can be used to make five kinds of charts and graphs: bar graphs, line graphs, area graphs, pie charts, and XY plots.

image.caption: Number of postsecondary institutions
image.alttext: Bar graph showing the number of postsecondary institutions in four states.

interestingfact.text: A variable is an object, event, idea, feeling, time period, or any other type of category you are trying to measure. There are two types of variables-independent and dependent.

resource.title: Creating Hypertext Dialogues Drawn from Narrative History Collections
resource.description: invites students to use documents from "California As I Saw It: First Person Narratives, 1849-1900," to create hyperscripts depicting the motivations, expectations, fears, and realizations of immigrants who settled California between 1849 and 1900. Students' hyperscripts are online written dialogues that include links to illustrative written materials, images, and sound files from American Memory collections.

image.caption: Gold discovered in Colo.
image.alttext: Where gold was firs [sic] discovered in Colo., near Idaho Spgs. / photo. by L.C. McClure, Denver, [between 1890 and 1910].

resource.title: Coffeyville, Kansas: The Town That Stopped the Dalton Gang
resource.description: recounts the bank robbery attempt that made Coffeyville famous in 1892. Bob Dalton's gang had been robbing trains, stealing horses, and looting gambling houses in the Midwest. But Dalton wanted more. He claimed he would "beat anything Jesse James ever did?rob two banks at once, in broad daylight." This is the story of his attempt to do so and the response he met from the citizens of this small southeastern Kansas town.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: The Dalton Gang
image.alttext: Bodies of the Dalton Gang after the shoot-out. (Kansas State Historical Society)

resource.title: Azoria Project: Excavation of an Early Iron Age-Archaic Town in Eastern Crete, Greece
resource.description: represents an excavation of an Early Iron Age and Archaic (ca. 1200-480 B.C.) site on the island of Crete in the Greek Aegean. The project examines how this urban settlement developed from the Bronze Age until its establishment as a regional center in the Early Iron Age.

publisher.name: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

image.caption: On the island of Crete
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: BAM! Body and Mind
resource.description: includes a Teacher's Corner with middle school classroom activities based on national education standards for science and health. The site is designed to answer students' questions on health and science topics and recommend ways to make their bodies and minds healthier, stronger, and safer. Fun activities teach about issues ranging from stress, and physical activity, and asthma to epidemiology and a West Nile virus investigation.

publisher.name: Centers For Disease Control and Prevention
publisher.agency: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

image.caption: Infection detection
image.alttext: New York City. Central Park. The summer of ?99. Birds were dying of a mysterious illness. So were people. What was the cause? Was there a connection? Leave it to Team CDC to find the answers

resource.title: Bears of Yellowstone, Yellowstone Electronic Field Trip
resource.description: presents 40 photos of grizzlies and black bears fishing, traveling with their cubs, and in various other activities and habitats.

image.caption: Grizzly bear cubs
image.alttext: Grizzly Bear Cubs Less than One Year Old

resource.title: Biotechnology Education Program
resource.description: offers lessons and learning activities on acids and bases, diffraction, DNA fingerprinting and criminal evidence, electrophoresis (a tool molecular geneticists use to separate DNA, proteins, and other molecules), and other topics related to genetic engineering and testing.

image.caption: Logo
image.alttext: See caption below.

resource.title: Fusion: Physics of a Fundamental Energy Source
resource.description: provides introductory educational materials on fusion, the process that powers the sun and other stars; and plasmas, known as the "fourth state of matter."

image.caption: Conditions for fusion
image.alttext: Laser-beam-driven fusion

resource.title: Genomics and Its Impact on Science and Society
resource.description: examines the human genome project?what's been learned so far, anticipated benefits, and societal concerns. This site also provides information about genomics (the study of genes) and the genome (the exact instructions required to create a particular organism).

image.caption: Deinococcus radiodurans
image.alttext: Survives extremely high levels of radiation and has high potential for radioactive waste cleanup.

resource.title: Boston's Arnold Arboretum: A Place for Study and Recreation
resource.description: provides readings, maps, and lesson ideas about the first arboretum in the U.S., which opened to the public in the 1880s. This site, though focused on a place devoted to the study of trees, can help students learn how 19th-century urban conditions influenced the development of parks and how to research the history of parks in their own communities.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
