publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Sketch of the inauguration
image.alttext: Sketch of the inauguration, September 14, 1901. (National Park Service)

resource.title: These Honored Dead: The Battle of Rivers Bridge and Civil War Combat Casualties
resource.description: recounts a battle in a cold, rainy swamp in South Carolina during the last year of the war. In contrast to major campaigns and battles, this small battle presents the war on a human scale. Through maps, illustrations, photos, and descriptions, one can comprehend the entire battlefield and tactics used there. Excerpts from letters help students see the war and its effects from the perspective of individual commanders and soldiers.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Road at the swamp crossings
image.alttext: Sherman's March through South Carolina -- Road at the Swamp Crossings. (Courtesy of the University of Michigan Digital Library Production Service)

resource.title: Edison Invents
resource.description: examines several of his inventions?the telegraph, telephone, phonograph, and electric light bulb. Students learn about his life and how to create their own light bulb.

image.caption: Edison, 1895
image.alttext: Photo of Edison at the ore mill in Ogdensburg, N.J., 1895. (Edison National Historic Site 14.610/17

interestingfact.text: Thomas Alva Edison (nicknamed Al) was born on February 11, 1847, in Milan, Ohio. Edison was an inquisitive boy who began experimenting at an early age.

resource.title: Thomas Gainsborough
resource.description: presents 12 paintings that illustrate the range, richness, and originality of this British master of 18th-century portraits and landscapes. Gainsborough's works are characterized by noble and graceful figures, poetic landscapes, and fancy depictions of the rural poor.

image.caption: Cottage Girl with Dog and Pitcher
image.alttext: Thomas Gainsborough, 'Cottage Girl with Dog and Pitcher,' 1785. oil on canvas -- National Gallery of Ireland, Dublin

resource.title: Thomas Jefferson's Plan for the University of Virginia: Lessons from the Lawn
resource.description: tells the story of the creation of the University of Virginia. After serving as President, Jefferson continued advocating for a statewide system of education in Virginia, hoping to extend education beyond the elite to the common man. Although the Virginia legislature refused to fund a plan for primary and secondary education, when it approved funding in 1818 to establish a state university, Jefferson immediately drew architectural plans for his ideal university.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Students on the lawn
image.alttext: Students on the Lawn, 19th Century. (Valentine Richmond History Center, Richmond, Virginia)

resource.title: Thurmond: A Town Born from Coal Mines and Railroads
resource.description: recounts the story of the New River Gorge area in West Virginia. It is mountainous and remained sparsely populated and largely inaccessible until 1873, when the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company laid track through the gorge. Coal mining companies, towns, and camps appeared almost overnight to mine the coal deposits. One of these towns, the railroading town of Thurmond, reached its peak as the major revenue producer for the C&O Railroad during the early 1900s?a time when coal was king.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: The Thurmond depot
image.alttext: A postcard picture of Thurmond depot, photographer and date unknown.

resource.title: Tips for Parents on Keeping Children Drug Free
resource.description: tells what your children should know about drugs by the time they reach the third grade, ways to help your child stay drug free in the middle and junior high school years, and how to ensure that your child's school is keeping students drug free.

resource.title: Today in History
resource.description: features a different person or event in history each day. Past features include Frederick Douglass, Woodrow Wilson, George Washington, Abraham Lincoln, Benjamin Banneker, Rosa Parks, Samuel Slater, Louisa May Alcott, Radio City Music Hall, the Wright brothers' first flight, the Bill of Rights, the Gadsden Purchase, the Federal Reserve System, the Wounded Knee massacre, Pearl Harbor, the first controlled nuclear fission chain reaction, and more.

image.caption: Edgar Allan Poe
image.alttext: Edgar Allan Poe -- Daguerreotype, 1848

resource.title: Tox Town
resource.description: is an interactive guide to toxic substances commonly found in water, rivers, offices, stores, schools, parks, homes, and factories. Substances include arsenic, asbestos, carbon monoxide, lead, mercury, ozone, radon, and toluene.

resource.title: Tracking the Buffalo: Stories From a Buffalo Hide Painting
resource.description: puts students in the role of historians as they examine a buffalo hide painting and click on areas that reveal clues to the painting's story. The story helps students understand the role of the buffalo in the lives of the American Indians of the northern plains.

image.caption: Buffalo hide painting
image.alttext: Buffalo hide painting -- Sioux. Date unknown. Cat. No. 167,147. National Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian Institution

interestingfact.text: Indians of the northern plains wore buffalo hides for both practical and ceremonial purposes. They wore buffalo hides in winter, with the fur on the inside for warmth.

resource.title: Traveling the National Road
resource.description: tells the story of the first road built with federal funds. Construction of the 632-mile road from Cumberland, Maryland, to Vandalia, Illinois, began in 1811. The aim was to improve trade between the east and the emerging western frontier and to avoid losing western trade to England in Canada or Spain in the Louisiana Territory. The website tells how the road was built, how people traveled on it, accommodations they found along the way, and more.

image.caption: Site resource list
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Valley Forge
resource.description: looks at the campsite that marked a turning point in the American Revolution. By 1777, General Washington had suffered more defeats than victories. He sought a winter campsite that would allow observation of the British army without exposure to surprise attack. In December, he led 12,000 men into Valley Forge, Pennsylvania, while the British camped 20 miles away in Philadelphia. Nearly 2,000 American soldiers died of disease. But the Continental Army learned discipline and organization.

image.caption: Artillery gun crew
image.alttext: Artillery Gun Crew (1975). Henry Knox was the Continental Artillery commander. He insisted on thorough and ongoing training for artillerists. Illustration by Don Troiani, National Park Service.

resource.title: Dr. Billy Taylor, a Conversation on Jazz
resource.description: presents excerpts from four lectures by Billy Taylor -- a noted jazz pianist, historian, and educator. He discussed jazz from its roots in the African-American slavery experience, through the early days of ragtime, and onward through swing, bop, and progressive jazz. Excerpts can be sorted by artist or jazz style. They're organized around questions, such as: Where was jazz born? How did swing become bebop? How is bebop influencing today's jazz artists?

image.caption: Dr. Billy Taylor
image.alttext: See caption below.

interestingfact.text: "[A jazz legend is] someone who has added immeasurably to the growth and development of jazz.... It could be as an artist, or someone like John Hammond, who discovered Bessie Smith...."

resource.title: Windows to the Universe
resource.description: explores the Earth, planets of our solar system, and the universe. It includes images, animations, and data sets, and information about books, movies, scientists, and myths.

image.caption: Solar eclipse
image.alttext: During a total solar eclipse, the umbra reaches the Earth. During an annular eclipse, it does not. An eclipse occurs when the Moon passes in the path of the Sun and Earth.

resource.title: Winslow Homer's Right and Left
resource.description: is a streaming slideshow of the artist's last great painting, completed the year before his death in 1910. Its title refers to a feat in hunting of shooting two ducks in rapid succession with a double-barreled shotgun?one with the right barrel, followed immediately by one with the left.

image.caption: Right and Left -- details
image.alttext: Winslow Homer, 'Right and Left,' 1909. Gift of the Avalon Foundation, 1951.8.1

resource.title: Women's History Month
resource.description: showcases historic properties that illustrate contributions of women to our nation's history. Harriet Beecher Stowe, Eleanor Ford, Amelia Earhart, Mary McLeod Bethune, and are among those featured.

image.caption: Amelia Earhart's accomplishments
image.alttext: Photo of Amelia Earhart standarding in front of a flight map.

interestingfact.text: On December 1, 1955, Rosa Parks, an African American, refused to move to the back of the bus as required by law. She sparked a 381-day bus boycott in Montgomery, Ala., that led to a 1956 Supreme Court decision banning segregation on public transportation.

resource.title: Woody Guthrie and the Archive of American Folk Song: Correspondence, 1940-1950
resource.description: highlights letters Guthrie wrote in the early 1940s after moving to New York City, where he pursued broadcasting and recording careers, met artists and social activists, and gained a reputation as a songwriter and performer. The site includes a biographical essay, a timeline of Guthrie's life, and an encoded finding aid of Guthrie materials at the Library of Congress.

image.caption: Woody Guthrie
image.alttext: [Woody Guthrie, half-length portrait, facing front, playing guitar] New York World-Telegram and the Sun Newspaper Photograph Collection (Library of Congress).

resource.title: Working on the Past in Local Historic Districts
resource.description: tells about "local preservation ordinances"?what they are, how they work, and how they are making a difference for some of the 2,300 local historic districts.

resource.title: Yiddish Radio Project
resource.description: preserves recordings from the golden age of Yiddish radio (1930s-50s). Online exhibits include "Yiddish melodies in Swing," the history of Yiddish radio, "Rabbi Rubin's Court of the Air," radio dramas of Nahum Stutchkoff, "Levine and His Flying Machine," and commercials on Yiddish radio. Audio clips accompany each exhibit.

image.caption: Joe and Paul
image.alttext: The Barton Brothers inherited Red Button's 'Joe and Paul' routine and turned into one of the best selling Jewish albums of all time.

resource.title: You Be the Conservator
resource.description: invites students to play the role of a museum conservator, discovering clues about an historical object in order to preserve or restore it. In the featured activity, the object is a "santo," a painted woodcarving of a saint in the Catholic Church.

resource.title: You Be the Historian
resource.description: invites students to examine clues and determine what life was like for a family that lived in New Castle, Delaware, during the 1700s. Students also discover what historians in the next century might learn about us if they found our homes the way they are today.

resource.title: The American Presidency: A Glorious Burden
resource.description: examines the job of a president, the balance of power with the Supreme Court and Congress, and ways presidents have communicated with the public. Features include the battle sword of George Washington, the lap desk on which Thomas Jefferson wrote the Declaration of Independence, and the top hat worn by Abraham Lincoln the night he was assassinated.

image.caption: Communicating the Presidency
image.alttext: Photo of Mount Rushmore

interestingfact.text: John and Abigail Adams moved into a partially completed White House in late 1800. Construction started eight years earlier, based on James Hoban's design in an architectural competition.

resource.title: Battle of Glorieta Pass: A Shattered Dream
resource.description: examines a Civil War battle known as the "Gettysburg of the West." Texans invaded this mountain valley, intent on conquering New Mexico. Victory here would be a necessary prelude to detaching the western states from the Union and expanding the Confederacy to the Pacific Ocean. They were met by volunteers from Colorado along the canyon and ridge on 03/26, 1862. A three-day battle ensued, culminating in the Confederates retreating to Texas and the Confederate hopes of expanding west shattered.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Pigeon's Ranch
image.alttext: Fight at Pigeon's Ranch. (Roy Anderson, artist; Courtesy of Pecos National Historical Park)

resource.title: Vanderbilt Mansion National Historic Site: Monument to the Gilded Age
resource.description: describes this Hyde Park estate that includes a palatial Beaux-Arts mansion, stunning views of the Hudson River and Catskill Mountains, and over 600 acres of landscaped property. The mansion was built in 1895-8 by Frederick Vanderbilt, an heir of the fortune created by Cornelius "Commodore" Vanderbilt. Cornelius, at the age of 16, borrowed $100 from his parents, purchased a periauger (a flat-bottomed sailing barge), and began a ferry service now known as the Staten Island Ferry.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Under construction
image.alttext: The Vanderbilt Mansion under construction, 1895.

resource.title: Virtue and Beauty
resource.description: features nearly a dozen portraits of women in Florence created between 1440 and 1540. These paintings, marble sculptures, medals, and drawings reflect a time when subjects in art expanded to include not only rulers and their consorts but also women of the merchant class.

image.caption: Fantasy beauty
image.alttext: Sandro Botticelli, 'Young Woman (Simonetta Vespucci?) in Mythological Guise,' c. 1480/1485. tempera on panel

interestingfact.text: In the first half of the sixteenth century, portraits became larger and included more of the sitter's body. This new type originated with Leonardo's Mona Lisa, which portrays the sitter in a relaxed pose with her hands resting in her lap. Bronzino reflected Leonardo's influence in his Portrait of a Lady, thought to represent Francesca Salviati at the time of her second marriage to Ottaviano de' Medici.

resource.title: Voices from the Field
resource.description: presents 10 stories written by Peace Corps authors. Lesson ideas and student work accompany the stories, which are set in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Guatemala, Guinea-Bissau, Liberia, Niger, Poland, and Papua New Guinea. Stories and accompanying materials are designed to strengthen students' reading and writing, inspire students to create their own personal meanings and narratives, and broaden students' perspectives of the world and themselves.

image.caption: Introduction to Voices -- PDF
image.alttext: Introduction to Voices, which explains how the book is organized and how best to use it.

resource.title: Water In Africa
resource.description: is designed to help students learn important knowledge and skills in geography, language arts, and other disciplines by studying the use of water in 24 African countries. This website features online lessons developed by teachers and built around 600 photos and 300 anecdotes from Peace Corps volunteers in Africa. Photos and anecdotes may also be browsed by country, with basic country information and maps provided.

image.caption: Jars of water
image.alttext: Women return home from the pump, carefully balancing clay jars full of water on their heads. By Kelley Sams Kawari, Niger (1999).

resource.title: The Battle of Midway: Turning the Tide in the Pacific
resource.description: examines a pivotal World War II battle. In the spring of 1942, Japan attempted to establish a toehold in the Aleutian Islands, convert Midway into an air base for invading Hawaii, and lure the U.S. Pacific Fleet into a final battle that would finish it off. The Japanese fleet depended on radio codes that codebreakers in Hawaii and Washington, D.C. worked around the clock to interpret. This website tells how they broke the code and ended Japan's advance across the Pacific.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Yorktown, 1942
image.alttext: Bombing of U.S. carrier Yorktown, 1942. (National Archives and Records Administration)

resource.title: Watershed Ecology
resource.description: introduces basic watershed ecology concepts. It examines the physical forces that shape watershed ecosystems, plants and animals that inhabit them, typical watershed structures, and how watersheds function -- at different geographic scales and over time.

image.caption: Watershed ecology module
image.alttext: In this Watershed Ecology module, you have been introduced to the most basic features of an exceedingly complex type of natural system

resource.title: We the People... The Citizen and the Constitution
resource.description: helps elementary and secondary school students understand the history and principles of our constitutional government. The program focuses on the U.S. Constitution and Bill of Rights and fosters civic competence and responsibility. Upon completion of program, classes are encouraged to participate in simulated congressional hearings that allow students to demonstrate their knowledge of the Constitution and the Bill of Rights.

resource.title: West Building: Then and Now
resource.description: celebrates the 60th anniversary (March 2001) of the opening of the National Gallery of Art. An online photo essay shows how the West Building and its environment have changed over the years.

resource.title: The Battle of Oriskany: Blood Shed a Stream Running Down
resource.description: tells how long-standing prejudices and the Revolutionary War unleashed massive bloodshed among inhabitants of New York's Mohawk Valley. Located in rich farmland and at a strategic point in a fur trade route, the valley had been settled by European immigrants who had prospered from productive farms and lucrative trade. As war broke out, everyone had to choose sides: Rebel or Tory. It was not easy for many. Five hundred years of unity among the Six Nations was broken.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Battle of Oriskany
image.alttext: Battle of Oriskany. Painted by Frederick C. Yohn, 1977. (Courtesy of Utica Public Library)

resource.title: Westward by Sea: A Maritime Perspective on American Expansion, 1820-1890
resource.description: presents letters, business papers, photos, maps, ship logbooks, and narratives that can help students understand the story of American's travel by sea to settle California, Alaska, Hawaii, Texas, and the Pacific Northwest. Themes illustrated by these materials, selected from Mystic Seaport's collection, include whaling, life at sea, the California Gold Rush, and native populations.

image.caption: Rotch fleet
image.alttext: Rotch fleet among school of sperm whales

resource.title: What Are We Fighting for Over There? Perspectives on the Great War
resource.description: is a unit in which students use primary documents to develop an understanding of the World War I era, including how the U.S. prepared for and participated in the war and how the war foreshadowed the role of the U.S. as a world power of the 20th century.

image.caption: Company I, ca. 1919
image.alttext: Company 'I', 102 Inf., 2b Div., A.E.F.. c1919. Copyright deposit; Juan Casablanca; April 26, 1919; DLC/PP-1919:45950. Copyright claimant's address: Newport, R.I.

resource.title: The Battle of Prairie Grove: Civilian Recollections of the Civil War
resource.description: helps students place the Battle of Prairie Grove in the context of Arkansas' role in the Civil War. Photos and readings from eye witness accounts of the battle depict the harsh realities of Civil War and its effects on both soldiers and civilians.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Nancy Morton Staples, 1913
image.alttext: Nancy Morton Staples in front of the Morton Home, c. 1913. (Prairie Grove Battlefield State Park)

resource.title: Battle of Stones River: The Soldiers' Story
resource.description: provides readings, maps, and visual representations of this battle near Murfreesboro, Tennessee, which was the second bloodiest battle fought west of the Appalachians during the Civil War.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Chaos and destruction
image.alttext: A view of the chaos and destruction of the Battle of Stones River as painted by William Travis, c. 1865.

resource.title: What Is an American?
resource.description: invites students to look at life histories from the interviews of everyday Americans conducted by Works Progress Administration officials between 1936-1940 and determine to what extent Jean de Crèvecoeur's "definition of an American" holds true today. In Letters from an American Farmer, published in 1782, Crèvecoeur wrote that an American, if he were "honest, sober and industrious," prospered in a welcoming land of opportunity.

image.caption: Bethlehem-Fairfield shipyards
image.alttext: Bethlehem-Fairfield shipyards, Baltimore, Maryland. Lunch time. Siegel, Arthur S., photographer.

subject.subcategory: Other History & Social Studies: U.S. History Time Periods

resource.title: Campaign for Vicksburg, 1863
resource.description: describes the effort of the Union Army of Tennessee to capture Vicksburg, Mississippi. Taking Vicksburg was the key to ending the Civil War. It was the key to regaining control of the lower Mississippi River, which had been lost when Confederate forces closed the river. Regaining control of this area and the river, the most important economic feature of the continent, would allow the rich agricultural produce of the Northwest to reach world markets. It would also split the South in two.

image.caption: Confederate fortifications
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: The Church in the Southern Black Community, 1780-1925
resource.description: traces how Southern African-Americans experienced Protestant Christianity and transformed it into the central institution of community life. Coverage begins with white churches' conversion efforts and depicts the contradictions between the egalitarian potential of evangelical Christianity and the realities of slavery. It focuses on how the black community adapted evangelical Christianity, making it a metaphor for freedom, community, and personal survival.

image.caption: Trinity Church, Augusta, GA
image.alttext: Photo of Trinity Church, Augusta, GA

interestingfact.text: Emancipation from slavery in 1863 posed distinctive religious challenges for African Americans in the South. When the Civil War finally brought freedom, the task of organizing religious communities was only one element of the larger need to create new lives -- to reunite families, to find jobs, and to figure out what it would mean to live in the United States as citizens rather than property.

resource.title: The Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission
resource.description: provides a summary, history, and teaching activities related to the EEOC and this historic law, which forbade discrimination on the basis of sex as well as race in hiring, promoting, and firing.

image.caption: Title I -- Voting Rights
image.alttext: Image of the Civil Rights Act of 1964

resource.title: The Constitution: Counter Revolution or National Salvation?
resource.description: casts students in the role of politically active citizens in 1787, when the Federal Convention in Philadelphia presented the nation with a new model of government. Students, using primary documents from American Memory, produce a broadside in which they argue for or against replacing the Articles of Confederation with the new model?the Constitution.

image.caption: Join, or die
image.alttext: 'Join, or Die,' Woodcut, in The Pennsylvania Gazette, May 9, 1754.

resource.title: The Emerald Necklace: Boston's Green Connection
resource.description: recounts the creation of a series of parks in Boston in the 1880s. At that time, Boston was crammed with buildings and people. It was overcrowded, noisy, and dirty. City officials, concerned about the health and well-being of Bostonians, hired Frederick Law Olmsted, who had designed Central Park in New York, to create a park system that wove together a series of small parks?gardens, waterways, meadows, tree museums, and others?into what became known as Boston's Emerald Necklace.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

resource.title: The Forts of Old San Juan: Guardians of the Caribbean
resource.description: provides a history of Puerto Rico and the forts Spain established on the island to help protect its growing population and riches in the Caribbean.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: El Morro
image.alttext: El Morro and the western part of San Juan. (National Park Service)

resource.title: The Frederick Douglass Papers at the Library of Congress
resource.description: presents the papers of the 19th-century African-American abolitionist who escaped from slavery and then risked his own freedom by becoming an outspoken antislavery lecturer, writer, and publisher. The first release of the Douglass Papers contains 2,000 items (16,000 images) that span the years 1841 to 1964 and relate to Douglass's life as an escaped slave, abolitionist, editor, orator, and public servant.

image.caption: Frederick Douglass
image.alttext: Newspaper clipping, about Frederick Douglass, '...the peerless and Inimitable Orator, who speaks at People's church next Thursday Evening.'

interestingfact.text: To understand Frederick Douglass, his struggles, and the times he lived in, one must read about his life in his own words. Douglass wrote three autobiographies: The Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave; My Bondage and My Freedom; and The Life and Times of Frederick Douglass. Two are part of the American Memory online collections at the Library of Congress.

resource.title: Alcatraz Island
resource.description: is home to one of the world?s most infamous prisons. From the 1930s to 1960s, Alcatraz was the premier maximum security prison, housing inmates such as Al Capone and George "Machine Gun" Kelly. Before the prison was created, the island was home to American Indians. Today, it is one of San Francisco's most prominent tourist attractions.

resource.title: Document Analysis Worksheets
resource.description: are designed for students to use when analyzing photos, maps, cartoons, posters, artifacts, sound recordings, motion pictures, and written documents (memos, news articles, ads, patents, and others).

resource.title: Eleanor Roosevelt: American Visionary
resource.description: features photos and artifacts from the life of one of the most dynamic and controversial First Ladies in U.S. history. She was the first First Lady to hold regular press conferences and to routinely travel the nation. She held prestigious positions throughout her life, serving as delegate to the newly founded United Nations, draftee of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, and chair of the first Presidential Commission on the Status of Women.

image.caption: Eleanor Roosevelt, 1950
image.alttext: Image of Eleanor Roosevelt, 1950 -- FDR Library 09-2466

resource.title: Women Writers Resource Project
resource.description: is a collection of edited and unedited texts by women writing in English from the 17th century through the 19th century. The project offers graduate and undergraduate students the opportunity to edit texts. A complete list of unedited texts, suggestions for assignments, bibliographic resources, and examples of graduate student work are available.

image.caption: Mary Shelley
image.alttext: Portrait of Mary Shelley, the mother of Frankenstein who came from the rarefied reaches of the British artistic and intellectual elite.

resource.title: Captured Wisdom on Adult Literacy
resource.description: is a series of stories about adult literacy teaching success. In one story, adults learning English use the Internet to find pictures and information about their home country for written and oral reports. In another, adult students act as consultants hired to save a failing restaurant and use technology to deal with irate customers, schedule work hours, and design new menus.

image.caption: Antarctica project video
image.alttext: Antarctica is the fifth largest and the southernmost continent. Its position at the South Pole, together with its elevation and ice and snow cover, generates the coldest climate on earth.

resource.title: Costumes from the Index of American Design
resource.description: offers a survey of American fashions from 1740 to 1895. Most of the costumes represented are formal garments preserved and handed down in families from one generation to the next. These costumes provide insight into the character and quality of American life from colonial times to the industrial revolution. Click on a design to find its title, artist, date created, measurements, material, location, provenance, full screen image, and other information.

image.caption: Woman's Shoes
image.alttext: 'Woman's Shoes,' Rendered by Marie Alain. watercolor, graphite, and gouache on paperboard, 37.6 x 50.9 cm (14 13/16 x 20 1/16 in.) Index of American Design -- 1943.8.1907

resource.title: Captured Wisdom in Middle School
resource.description: presents stories about successful teaching in middle school. Learn how an e-mail list helped students write better historical fiction, or how fifth-grade students planned a virtual vacation using cd-roms, travel books, and the Internet.

resource.title: www.whitehousekids.gov
resource.description: provides an online tour of the White House, biographical information about the President and Vice President, and games and quizzes. It includes special features on U.S. Presidents and life in the White House, as well as a teacher's and parent's guide.

image.caption: Photo match
image.alttext: Click on the paws on the right to move the photo strips until you have a match. Once you have a match, click on the red paw to see the Barney caption for that photo!

resource.title: We the People Bookshelf
resource.description: invites schools and libraries to apply to receive 15 thematically related books that depict universal themes and key moments in American history.

image.caption: Becoming American bookshelf
image.alttext: Imagery from the cover of 'Dragonwings' by Laurence Yep

resource.title: Ask an Astronomer for Kids
resource.description: provides answers and photos for 200 common questions about astronomy and objects in space. Topics include planets, stars, the solar system, comets, asteroids, galaxies, and the night sky.

image.caption: Search for life
image.alttext: See caption below

resource.title: Stories from Space
resource.description: tells brief stories about the planets, tools used for exploring space, and "what's in space." Photos of planets, stars, telescopes, and space craft are included.

resource.title: Cool Cosmos
resource.description: invites students to learn about infrared light and step into the world of infrared astronomy. Teachers and students may discover light outside the visible spectrum with these classroom activities, experiments, and lessons. The site provides FAQs, ask-an-astronomer videos, an infrared astronomy timeline, and more.

image.caption: IR portraits
image.alttext: Image for an infrared view of boy in different colors as well as for temperature information.

interestingfact.text: Infrared light shows us the heat radiated by the world around us. By viewing animals with a thermal infrared camera, we can actually "see" the differences between warm and cold-blooded animals. Infrared also allows us to study how well feathers, fur and blubber insulate animals.

resource.title: Edward Ruscha, Lisp, 1968
resource.description: explores an in-depth study of Edward Ruscha's 1968 painting Lisp. Ruscha, one of the most compelling artists of the last 40 years, is best known for paintings in which words play a central role.Lisp exemplifies his interest in words not only for the images and meanings they suggest, but also as representational imagery and subject matter.

image.caption: Lisp
image.alttext: Image of Edward Ruscha's (American, born 1937) 'Lisp,' 1968. Oil on canvas, Gift of the Collectors Committee 2001.56.1

resource.title: Visible Earth
resource.description: is a searchable directory of images, visualizations, and animations of Earth. Topics include soils, clouds, storms, hurricanes, droughts, precipitation, vegetation, oceans, sea ice, human population, land use, erosion, fires, rocks, minerals, regions, and countries.

image.caption: Eastern United States
image.alttext: The Eastern United States. Credit: Jacques Descloitres, MODIS Land Rapid Response Team, NASA/GSFC

interestingfact.text: The brightest areas of the Earth are the most urbanized, but not necessarily the most populated. Cities tend to grow along coastlines and transportation networks. Even without the underlying map, the outlines of many continents would still be visible.

resource.title: Veterans History Project
resource.description: is collecting oral histories, letters, diaries, and photos of America's war veterans and those supported them. The project includes participants in World War I, World War II, and the Korean, Vietnam, and Persian Gulf wars. Students, citizens, and organizations are invited to contribute using the Project Kit, which provides all information and forms needed to interview a veteran. Libraries, museums, and civic groups can read about model veterans projects and start a project in their community

image.caption: Richard Henry Peterson
image.alttext: Richard Peterson, POW processing photo, 1942

interestingfact.text: D-Day was only the beginning for Allied forces intent on recapturing Europe from German domination. Alvin Dickson was one of thousands of soldiers whose job sounded simple: take back every town and every farm, and don't stop until you reach Berlin or the Germans surrender.

resource.title: Polluted Runoff
resource.description: provides lessons and activities for studying how runoff affects streams, how to analyze what's upstream and downstream from your community (watersheds), and how families can reduce "nonpoint source" pollution, which results from rainfall or snowmelt moving over and through the ground.

image.caption: Rural runoff
image.alttext: How Does Rain Become Runoff? A Rural Example

resource.title: Future State
resource.description: is the U.S. State Department's website for youth. It offers lesson plans on terrorism, Vietnam, and the Cuban Missile Crisis and information about more than 50 international issues. "Careers Representing America," games, and "Meet the Secretary of State" are among the features. Links are provided for learning about current events, geography, and the environment.

image.caption: What's happening
image.alttext: Logo of Future State at the U.S. State Department

interestingfact.text: On September 15, 1789, Congress passed "An Act to provide for the safe keeping of the Acts, Records, and Seal of the United States, and for other purposes." This law changed the name of the Department of Foreign Affairs to the Department of State because certain domestic duties were assigned to the agency.

resource.title: Online Science-athon
resource.description: helps students discover the science in their daily lives. It is organized around four events: How Tall Am I? (Grades 2-3), the Marble Roll (Grades 4-8), Catching Sunshine, and the Chocolate Melt. The site makes it easy for teachers to incorporate the events into instruction, align learning with academic standards, and get students investigating their world in ways that are fun and instructive. Each event produces class data and includes questions for exploring student-generated data.

resource.title: ISS EarthKAM
resource.description: offers thousands of images of Earth and guides for using them to support instruction in Earth science, space science, geography, social studies, math, and other subjects. Images can be searched by country or geographic feature (island, archipelago, peninsula, canyon, and others). Photos were taken by a digital camera mounted on the International Space Station (ISS) under the direction and control of students.

image.caption: Cape Cod and Boston
image.alttext: ISS EarthKAM image of Cape Cod and Boston, Massachusetts superimposed over a Jet Navigation Chart.

interestingfact.text: An orbit is a fixed path in space that the spacecraft follows. Depending on the mission, the size, shape, and orientation of an orbit will vary. A satellite is any object in orbital motion (sun, moon, earth, spacecraft, and shuttle).

resource.title: Study of Place
resource.description: offers two online science units for middle-school students. Antarctic Exploration tells the story of Sir Ernest Shackleton's 1914 expedition to Antarctica and how, when his ship became icebound and was crushed to pieces, he and his crew survived before being rescued two years after their journey began. Ocean Currents Exploration tells how Ben Franklin charted the Gulf Stream, a current in the Atlantic Ocean, to help speed mail delivery from Europe to the U.S.

image.caption: Endurance in the ice
image.alttext: Image of the 'Endurance' in the ice. Image Courtesy of Royal Geographic Society.

interestingfact.text: In the third century B.C., the Greek astronomer and mathematician Eratosthenes estimated the Earth's size by comparing the shadows cast at two locations at noon. He used his knowledge of triangles, circles, and angles to calculate the Earth's circumference to within one percent of the actual measurement.

resource.title: Pottery from the Index of American Design
resource.description: shows the variety of pottery made in America in the 18th and 19th centuries. Pottery making was among the earliest of American crafts.

resource.title: Search the National Gallery of Art
resource.description: lets you search the Gallery's collection by artist, title, style, medium, keyword or phrase for teaching resources, and more than 25 themes?allegory, animal, landscape, magic, military, religious, still life, and others. An alphabetical index of artists is included.

image.caption: Ant
image.alttext: M.C. Escher [Dutch, 1898 - 1972], 'Ant,' 1943. lithograph; Rosenwald Collection. All M.C. Escher works © Cordon Art-Baarn-the Netherlands.

resource.title: Shaker Crafts from the Index of American Design
resource.description: presents six objects that show simplicity of form and harmony among parts, two principles of Shaker craftsmanship.

image.caption: Shaker Tall Clock
image.alttext: 'Shaker Tall Clock,' Rendered by Irving I. Smith. watercolor, graphite, pen and ink, and gouache on paperboard, 31.9 x 22.2 cm (12 9/16 x 8 3/4 in.) Index of American Design, 1943.8.13585

resource.title: Photographs from the Chicago Daily News: 1902-1933
resource.description: comprises over 55,000 images of urban life captured on glass plate negatives between 1902 and 1933 by photographers employed by the Chicago Daily News, then one of Chicago's leading newspapers. The photographs illustrate the enormous variety of topics and events covered in the newspaper, although only about twenty percent of the images in the collection were published in the newspaper. Most of the photographs were taken in Chicago, Illinois, or in nearby towns, parks, or athletic fields.

image.caption: A World Series at Wrigley
image.alttext: Photo of Wrigley Field in Chicago, Illinois, during a 1929 World Series game between the National League's Chicago Cubs and the American League's Philadelphia Athletics.

interestingfact.text: For the first twenty years of the twentieth century, horse-drawn vehicles coexisted with newer means of transportation. There was the Loop (elevated trains running above the streets), electric-powered streetcars (trolley cars running on rails along the streets), and new gasoline-powered automobiles and trucks.

resource.title: NGA Loan Materials Finder
resource.description: lists slide shows, multimedia programs, videocassettes, CDs, and videodiscs available from the National Gallery of Art. Various artists, subjects, techniques, and styles are examined in the programs, which are designed for use in grades kindergarten through 12.

image.caption: Art Nouveau, 1890-1914
image.alttext: Art nouveau was one of the most innovative and exuberant of the modern art movements.

resource.title: Textiles from the Index of American Design
resource.description: presents rugs, quilts, and coverlets made by American women in the 18th and 19th centuries, articles made by professional weavers, and fabrics produced by textile mills in America's early years of industrialization.

resource.title: The Quilt Index
resource.description: is a hub of information on American quilts and quilt-making. It now features images and documentation for hundreds of quilts from Kentucky, Tennessee, Michigan, and Illinois. An online discussion is open to anyone interested in the documentation or study of quilts, quilters, and quilting history.

image.caption: Feathered star
image.alttext: Feathered Star -- detail -- quilted by Wilson, Sara Ross, 1800-1849, made in Tennessee (TN) USA

resource.title: Battle of Honey Springs: The Civil War Comes to the Indian Territory
resource.description: illustrates how the war, when it moved to the rolling prairie of now eastern Oklahoma, divided Native Americans. It includes maps, soldiers' accounts of the battle, and illustrations.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: The battle
image.alttext: The Battle of Honey Springs. (Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper)

resource.title: High School Environmental Center
resource.description: is a portal to environmental resources. It organizes sites by topics: air pollution, climate change, global warming; conservation of energy, soil, and water; coral reefs, forests, watersheds, and other ecosystems; drinking water, waste water, ground water; asthma, lead, pesticides, sun protection, and other health issues; waste and recycling; and local data and maps.

image.caption: Ecosystems
image.alttext: An ecosystem is defined as a place having unique physical features, encompassing air, water, and land, and habitats supporting plant and animal life.

interestingfact.text: Acid rain is measured using a scale called "pH." The lower a substance's pH, the more acidic it is. Pure water has a pH of 7.0. Normal rain is slightly acidic because carbon dioxide dissolves into it, so it has a pH of about 5.5. As of the year 2000, the most acidic rain falling in the US has a pH of about 4.3.

resource.title: Picasso: The Cubist Portraits of Fernande Olivier
resource.description: displays 16 portraits of Picasso's companion, Fernande Olivier. They're from a series of 60 portraits Picasso created of Olivier between spring and fall in 1909. This series is virtually unprecedented in its devotion to a single subject. The exhibit (through January 18, 2004) reveals Picasso's exploration of cubism and his reformulation of human physiognomy.

image.caption: Woman in Green
image.alttext: Woman in Green, Paris, fall-winter 1909-1910, oil on canvas, Van Abbemuseum, Eindhoven © 2003 Estate of Pablo Picasso / Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York

interestingfact.text: Pablo Ruiz y Picasso (1881-1973) is generally considered the most influential artist of the 20th century. He was unique as an innovator of styles and techniques and one of the most prolific artists in history, creating more than 20,000 works. Shortly after moving to Paris in 1904, Picasso met Fernande Olivier (1881-1966), who soon became his companion. An artist's model, "la belle Fernande" was the inspiration for numerous works during the course of their relationship.

resource.title: The Age of Watteau, Chardin, and Fragonard: Masterpieces of French Genre Painting
resource.description: is the first comprehensive exhibit devoted to paintings of scenes from daily life, real and imagined, in French art of the 18th century. A brochure, available online, presents 13 pieces from the exhibit and a narrative describing each painting and artist. The paintings include lyrical pastorals, Paris street scenes, and dignified representations of bourgeois life.

image.caption: The Marriage Contract
image.alttext: Jean-Baptiste Greuze, 'The Marriage Contract,' 1761. Musee du Louvre, Paris

resource.title: The Art of Romare Bearden
resource.description: includes more than 30 pieces from this comprehensive retrospective. A preeminent artist of his generation, Bearden (1911-1988) was known for his collages; however, he also produced paintings, drawings, murals, and theater sets and costumes. Themes in his works include religious subjects, rituals, jazz clubs, and history and literature. This website offers a special feature, teaching packet, children's guide, and interactive collage-making tool for kids (of all ages).

image.caption: Now the Dove and the Leopard Wrestle
image.alttext: Romare Bearden, 'Now the Dove and the Leopard Wrestle,' 1946, oil on canvas. Clements Library, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. © Romare Bearden Foundation/Licensed by VAGA, New York, N.Y.

resource.title: Modeling for Understanding in Science Education (MUSE)
resource.description: offers instructional units in earth-moon-sun dynamics and natural selection. These units were produced though a collaborative project involving university researchers, high school teachers, and students. Each unit contains extensive information and materials for use in middle or high school.

image.caption: Earth & moon dynamics
image.alttext: Black and white photo of the moon, sun and Venus

interestingfact.text: Evolution, the conceptual cornerstone of biology, provides a lens though which each of the sub-disciplines in the biological sciences can be viewed.

resource.title: Treasury's Learning Vault
resource.description: recounts the history of the Treasury Department and tells what each office and bureau does. A tour of the Department, fact sheets, and frequently asked questions are provided.

resource.title: U.S. Global Change Research Program
resource.description: provides information designed to help understand, assess, and predict changes in the global environment. Topics include atmospheric composition, climate variability and change, ecosystems, global carbon cycle, global water cycle, land use, and human contributions and responses.

image.caption: A floating iceberg
image.alttext: A floating iceberg off the Antarctic Peninsula. Photo courtesy CU-Boulder National Snow and Ice Data Center.

resource.title: Waterford, Virginia: From Mill Town to National Historic Landmark
resource.description: tells the story of a village west of Washington, D.C. In 1733, Amos Janney purchased 400 acres along Catoctin Creek and built a mill for grinding flour and sawing wood. As fellow Quakers came to the area seeking fertile farmlands, a settlement grew up around "Janney's Mill." Renamed Waterford in the 1790s, the settlement prospered. Markets were expanded by the Chesapeake/Ohio Canal and Baltimore/Ohio Railroad. The area was devasted by the Civil War and never returned to its pre-war success.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Main Street hill, circa 1862
image.alttext: View down Main Street hill, circa 1862. (The Waterford Foundation)

resource.title: Furniture from the Index of American Design
resource.description: displays 26 chairs, tables, and other pieces that show the major styles of fine American furniture from 1650 to 1850. During this time, American furniture followed English fashions but was simpler in form and decoration.

image.caption: Chest of Drawers
image.alttext: 'Chest of Drawers,' Rendered by Ferdinand Cartier. watercolor, colored pencil, pen and ink on paperboard, 54.8 x 62.5 cm (21 9/16 x 24 5/8 in.) Index of American Design, 1943.8.4699

resource.title: FBI Youth
resource.description: invites students to take the "special agent challenge," spend a day in the life of an FBI employee, follow a case through the FBI lab, learn about investigations throughout the world, see specially trained dogs that locate bombs and drugs, and read about the history of the FBI.

image.caption: ...a strange flashlight
image.alttext: Color photo of a lab technician

interestingfact.text: At the time of the arrest at a park in Vienna, Virginia, Robert Philip Hanssen, age 56, was clandestinely placing a package containing highly classified information at a pre-arranged, or "dead drop," site for pick-up by his Russian handlers. Hanssen had previously received substantial sums of money from the Russians for the information he disclosed to them.

resource.title: Behind the Veil: Documenting African American Life in the Jim Crow South
resource.description: is a research project on African American life during the Jim Crow era (c. 1890s-1950s). It was a time of undeniable oppression and exploitation of black Americans; however, these 60 years of legal segregation in the South were also a time when African Americans built communities and institutions, resisted discrimination despite personal risk, and influenced American culture.

resource.title: Launching the New U.S. Navy
resource.description: tells how and why our Navy was created. After the Revolutionary War, Barbary pirates preyed on American vessels and held seamen for ransom. In 1794, Congress reestablished the Navy with authorization for six vessels.

resource.title: Benjamin Franklin
resource.description: explores Franklin's life as a writer, inventor, diplomat, businessman, musician, scientist, humorist, civic leader, international celebrity, abolitionist, and genius. It includes information on his experiments, role as a founding father, his diplomatic work, and his community work. Lesson plans, a timeline, interactive science experiments, a kite building exercise, and other resources are also available.

image.caption: A man of letters
image.alttext: Drawing of 'Franklin the Editor'

interestingfact.text: Benjamin Franklin was born in Boston on January 17, 1706, the fifteenth child of his father Josiah and eighth child of his mother Abiah. Josiah Franklin earned his living as a candle and soap maker.

resource.title: Ecybermission
resource.description: is a web-based math, science, and technology competition for teams in grades 6, 7, 8, and 9. Each team proposes a solution to a real problem in their community and competes for regional and national awards (such as U.S. savings bonds). Last year's winning 8th-grade team devised a 2-digit key code system to speed the handling of 911 calls. Registration is open through December 15.

resource.title: Using Primary Sources in the Classroom
resource.description: offers suggestions for using photos, documents, and other artifacts to help make history come to life for students. Suggestions include the use of inventions, uniforms, fashion, tombstones, oral histories, interviews, music, census data, land surveys, maps, blueprints, or architectural drawings, cookbooks, advertisements, and ancestors' photos, clothes, and papers.

image.caption: Red Star Line
image.alttext: Color drawing of the Red Star Line from 'Emergence of Advertising in America: Advertising Ephemera'

resource.title: The Nineteenth Century in Print: the Making of America in Books and Periodicals
resource.description: presents digitized books and periodicals published in the U.S. during the 19th century. The collection includes 23 popular magazines and more than 1,500 books that illuminate themes central to American life in the mid- to late 19th century, including the Civil War, slavery and abolition, religion, education, self-help and self-improvement, travel and westward expansion, and poetry.

image.caption: The Self-Instructor in Phrenology and Physiology
image.alttext: Illustration from Phrenology book. The self-instructor in phrenology and physiology: with over one hundred new illustrations, including a chart for the use of pratical phrenologists / by O.S. and L.N.

interestingfact.text: Many nineteenth-century Americans revelled in the amplitude of language, whether spoken or written, and delighted to frame their perceptions in the structures of poetry. The result was an outpouring of poetic works and the extensive employment of poetic quotation in texts of many kinds.

resource.title: American Notes: Travels in America, 1750-1920
resource.description: provides 253 narratives describing travels in the colonies and U.S. The collection includes works by authors not widely known as well as by Matthew Arnold, James Fenimore Cooper, Dickens, Washington Irving, Sir Charles Lyell, Robert Louis Stevenson, and other major figures. The collection is searchable and can be browsed by not only by author and title, but also by subject.

image.caption: A short American tramp...
image.alttext: Illustration from, A short American tramp on the fall of 1864, by the editor of 'Life in Normandy', John Francis Campbell, (Edinburgh, Edmonston and Douglas, 1865.)

interestingfact.text: "I left London with the feeling of the captive of Chillon, who regretted his prison when he stepped out of it. The exile is nowhere at home, and his stay is bitter everywhere. After the deceptions I experienced in my life, I no longer cherished any delusion, and like the personage of Gogol, I was about to move from one gaol to another," said Ivan Golovin in Stars and stripes, or American Impressions.

resource.title: The Wilbur and Orville Wright Papers
resource.description: documents the Wright brothers' lives and their work that led to the world's first powered, controlled, and sustained flight. Nearly 50,000 digital images are provided?diaries, scrapbooks, drawings, photos, and more. Learn about the Wright brothers' boyhoods and early business ventures. See the famous glass-plate negative of the "First Flight" at Kitty Hawk on December 17, 1903. Read letters and diaries in which they recount the work leading up to that day.

image.caption: Patent on the flying machine
image.alttext: [Patent, 22 May 1906]. Wilbur and Orville Wright Papers. Subject File: Patents-- By Wright Brothers--USA-- filed 23 March 1903, patented 22 May 1906. Manuscript Division, Library of Congress.

resource.title: VA Kids
resource.description: offers information about America's veterans, the U.S. flag, the history of veterans day, and the Department of Veterans Affairs. It includes a resource guide for teachers, as well as classroom projects and activities for Veterans Day.

image.caption: "... to care for him..."
image.alttext: Image of Lincoln in front of the flag

interestingfact.text: When two or more flags are flown from the same pole, the American flag must be on top. Also, when the flag is flown at half-staff, it should be pulled to the top for a moment, and then lowered to the half-staff position.

resource.title: Science Education
resource.description: includes booklets on cells, genes, health, chemistry, and medicines. The booklets explore advances in the development and delivery of drugs, links between genes and diseases, how genes work, the body's reaction to medicines, and the hundreds of thousands of molecules that perform specialized functions inside the fundamental unit of life (the cell). One booklet, "The Structures of Life," features stories designed to inspire young people to consider careers in biomedical research.

publisher.name: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

image.caption: Molecules to medicines
image.alttext: Colchicine, a treatment for gout, was originally derived from the stem and seeds of the meadow saffron (autumn crocus). Illustration: National Agriculture Library, ARS, USDA.

interestingfact.text: The human body keeps time with a master clock called the suprachiasmatic nucleus or SCN. Situated inside the brain, it's a tiny sliver of tissue about the size of a grain of rice, located behind the eyes. It sits quite close to the optic nerve, which controls vision, and this means that the SCN "clock" can keep track of day and night. Given enough time, your SCN can reset itself after you fly in an airplane from one time zone to another.

resource.title: Library of Congress LIVE
resource.description: is a series of free events and webcasts that combine the treasures from the Library's collections with music, dance and dialogue. Webcast archives include the invention, art, and science of Leonardo da Vinci; music and stories from Scandinavia; Celtic stories, songs, and traditions; and the alley communities of Washington, D.C.

resource.title: Molecular Workbench
resource.description: offers tools for visualizing and computing the motion of atoms and molecules. See simulations of diffusion, dissolution, distillation, chemical reactions, chain reactions, equilibrium, catalysis, self-assembly, x-ray diffraction, light-matter interactions, DNA hybridization, nano machinery, Maxwell's law of speed distribution, Archimedes' principle of buoyancy, Pascal's principle, ideal gas laws, and more.

image.caption: From monomers to polymers
image.alttext: Uniformity and diversity of life's building blocks

interestingfact.text: Many functions of living cells are made possible by the spontaneous organization of molecules of various types in an amazingly accurate way. This is called self-assembly. Self-assembly is considered a promising nano-assembly.

resource.title: Earth System Science Education Alliance
resource.description: offers three earth science courses for teachers. The courses are delivered over the Internet for teachers of grades K-4, 5-8, and 9-12. A master teacher mentors 20-24 teachers; an Earth scientist assists with science content. Teachers collaborate and earn graduate or continuing education credit while solving problems, building models, and designing classroom activities.

resource.title: Teaching About the Holocaust
resource.description: offers teachers an online workshop, teaching guide, chronology, personal histories, lessons, and other publications for teaching about the Holocaust. Online learning activities and resources are provided for students, families, and adults. The Museum provides conferences and workshops in Washington, D.C., and across the U.S.

image.caption: Auschwitz
image.alttext: Candles mark the railway tracks leading to the Auschwitz camp. January 27, 2005.

interestingfact.text: While many were indifferent, thousands of Europeans risked their lives to help Jews. Agnes Mandl Adachi was born in Budapest, Hungary, in 1918. One night, she and three men jumped in the freezing Danube River and saved 50 people.

resource.title: Holocaust Encyclopedia
resource.description: weaves photos, narratives, and historical footage into a web presentation on more than 20 Holocaust topics, including antisemitism, pogroms, the Third Reich, the "final solution," the camp system, forced labor, mobile killing units, ghettos, the resistence, the U.S. and the Holocaust, World War II, and the liberation of the camps.

image.caption: The aftermath
image.alttext: Soon after liberation, surviving children of the Auschwitz camp walk out of the children's barracks. Poland, after January 27, 1945.

interestingfact.text: Kindertransport (Children's Transport) was the informal name of a rescue effort which brought thousands of refugee Jewish children to Great Britain from Nazi Germany between 1938 and 1940.

resource.title: Wright Brothers National Memorial: Site of the First Controlled Powered Flight
resource.description: tells how bicycle makers in Dayton, Ohio, launched the aviation age. After reading about the glider accident that killed Otto Lilienthal, Wilbur and Orville Wright spent four years designing flying machines in Dayton and testing them near Kitty Hawk. Maps and photos show their flying machines and living quarters on the windswept dunes of the Outer Banks where, on December 17, 1903, they made history.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: 1901 glider
image.alttext: Wilbur Wright flying the 1901 glider. (Courtesy of Special Collections and Archives, Wright State University, Repository # 15-5-16; N542)

resource.title: The Battle of Bennington: An American Victory
resource.description: recounts a small but important triumph in the summer of 1777. For two months, General John Burgoyne led his army along the Lake Champlain-Hudson River corridor, capturing several American forts. In August, however, finding himself in need of provisions, wagons, and horses, he sent a force to Bennington, Vermont, to capture these supplies. What happened there contributed to the British defeat at Saratoga and helped decide the outcome of the war.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: The Battle of Bennington...
image.alttext: Alonzo Chappel's painting of The Battle of Bennington, August 16, 1777 (Collections of The Bennington Museum, Bennington, Vermont).

interestingfact.text: Sources suggest that of the approximately 2.5 million people living in the American colonies, 20 to 30 percent were Loyalists. Another 20 percent were enslaved Africans and another 300,000 to 400,000 did their best to remain neutral. Those supporting independence probably counted for less than half of the people of the colonies.

resource.title: Colorful Impressions: Printmaking Revolution in 18th Century France
resource.description: presents 15 pieces from the period of innovation unleashed by German artist Jakob Christoffel Le Blon's breakthrough in the use of color in the 1720s. The resulting "printed paintings" and "engraved drawings," as they were called, allowed the middle classes to hang on their walls replicas of art works found in the mansions of aristocrats and royalty.

image.caption: A Woman Playing the Guitar
image.alttext: Jean-François Janinet after Nicolas Lavreince (French, 1752 - 1814) 'A Woman Playing the Guitar,' 1788/1789, wash manner, printed in blue, red, yellow, and black inks, National Gallery of Art, Widen

interestingfact.text: Accustomed as we are today to seeing color in images in every conceivable medium, color prints hardly seem revolutionary. Color was in fact a regular ingredient in prints from their invention in the early 1400s, but at that time color was always applied by hand. The invention of ways to create realistic-looking printed color took another three hundred years.

resource.title: The Lewis and Clark Expedition: Documenting the Uncharted Northwest
resource.description: recounts the expedition's crossing of the Lemhi Pass and Lolo Trail, and the time spent at Fort Clatsop near the Pacific Ocean. Although the Corps of Discovery did not realize its dream of finding a water route to the Pacific Ocean, the expedition overcame many obstacles and dangers to open the Northwest to the influence of the U.S., established relations with American Indian tribes, and gathered useful scientific documentation.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: United States in 1800
image.alttext: The United States in 1800 -- adapted from the 1800 and 1810 U.S. territorial growth maps in the National Atlas of the United States of America, U.S. Department of the Interior Geological Survey, Washi

resource.title: Wheat Farms, Flour Mills, and Railroads: A Web of Interdependence
resource.description: examines those three industries as they evolved together in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area and North Dakota during the late 1800s. The three depended on each other for success and propelled this region to dominance in U.S. flour production for more than half a century.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: West side milling district
image.alttext: West Side Milling District, Minneapolis, ca. 1890. (Minnesota Historical Society, photographer unknown)

resource.title: Paterson, New Jersey: America's Silk City
resource.description: examines conditions that led to the famous 1913 strike in a city that produced nearly half the U.S.'s manufactured silk. Conflicts between labor and management increased in the U.S. during the early 20th century. In Paterson, on January 27, 1913, when Henry Doherty tried to extend a new "four-loom system" throughout his plant, 800 silk weavers walked out. More than 20,000 Paterson silk workers took part in the strike, which lasted over five months.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Dye house workers, ca. 1900
image.alttext: Dye house workers, ca. 1900. (Courtesy of the Passaic County Historical Society)

resource.title: Chesterwood: Workshop of an American Sculptor
resource.description: describes the work and estate of one of America's most important sculptors. Daniel Chester French (1850-1931) produced more than 100 works?the statue of Abraham Lincoln for the Lincoln Memorial?during a period when sculptors enjoyed high status. Models and sketches from the Lincoln project, which took nine years, are provided, as are photos of the farmhouse that he converted into his estate and workshop.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Sketch model of Abraham Lincoln
image.alttext: Sketch model of 'Abraham Lincoln.' Peter A. Juley & Son Collection, Smithsonian American Art Museum.

resource.title: New Kent School and the George W. Watkins School: From Freedom of Choice to Integration
resource.description: looks at the 1968 Supreme Court ruling that ended a decade of resistance to school desegregation in the South (1955-1964) and triggered massive integration of schools (1968-1973). The New Kent and George W. Watkins schools illustrated typical characteristics of a southern rural school system that achieved token desegregation following the Brown decision.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: 1967 girls basketball team
image.alttext: 1967 New Kent School Yearbook. Courtesy of New Kent County Public Schools, Virginia.

resource.title: Mark Rothko: The Mural Projects
resource.description: presents nine works by one of America's foremost artists. The works are related to two mural commissions from the 1950s-1960s. Rothko (1903-1970) is closely identified with the New York School, a circle of painters that emerged during the 1940s. He created a new and impassioned form of abstract painting.

image.caption: Untitled (Harvard Mural sketch)
image.alttext: Untitled (Harvard Mural sketch), 1962. Gift of The Mark Rothko Foundation, Inc. Copyright © 1997 Christopher Rothko and Kate Rothko Prizel

resource.title: The Secret Life of the Brain
resource.description: presents a history of efforts to understand the brain, a three-dimensional tour of the brain, optical illusions, and an animation showing how magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) works. Videoclips examine how the brain evolves and differs from infancy to childhood, adolescence, and through adulthood.

image.caption: Scanning the brain
image.alttext: Photo of the brain

interestingfact.text: Phineas Gage, a railroad worker, survived a bizarre accident in which the frontal lobe of his brain was pierced by an iron rod during an explosion. He recovered, but experienced profound mood and behavior changes. This famous case was an important milestone in the study of the brain's anatomy because it suggested that key parts of the personality resided in the frontal lobe.

resource.title: Galileo's Battle for the Heavens
resource.description: explains why Galileo is the father of modern science, why Galileo's refractor and Newton's reflector remain the two standard types of optical telescopes today, and Galileo's big mistake. See demonstrations of his experiments, an illustrated chronology of his life, an online pendulum, and an interactive inclined plane.

image.caption: Before the Inquisition
image.alttext: Galileo appears before the Inquisition, circa 1632, in a 19th-century painting by Joseph-Nicolas Robert-Fleury.

interestingfact.text: The drama of Galileo's trial by the Inquisition in 1633 has cast him as a renegade astronomer who drew fire from a Church blind to reason, but the real Galileo, never tortured or excommunicated, remained a loyal Catholic throughout his life. He pursued all his bold investigations convinced that Nature followed a Divine order.

resource.title: Creative Space: Fifty Years of Robert Blackburn's Printmaking Workshop
resource.description: features works by the master printmaker and by his collaborators, students, and friends. Blackburn (1920 - 2003) changed the course of American art through his graphic work and the Printmaking Workshop, which he founded in New York City in 1948. His experiments in color lithography helped fuel the explosion of graphic art during the 1960s.

image.caption: Man With Load
image.alttext: Robert Blackburn (1920-2003) 'Man With Load' (or 'The Toiler, Toil'), 1936. Charcoal, ink, and graphite from Prints and Photographs Division.

interestingfact.text: Following high school graduation in 1940, Blackburn attended the Art Students League in New York until 1943. By late 1947, he had acquired his own lithographic press. In 1948, he opened his own studio in Chelsea, printing for artists and encouraging his friends to experiment in lithography.

resource.title: Mars Exploration Rover Mission
resource.description: provides images and updates on the two Mars rovers, Spirit and Opportunity, which landed on Mars in 2004. Videos and text depict the challenges of getting to Mars: testing the rovers on Martian terrain, launching the rovers, navigating their flights, bringing them into the Martian atmosphere, landing them, and getting them out of the lander cocoon.

image.caption: Rover
image.alttext: Artistic image of Rover on the Martin surface.

resource.title: Back Stairs at Brucemore: Life as Servants in Early 20th Century America
resource.description: looks at the role of servants at a 33-acre estate during the early 1900s. The 21-room mansion was built in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, in the 1880s with a separate entrance, dining area, and stairs for servants. Servants cleaned house, supervised children, washed laundry, cooked meals, cared for the garden and farm animals, and maintained carriages and cars. Floor plans, photos, and diary excerpts are included.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: The Brucemore estate
image.alttext: Arial photo of the Brucemore estate located in Cedar Rapids, Iowa.

interestingfact.text: When George and Irene Douglas moved to Brucemore in 1906, they had two daughters, Margaret and Ellen. Another daughter, Barbara, was born shortly afterward. The Douglases personalized the estate to meet their needs as a growing family and transformed their home into a fully functioning country estate.

resource.title: America's Space Program: Exploring a New Frontier
resource.description: tells the story of America's journey to the moon. The creation of NASA, the Apollo vehicles, and the January 1967 tragedy are part of the story. On July 20, 1969, as the Eagle lunar module approached the moon, it became clear that the computer had chosen an unacceptable landing site -- a boulder-strewn crater. With 114 seconds of fuel left, astronauts Armstrong and Aldrin overrode the computers and manually landed the Eagle.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Apollo 11 to the moon
image.alttext: Photo of the launch of the 'Saturn V' rocket that propelled Apollo 11 to the moon.

interestingfact.text: The Apollo project to put a man on the Moon was a product of the 1960s, a period of heightened Cold War tensions. Allegations of a dangerous "missile gap" between the Soviet Union and the United States had been an important element in John F. Kennedy's successful presidential campaign in 1960.

resource.title: 1900 America: Historical Voices, Poetic Visions
resource.description: is a lesson plan in which students create their own multi-media epic poems about the year 1900. Walt Whitman?s "Song of Myself" and Hart Crane?s "The Bridge" serve as artistic models for students, who also draw on life histories, sound recordings, and other primary resources.

resource.title: America at the Centennial
resource.description: uses images and texts from the Philadelphia Centennial Exposition of 1876 to help students learn what the Exposition said about America at that time. Students work as historians using primary sources to create museum exhibits on issues of the Centennial Era.

image.caption: The Corliss engine
image.alttext: Our centennial--President Grant and Dom Pedro starting the Corliss engine / from a sketch by Theo. R. Davis.

resource.title: Artifact Road Show
resource.description: outlines a staff development workshop and offers lessons designed to help students put historical events in context and see them as a part of a larger story. Use of primary resources is the focus -- where to find them, what they are, how to examine them, and how to "construct the context" to tell the whole story.

resource.title: The Robinson House: A Portrait of African American Heritage
resource.description: pieces together the story of the James Robinson family from artifacts found in archaeological excavations around the house where they lived for nearly a century. An African American born free in 1799, Robinson worked in a Virginia tavern earning nearly $500 to purchase 170 acres of land near Bull Run. There he built a log cabin, and his family turned the land into a prosperous farm, making him one of the wealthiest African Americans in the Manassas area in the mid-19th century.

image.caption: The house in 1850
image.alttext: The original Robinson House was small - only 1½ stories with 400? of living space and a porch. According to 1850 census data, nine people lived in James Robinson?s small home.

resource.title: Harry Truman and Independence, Missouri:
resource.description: features the home and story of our thirty-third President. Upon returning home after World War I, Truman married his childhood sweetheart, started a clothing store that failed, and was elected to a judgeship and later the U.S. Senate. He was Vice President 82 days when President Roosevelt died. As President, he used the atomic bomb to end World War II, instituted the Marshall Plan, and sent troops to defend South Korea when the North invaded.

publisher.name: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places
publisher.agency: National Park Service, Teaching with Historic Places

image.caption: Truman at the Capitol
image.alttext: [Photo] Harry S Truman at the U.S. Capitol Building

interestingfact.text: Citizen Truman spent his retirement years continuing to contribute to his town, his country, and the world. He published his memoirs and raised funds to construct his presidential library and museum. On December 26, 1972, the former President died. His wife, Bess, continued to live in their home until she passed away on October 18, 1982. In her will, she left the home and most of its possessions to the people of the United States.

resource.title: Ethnographic Program
resource.description: provides a map linked to nearly 60 national park sites and resources that emphasize the role of African Americans in the development of American culture, heritage, and history. Each link describes the importance of that park or resource to African American history.

image.caption: What is ethnography?
image.alttext: Officers of Women's League, Newport, R.I. Courtesy of the Library of Congress, Prints and Photographs, W.E.B. DuBois Collection.

resource.title: Marco Paul's Travels on the Erie Canal
resource.description: is a lesson plan that draws on photos, texts, and other sources to help students learn about the Erie Canal and its impact on the economic and social growth of New York and the nation.

image.caption: Boats on the Erie Canel
image.alttext: Packet boat from the collection of the Rochester City Hall Photo Lab (Courtesy of Rochester Images)

resource.title: The Branding of America
resource.description: offers thumbnail histories of nearly 30 well-known brand names associated with soft drinks, potatoes, cereal, fruit, airplanes, buses, pianos, sewing machines, jeans, shoes, and other products.

image.caption: Kellogg's
image.alttext: Kellogg toasted corn flakes cereal, 1906

resource.title: The Online Academy
resource.description: highlights artifacts, scholars, collectors, and preservers of African American history. Features include the inventor of the multiple effect vacuum process for producing sugar, the first identified African American toolmaker, the autobiography of an African American cowboy, and Zora Neale Hurston's first novel.

publisher.name: Anacostia Museum and Center for African American History and Culture

image.caption: Carte de visite for Frederick Douglass
image.alttext: Carte de visite (French for 'visiting card'). Visiting card photograph of Frederick Douglass, prominent writer and orator; ca. 4 x 2-1/2. Late 1800s

interestingfact.text: Langston Hughes (1902-1967) was a major figure of the Harlem Renaissance, the blossoming of African American art, literature, culture, and criticism of the 1920s and 1930s, centered primarily in New York City, but flourishing also in Washington, D.C., Chicago, and other urban centers.

resource.title: National Museum of African Art
